Coupled Fluid-Structure Model For Improved Evaluation Of Vestibular Function During In-Flight Conditions
A Joint Experiment/Computational Study of Endothermic Chemistry In Aviation Fuels
Three-axis Locomotion Simulator for Dismounted Troops
Exploiting Chaos to Improve Signal Detection

abstract: We propose to design a hybrid neural network and knowledge base automatic classification system which dynamically constructs an optimal decision tree. Our proposed hybrid system offers several advantages. Expert system knowledge bases will be used to construct the decision hierarchy with neural network modules acting as classifiers at the nodes of the tree. Neural networks such as Fuzzy ARTMAP can be trained with ease and little computational effort. The proposed research extends the concept of self-organization from within the neural network outward to the overall structure of the decision hierarchy to support dynamic construction of an optimal decision tree. We will analyze the feasibility of the approach via demonstration and comparison with a previously developed ATR system. The military significance of our Phase I work includes adaptive and robust classification of potential targets given large quantities of features from preprocessed sensor data.  The commercial application will lead to a general supervised classification system capable of rapid decision making and dynamic reorganization of its internal structure. In addition to the planned use in our own intelligent agent software, applications also exist for the technology to speech processing and medical imaging systems. We also see commercial software applications via the development of a neural network/expert systems shell targeted to aerospace, electrical, mechanical and civil engineering.
title: Hybrid Neural Network/Knowledge Base Automated Classification System

abstract: This Phase I study will evaluate the feasibility of using artificial neural networks (ANNs) for real-time detection of helicopter performance limit exceedance.  We propose to integrate two complementary technologies: ANNs and fuzzy logic (FL).  ANNs will be used to represent the complex hypersurfaces that define a helicopter's performance limits, and fuzzy logic will be used to perform limit detection and classification during operation.  Fuzzy logic will also be used to develop control augmentation logic for preventing limit exceedance.  The purpose of this hybrid system is to provide a helicopter and its pilot with real-time protection from performance limit exceedances that might lead to catastrophic failure, loss of control, or degrade airframe fatigue life.  The system will be designed to detect limit exceedances based on the patterns presented by the aircraft's state and control deflections.  Following development, a feasibility demonstration will be conducted using a limited-scope engineering simulation of an existing helicopter, providing a foundation for real-time evaluation under a Phase II effort.
title: A Hybrid Neural/Fuzzy Limit Detection and Exceedence Prevention System for Helicopters

abstract: Today's battlefield environment poses an increasing challenge due to more sophisticated and capable threats.  What is required is to find a method that can detect, classify, and engage targets using multisensor data in a timely, efficient manner and which is robust to countermeasures, environmental effects, and sensor limitations and constrains.  We propose a hybrid neural network/fuzzy logic/information processing approach for battlefield sensor fusion.  Our approach is based on successful results using a hybrid approach.  Our baseline Phase I effort will focus on development of a sensor database that includes sensor characteristics and capabilities versus mission requirements and identifies neural network/fuzzy logic implementation solutions.  Additionally, we propose an optional feasibility demonstration by developing and evaluating a prototype system.  Our hybrid approach to sensor fusion offers several advantages. Neural networks offer rapidly adaptable on-line solutions, capability to fuse multispectral channels and to detect and classify new threat classes, and implementation efficiency on emerging VLSI designs.  Fuzzy logic complements neural networks in sensor calibration, interpreting network outputs, detecting and classifying threats, fusing decisions from parallel neural and rule base classifiers, and incorporating ambiguous information. Information processing algorithms perform sensor measurement pre-processing, data alignment, feature extraction, an data association.
title: Neural Networks and Fuzzy Logic for Battlefield Sensor Fusion
Hybrid Methodology for Knowledge Elicitation and Mental Model Visualization
Agent Based Human Interfaces For Space Crews
Model-Based Situation Awareness Metric for Air Superiority Scenarios
A Recurrent Neural Network/Expert System Approach to Automated Task Planning and Resource Allocation
A Model-Based On-Line Cockpit Error Monitoring System
Information Filtering for Rapid Battlefield Visualization

abstract: Composite structures are lighter, stronger, and have more predictable performance than do components implemented with conventional metal structures.  However, defense and industry have been slow to adopt composites components, even in application areas where firm cost justification arguments can be made, because of inexperience with composite structure failure modes and the difficulty of routine NDE inspection.  The proposed development and testing activity will alleviate this problem by:  (1) providing a strong database relating NDE measurements with destructively analyzed composite structure failure modes (i.e. quantitative data relating measurable external phenomena with internal structural integrity of the composite components).  (2) providing validated NDE testing equipment on (1) above which eases customer acceptance of composite materials-based components by allowing easy on-site measurement of incoming and field-installed components to assure safety and reliability (quality assurance after installation, during operation, and after maintenance).  (3) supporting low cost, 100% routing inspection of composite components during and after the manufacturing process (quality assurance during and after manufacture).
title: Rapid Nondestructive Optical Inspection of Advanced Composite Structures

abstract: The complexity and cost of Air Force satellite ground control operations, coupled with current downsizing efforts, point to the need for space-based diagnostic capability for satellite systems.  Cybernet Systems proposed the development of an innovative diagnostic architecture.  This architecture will combine artificial intelligence paradigms such as neural networks and expert systems to create a diagnostic agent.  This system will have immediate use in ground operations, and will be a viable candidate for moving to space to be located on the satellites themselves.  Cybernet's innovative approach to solving the diagnostic problem will embed a general-purpose diagnostic engine within a reconfigurable framework, thereby creating a diagnostic agent with tremendous dual-use potential.  This proposal leverages Cybernet Systems' extensive experience with artificial intelligence and adaptive network systems design and systems integration, particularly in the areas of diagnostic systems and space-related software.
title: Reconfigurable Space-Based Diagnostic Agent

abstract: Commercial perimeter monitoring systems rely heavily upon visual band CCD surveillance cameras.  To enhance monitoring operations at night, the military often adds IR surveillance technology, as well as low light TV capability.  In all of these image-based monitoring activities, we expect a human operator to confirm intruder alerts before the intruder is close enough to be positively identified. Thus, positive confirmation requires personnel to issue verbal challenges to distinguish between intruders and authorized personnel.  We propose the alternative of providing authorization through an active transponding system which can be interrogated through existing image-based surveillance equipment, even when the personnel are located at extreme ranges.  This approach is compatible with visual and IR band surveillance imaging systems and also supports providing low cost IFF function to the individual soldier.
title: Active Identify Friend/Foe Intruder System

abstract: Conventional imaging spectrometers acquire data within a four dimensional continuum (x, y, lambda, t) in several ways, all of which involve some form of scanning--mirrors must be moved or different filters must be dialed in.  We are proposing a highly innovative imaging spectrometer concept that is non-scanning and contains no moving parts.  The elimination of scanning results in a more rugged design and enables the instantaneous collection of all data needed for the subsequent reconstruction of the three dimensional (x, y, lambda) data at each instant of time.  A laboratory version of this system has been demonstrated and the preliminary results are very favorable.  This Phase I SBIR proposed to initiate a development/refinement process which converts this proof of principle system into a fieldable instrument with a well documented design methodology.
title: Non-Scanning, No Moving Parts, Computed Tomographic Imaging Spectrometer

abstract: Conventional imaging spectrometers acquire data within a four dimensional continuum (x,y,l,t) in several ways, all of which involve some form of scanning--mirrors must be moved or different filters must be dialed in. We are proposing to compare the relative costs and benefits of three different approaches to obtaining multispectral imaging data. The three proposed approaches represent a broad cross section of performance and cost relative to the four dimensional multispectral imaging problem. The three approaches include (1) multiple focal planes with fixed filters, (2) a single focal plane with switched filters, and (3) a single focal plane with 2 D holographic gratings based on a highly innovative imaging spectrometer concept recently demonstrated at the University of Arizona that is non-scanning and contains no moving parts. The three design approaches include dewar designs that encompass optical, thermal, mechanical and electrical design details based on existing IR focal planes. This Phase I SBIR comparative design will conclude with a recommendation for the best approach to be pursued in Phases II and III.
title: Multispectral Imaging Comparative Design Study

abstract: Attitude estimation of 3D objects is a necessary component of many of today's most difficult problems.  Currently White Sands Missile Range (WSMR) has an application in which they wish to use live imagery from multiple video sources to precisely determine the attitude or pose of missiles, aircraft, and submunitions as they pass through the field of view.  This proposal describes a system that solves this problem using an existing software package developed by the research team and leveraging off of the cost-effective trends in COTS parallel processing in the commercial market-place.  The Phase I effort will process imagery from WSMR in order to a) make the necessary system modifications to achieve desired performance and b) arrive at a real-time implementation design.  The required speed and throughput of the proposed system are aggressive, but achievable due to the extensive experience possessed by the research team in all required technical areas.
title: A Highly Leveraged Real-Time Pose Determination System

abstract: Transmittance pulse oximetry is currently the preferred method of noninvasive oxgenative monitoring.  However, this type of monitoring is limited with regards to peripheral probe placement, creating an inability to measure deep-tissue oxygenation to the level desired.  Recently reflective methods have been applied to pulse oimetry;  however, the reflected signal isdifficult to measure and interpret.  The reflective studies performed to date utilize individual probe placement and measurements schemes.  We propose an alternative approach invoking multiple probes fabricated to incorporate deep tissue oxygenation characterization in conjunction with surface assessment.  A volumetric profile will be established to formulate a more complete representation of systemic oxygenation - a profile with increased resolution and sensitivity. Associated experimental data integrated with theoretical analysis will assist in the formulation of a coherent mathematical model. Time resolved spectroscopy will be investigated using pulse sequencing as opposed to individual narrow pulses.  This approach will augment experimental tissue diffusion investigation.  The Phase I study will produce the sensor system design to best detect surface and deep tissue oxygenation noninvasively.
title: The MOST-Monitor for Oxygenation of Surface and Tissue
A Perception- Based Image Rendering System
Whole Body Kinesthetic Displays
Graphics, Sensors, And Planning For Robotics
Micro-Inertial Momentum Sphere Stabilizers
Perception-Based Image Interpretation
A Miniature Portable Physiological Measurement And Analysis System
A Virtual Test Range for Real and Virtual Equipment

abstract: With the development of advanced technologies (including military weapons), more and more chemicals are employed, subsequently, more hazardous chemicals and chemical agents are generated (e.g.millions of pounds of military chemical wastes per year in USA).  Some of these chemicals related to military chemical wastes are phosphorus-based chemicals, chlorocarbons, and stimulants.  At present, these chemicals are treated by incineration at high temperature.  In the past, it is found that certain ultrafine (nanoscale), highly reactive metal oxide (e.g. CaO and MgO) could absorb these toxic chemicals and allow for reclamation of valuable byproducts as fuels or feedstock.  This technique is named as Destructive Absorption Technology (DAT).  In the proposed research, we will develop a low cost fabrication process for high surface area MgO powders.  The process proposed is the sol-gel based aerosol process in which the sol-gel solution reaction will be tailored to produce sparse clusters, and then the solutions will be used as the precursors for the aerosol process to produce high surface area MgO powders.  The powders will be tested for their destructive capacity using stimulants and chlorinated solvents as substrates, and the results will be correlated with the surface area and surface chemistry.
title: Preparation of Low Cost, High Surface Area of Active MgO via the Sol-Gel Based Aerosol Process

abstract: In this research, a TiO(2) ormocer-aerogel thickness film has been proposed.  The TiO(2) ormocer-aerogel can provide advantages both from ormocer and aerogel, such as superior mechanical and optical properties, large surface area, and high porosity.  Up to few hundred um thick of the TiO(2) ormocer-aerogel film can provide much larger surface than the TiO(2) colloidal films to deposit sensitized dye.  Much higher conversion efficiency and reaction rate can be expected.  The capability of the photocatalytic reaction can also be significantly increase.  The continuous network of the ormocer also provides better electronic contact than the colloidal films, better charge transfer between dye and TiO(2) catalyst is possible.  The hydrolysis between sensitized dye and ormocer can also provide crosslinking between dye and TiO(2) matrix, and better efficiency and stability can be expected.  One of the advantages of the sol-gel process is the molecular level mixing.  Therefore, doping effect on the TiO(2) ormocer-aerogel will also be studied in this research.  The activity of the metal or oxide dopants should be significantly improved as that has been in aerogel.  The interaction of the dopants and the sensitized dye will also be studied.  Transparent conductive electrode (ATO, ITO) can also be fabricated by the sol-gel process, which can further decrease the manufacturing cost of the photocatalytic reactor.
title: High Efficiency TiO2 Photocatalyst by the Sol-Gel Process

abstract: The optical systems are widely employed in military and civil equipment. The conventional optical system employs homogeneous materials which sometime are not sufficient to produce an adequate image. In this research, we propose to fabricate axial GRIN glasses via the layering of sol-gel solutions. The proper sol-gel solutions will be synthesized, the technique to form axial GRIN solutions will be identified and the conversion of the GRIN gels to the GRIN glasses will be investigated in this proposed research. The resultant axial GRIN lens will be characterized. This success will introduce new axial GRIN components into optical systems. The introduction of this novel GRIN lens will simplify the optical systems (reduction of number of lens) and improve the performance of the system (e.g. a missile guidance system). In addition, the introduction of these novel axial GRIN lens will benefit the development of small personal photocopiers, fiber optic communications, compact audio disk players, disk cameras, and medical endoscopes. The demonstrative investigation on Phase I will provide the basis for Phase II when the process is scaled up. In addition, the information and experimental data can be utilized to analyze the characterization results on the refractive index profile and to further optimize the process to achieve the desired index profile which will be performed in Phase II. The introduction of this novel GRIN lens will simplify the optical systems and improve the performance of the system (e.g. a missile guidance system). In addition, it will benefit the development of small personal photocopiers, fiber optic communications, compact audio disk players, disk cameras, and medical endoscopes.
title: Refractive Index Gradient Lens Via Sol Gel Process
Multi-Layer Conductive Thermal Control Coatings Via The Sol-Gel Process
Fabrication of TiC Fibers via Polymer Pyrolysis
Amorphous Silicon Carbide Thin Film Photovoltaic Cells by the Sol-Gel Process

A Novel Cyclodextrin-Based Adsorption Process for Natural Products Purification
An Improved Process for Production of Natural Carotene

abstract: We successfully developed and obtained FDA approval for its noninstrumented total cholesterol testAccuMeter(R) technology. The product is presently being sold to consumers. We have also developed antest which is currently being optimized for the over the counter market. The development work for bofunding, in part, from SBIR Phase I and II grants. Extending this technology, we now seek to developquantitative test for LDL cholesterol in whole blood. Such a simple, direct test would be of immenseprofessionals and their patients for assessing risk for coronary heart disease (CHD). Total cholestecholesterol tests performed either in the doctor's office or by patients at home would provide an incloser, timely, and more convenient monitoring of these independent risk factors for CHD. These prodscreening tools, would aid early detection of and treatment for hypercholesterolemia through diet, eto reduce risk of CHD. This research will evaluate methodology for the separation of LDL from otherblood specimens, using the AccuMeter test format. Proposed work will also modify sensitivity of themeasurement of LDL cholesterol in the range of 50-200 mg/dL.
agency: Department of Health and Human Services
title: Noninstrumented Quantitative Assay for Ldl Cholesterol
Adaptation of a Chinook Pontoon Boat Allowing Full Accessibility for Persons Physically Challenged

abstract: Sea water purification technologies have been improved and available to the point that to have water or steam injected gas turbine technology as the Navy ship propulsion system is now a very feasible and attractive technology to meet future Navy mission.  These missions would include:  high thermodynamic efficiency, low pollution, low noise, low infrared signature with fast start-up for improved mobility and increased survivability.  This program integrates all the known ground-based water spray and steam injected experience and technology on a component by component study to arrive at a new thermal cycle tailored for Navy missions.  The Phase I study will be a computerized study on the interactive behavior of major components with water spray or steam  injected systems, which will conclude in the selection of optimized configurations for the engineering design (Phase II).  The study is linked to the hardware test and commercialization program. Phase I will be meticulously performed with the use of the GATE program when applicable, the company's own program where necessary and interactions with major component suppliers to obtain their databases and assistance to assure the success of the program. Interfacing with Navy officials for mission definition and desired performance is recommended as a major key to the program.
title: Improvements to Naval Ship Engines Through Water Addition
Submarine Low Cost Littoral Water Sonar Localization System
Head-Brain Injury Simulator

abstract: A Voice Assistant for Mission Planning (VAMP) is proposed as a user interface for the Navy's Tactical Air Mission Planning System (TAMPS).  This interface will be applied first to a current version of TAMPS which is used only prior to the conduct of the mission, and later to a cockpit mission planning tool that can be used to adjust plans while in-flight.  The interface design will be based on explicit principles for design of voice interfaces which will in turn employ a state-transition-network representation of the current TAMPS graphical user interface (GUI) and a cognitive task analysis of mission planning performance.  The design process will also specify measurable design criteria and methods for estimation of the performance of cnadidate designs on these criteria.  Whereas airborne use of voice will be beneficial in permitting "hands free" interaction with the planning system, the goals of the initial ground-based application will be to provide intelligent assistance in interface navigation and also to enable off-line dictation of preliminary mission specifications.  Plans for the evolution of VAMP along with future versions of TAMPS are also provided.
title: DEVELOPMENT OF A VOICE ASSISTANT FOR MISSION PLANNING
Development of the HUMS Interface System (HINTS) for Helicopters
Commander's Intelligent Battlefield Information Display (CIBID)
ScanEval: An approach for Integrating Eye Tracking into Automated Instructional Environments

title: Cancer Patient Data Retrieval Agent (CAPRA)

title: Electronic Laboratory Notebooks From Pen-Based Computing

abstract:
The research and innovation proposed here will use genetic technology and knowledge to produce a domestic dairy sheep strain productive under United States Southern Region and Third World conditions, while also generating new information about ewe management.  Dairying with sheep presents innovative economic opportunities to the sheep industry, and the number of dairy sheep operations is expanding.  A major limiting factor on dairy sheep production is the availability of dairy genetics.  Another limiting factor for the U.S. Southern Region is the inadequate use of tropically-adapted sheep breeds that tolerate heat and humidity, and possess high feed conversion efficiency and parasite resistance.

In Europe a dairy sheep breed exists with unsurpassed production traits.  The East Friesian dairy sheep has been successfully used in cross breeding programs in the Middle East and Europe.  The proposed research will import East Friesian embryos from Europe while at the same time performing lactation and metabolism studies on two tropically-adapted breeds:  the St. Croix and the Gulf Coast Native.  The ultimate goal of the proposed research is to develop one or two new synthetic strains of sheep that will possess both the excellent production traits of the East Friesian and the hardiness and adaptable qualities of the St. Croix of Gulf Coast Native.
title: Developing Commercial Dairy Sheep for Southern United States Conditions

abstract: The early detection of incipient failure in a Mechanical System is of practical importance as it permits scheduled inspections without costly shutdowns and indicates locations in need of repair before a system will incur any catastrophic failure. This project aims at the development of a comprehensive procedure to identify incipient mechanical faults and their propagations using acoustic signals. Considerable success has been already accomplished by the authors in identifying gear failures from both experimental and analytical vibration signals. Some success had also been achieved in correlating acoustic signals with system vibrations. However, extensive efforts in i) acoustic signal conditioning, ii) correlations between acoustic and vibration signals due to component damage, and, iii) development of pattern recognition and damage estimation procedures for acoustic signals, are required for the development of an accurate machine health monitoring system. In order to develop an accurate signature pattern recognition procedure, a complete database of the acoustic/vibration signals has to be generated. Experimentally validated numerical models will be developed to generate acoustic and vibration signal database for both normal and abnormal operating conditions. The main goals of this study are: a) development of a procedure to eliminate unwanted noise in the acoustic signal and to increase coherence with the vibration b) experimental examination of the applicability of acoustic sensors, c) correlation of acoustic signal with mechanical vibrations, feasibility study of using existing vibration monitoring techniques for acoustic data, and the development of a condition based prognostic procedure to predict component life.
title: Application of Acoustic Sensors for Rotorcraft Gearbox Health Monitoring and Diagnostics

abstract: Coccidiosis is one of the most important diseases of poultry worldwide.  Estimates of the cost to U.S. chicken production alone exceed $350 million dollars annually.  Since coccidia-free environments are unattainable in poultry houses it would be beneficial to identify the levels and species of Eimeria present so that severe infection, impaired feed conversion and production losses can be minimized.  This Phase I research plan proposed here will assess the feasibility of improving coccidiosis management through tests which combine the use of genus and species specific DNA detection to evaluate the level of infection in a flock via quantitative detection of Eimeria oocysts in fecal samples.  Chromagen's proprietary signal amplification technologies will be applied to the synthesis of highly fluorescent DNA probes which hybridize readily and specifically to their respective target sequences.  In addition, the sensitivity of time-resolved fluorescence will be utilized to make the assay effective for detection of Eimeria.  The Phase I effort will be divided into five areas of investigation: (i) development of procedures for sample collection and reproducible isolation of oocysts from fecal samples; (ii) quantitative extraction of sporozoite DNA; (iii) probe development; (iv) evaluation of the hybridization assay for sensitivity, specificity, and reproducibility, and (v) instrumented detection and data management.
title: Development of DNA Probes for Detection and Management of Coccidiosis in Poultry
SBIR: Development of On-Line Raman Spectrometer for the Pharmaceutical Industry
Remote Sensing of Pelagic Fish Stock
Raman Spectrometer for in-vivo Tissue Analysis
Inexpensive Digital Phase Fluorometer
Novel Near Infrared Fluorescent Dyes

abstract: Increasing amounts of the Department of Defense's software costs are going into safety-critical systems.  Our innovation will allow Rome Laboratory to automatically assess the fault-tolerance of its software with a method distinct from the traditional methods of formal analysis or empirical software testing.  We will apply a simulated fault-injection scheme that exercises the region of the input space that is frequently termed as the "ultra-dependable" region.  This innovation will accept code and a user supplied operational distribution, and automatically assess the fault- tolerance of the software for inputs upon which the code is highly unlikely to be tested.  The innovation will automatically determine where additional fault-tolerant mechanisms are necessary, to ensure fault-tolerance throughout the software's life, not simply in the early stages of deployment.  The project objective is to show that such a tool is feasible and the model is theoretically sound, and the anticipated results of this effort are a detailed design for the tool.
title: A Software Quality Methodology That Assesses the Fault Tolerance of Un-tested Inputs
A Dynamic Software Safety Tool For Catastrophic Event Predication Of Ada Systems
A Plausible Software Reliability Assessment Framework
Direct Rapid Prototyping and Process Generation

abstract:
We propose to develop DIALOG, an environment for collaborative decision making that will enable health care providers and administrators to model, learn, and reason about their business enterprise.  DIALOG will utilize a user-friendly, pen- and gesture-based graphical interface, and will enable "any time/any place" collaboration over shared digital libraries and dynamic "microworld" simulations.  It also will support team interactive decision analysis over information.  DIALOG will be optimized for use with a variety of new workgroup technologies, such as wireless LANs, mobile tablet computers, broadband ATM networks, and large, interactive display LiveBoards.  The framework will allow everyone within an enterprise to gain a shared understanding of the "big picture" regarding the organization's goals, purposes, and operations.  It will help people identify potential process improvements, communicate requirements among departments and individuals, and make informed organizational decisions.

This project responds to a critical need to use our emerging computing and telecommunications technologies to improve decision making, increase organizational efficiencies, and improve global competitiveness for U.S. corporations.  DIALOG is an innovative new approach to enabling the learning that is required to improve fundamental business processes, and has strong potential for commercial success within the U.S. healthcare industry and across a broad range of U.S. industries.
title: DIALOG- A Tool for Team Interactive Organizational Learning in the Healthcare Industry

abstract: This proposal involves design of the major capabilities of a dynamical system software package, witprototyping implementation in the MLAB environment. Such major capabilities include analyzing chaotito models, iterate dynamical systems and plot trajectories, defining top level functions and dynamicsystem parameters, etc. During late Phase I and Phase II, we will adapt recent mathematical advancesresearch to improve the modeling and controlling of cardiac chaos. This involves programming more bumodels to facilitate computing periodic points, stable and unstable manifolds of dynamical systems,in control of cardiac chaos and other chaotic biochemical dynamical systems. Finally, late Phase II,interfaces for the software to supply easy tool for input functions, initial conditions, adjust paraperform multiple operations in different windows at the same time.
agency: Department of Health and Human Services
title: Chaoslab--Software for Modeling Chaos for Cardiology

abstract: A research and development program will be conducted using laboratory breadboard equipment capable of producing laser light near the operating frequency of the copper metal laser.  Along with this technical feasibility study, a complete experimental study will be conducted to demonstrate optical gain, net lasing efficiency of the material.  This feasibility and experimental/analytical study will permit selection of proper laser system design parameters prior to construction of a breadboard laser system.
title: Solid (S) Metal (M) Atom (A) Laser (L)

abstract: The Integrated Surface Treatment System (ISTS) Plasma Spray CNC Workcell was originally designed to repair/refurbish a broad range of common worn parts so that they could be returned to service with a minimum of specialized operator skill or ancillary tooling. The concept holds great promise for both the US Government and for commercial industry. However, even though the thermal spray process is routinely used by Government and commercial organizations, the ISTS has yet to be embraced by the US Navy (the sponsor of the original ISTS effort) or by commercial industry. Phase 1 will assess the market needs for the ISTS in the repair and refurbishment of critical worn components based on examples from government and from private industry. It will evaluate the existing performance envelope of the ISTS (including the stand-alone process planner) and explore and recommend additional developments necessary to improve ease of use, productivity, and quality of repair. The cost/value relationship of the ISTS to candidate repair and refurbishment applications will also be detailed.
title: Dual Use Analysis of an Integrated Surface Treatment System

abstract:
The goal of this program is to develop compact, reliable lasers producing intense (millijoule) femtosecond pulses at high repetition rates.  These lasers will be designed to operate in industrial environments and will be ideally suited for non-linear optical diagnostics.  

During the Phase I we will demonstrate that diode-pumped fiber lasers can generate reliably ultrashort pulses, and that their output can be amplified after frequency doubling in various solid state gain media.  During the Phase II we will demonstrate that the solid-state amplifier(s) can be efficiently pumped by light emitting diodes (NOT laser diodes).  The combination of the fiber oscillator and the LED-pumped amplifier will form a powerful, compact, and reliable system of energetic femtosecond pulses.

Our program goals will be reached in collaboration with the Massachusetts Institute of Technology (Prof. E. Ippen) and the University of Rochester (Prof. I. Walmsley).
title: Ultrafast Compact Laser Source for Non-Linear Optical Diagnostics

agency: Department of Health and Human Services
title: Laser Source for 2-Photon-Excited Confocal Microscopy

abstract: Infectious hematopoietic necrosis (IHN) is a highly infectious rhabdoviral disease of important species of trout and salmon, both cultured commercially and as part of Federal and State sport fisheries and enhancement programs.  There are presently no proven or accepted mehtods for prevention or treatment of IHN.  Under the intensive culture conditions of aquaculture, IHN virus (IHNV) can cause significant losses at nearly all stages of production.  The results from preliminary studies suggest that intraspecific variation for IHNV resistance exists in rainbow trout, steelhead, and reciprocal corsses and this may be useful in breeding used to enhance for this trait.  In addition to evaluating select crosses for IHNV resistance, molecular approaches will be used to identify genes associated with resistance.  We anticipate demonstrating the feasibility of using PCR based RAPD analysis to identify unique genetic differences between trout groups differing in the IHNV susceptibility phenotype and to develop an initial set of markets for detailed genetic analyses during the second phase of these studies.
title: Intraspecific IHN Resistance in Rainbow Trout and Steelhead
Miniature Infant Cognitive and Language Assessment System

agency: Department of Health and Human Services
title: Miniature Narrow Band Telemetry System for EEG and AER

abstract: Chromium plating sludge waste from hard and decorative chromium platingoperations is classified as a hazardous waste and its disposal is a majorenvironmental concern.  Climax Research Services (CRS) will develop techniquesto recycle the chromium metal values in the sludge back into the domesticmetallurgical industry as purified aluminothermic chromium metal.  This proposaladdresses initially the hydrometallurgical treatment of chromium plating sludgeto remove unacceptable impurity elements.  Using fractional crystallization ofchromium sulfate followed by calcination, a purified chromic oxide will beproduced from the sludge.  Pre-proposal work by CRS has demonstrated thetechnical validity of this approach.  The chromic oxide will then be transformedby aluminothermic reaction into commercially-viable pure aluminothermic chromiummetal, using procedures developed in a previous EPA research contract.Aluminothermic chromium metal sales will be directed at the national non-ferrousfoundry industry.  This transformation of an environmentally harmful, hazardous,sludge into an environmentally acceptable industrial product is technicallyfeasible and commercially attractive.  It responds directly to EPA concerns forhazardous waste disposal.
title: CONVERSION OF HAZARDOUS CHROMIUM PLATING SLUDGE INTO ALUMINOTHERMIC CHROMIUM METAL
A New Alloy for Refiner Plates in the Pulp and Paper Industry

abstract: Although widely practiced as the current standard of care, electronic fetal monitoring (EFM) has noimproved fetal outcomes. This is partially due to difficulties inherent in fetal heart rate and continterpretation. Oxygen saturation through pulse oximetry has become a standard for detection of hypoill patient. The addition of fetal oxygen saturation to the currently available EFM information hasinvestigated for several years but an acceptable method has not yet been devised. The major issue hareliable and practical method for attachment or application of the oximetry probe to the fetus in sugood pulse signal. We will develop a fetal oximetry system that will be reliable and, at the same timajor element of the optical fetal pulse oximetry probe is to mount the emitters and detector in a fsimilar to those used currently to measure fetal heart rate. Additionally, the design will integratewith the fetal oximetry probe. The improved signal-to-noise ratio and elimination of movement artifawith unique signal processing to give reliable oximetry data using an application method (FSE) alreastandard for clinical use. Our goal is to improve fetal monitoring thereby reducing the morbidity, munnecessary cesarean sections.
agency: Department of Health and Human Services
title: Fetal Oximetry Probe
Direct Detection of Biological Microorganisms Based on Electron Transfer through DNA

abstract: The combined goal of phases I and II is develop optimized cultures of normal human hepatocytes thatmaintain high levels of expression of liver-specific biochemical and metabolic properties for a suffused as an effective model system for the human liver. Expression of cytochrome p450 isoenzymes andalbumin will be used as representative liver-specific markers during initial development, with otherI will examine diverse variables currently believed to influence retention of liver- specific properseverely limiting aspects of non-optimized serum-free cultures that will serve as a starting point.adjustment toward optimal values will also be initiated for the most critical components. The adjustcontinue during phase II, with the goal of optimizing as many as possible of the variables that inflexpression, while also making all aspects of the culture system as simple, stable and reliable as ca
agency: Department of Health and Human Services
title: Optimized Culture Systems for Human Hepatocytes

abstract: The overall goal of Phases I and II is to obtain the benefits of feeder layer cultures of normal hu(NHEK) in a highly defined medium without feeder cells. Feeder layer cultures support robust growth150 population doublings, but the need for serum and a second cell type makes them inconvenient andapplications. abstract:
There are two types of HF radar commercially available for measuring ocean surface currents:  narrow-beam phased-arrays and broad-beam direction-finding SeaSondes.  Comparison between simultaneous data from the two types of radar has never been made, but quantitative differences have been observed in currents measured by a SeaSonde and a phased-array radar deployed in the same location at different times.  We suggest that the differences are caused by antenna distortion due to their nearby surroundings.  Pattern measurements on each have shown significant distortions, while analysis algorithms for both systems are based on perfect patterns.

We propose methods to remove the effect of antenna pattern distortion from SeaSonde current velocities, and use the resulting current maps to simulate the phased-array results, which do not presently account for antenna pattern distortion.  These methods will be applied to currents measured by co-located systems of the two types.  We will use the NOAA/ETL SeaSonde operating at the Long Marine Laboratory in Santa Cruz, California and a phased array radar owned jointly by the University of Michigan, Stanford University and ERIM.  This will be the first simultaneous comparison of data from the SeaSonde and a phased array.
title: Improved Current Mapping with HF Radars: Correction for Antenna Pattern Distortion
TV Based Frame Fusion

abstract: Many areas of military and civilian work are becoming increasingly complex and non-routine.  Cognitive Flexibility Theory is a unique approach to instruction that prepares people to effectively deal with such challenges.  For critical elements of Navy training, complex content domains will be identified that are characterized both by complexity and difficulty in achieving training success.  The particular learning and knowledge application demands in these areas will be analyzed to ascertain congruence with the training advantages provided by Random Access Instructional systems based on Cognitive Flexibility Theory.  Instructional design specifications for Random Access Instruction hypermedia systems for use in two such training areas will be developed based on the theory.  To insure generality and a wide scope of applicability, the identified training domains will be examined for commonalities in the way Cognitive Flexibility Theory would be used to develop Random Access Instruction systems.  Those commonalities will form the basis for specification of features of a generic instructional design system--an "author's aid" of "shell" program that will permit trainers to develop Random Access Instruction hypermedia systems tailored to their domains and having a full complement of features based on Cognitive Flexibility Theory.
title: A System for Designing Random Access Instruction for Navy Courses
Representing and Analyzing Mental Models
Adaptive Signal Processing Techniques for Hands-Free Telecommunication Systems

abstract: High power diode-pumped 2 micron lasers are of great interest for a variety of lidar applications, including long range hard target tracking and space-based coherent laser radar systems operating in the eye-safe region of the spectrum. Lidar modeling suggests that 0.5-1 J/pulse energies at pulse repetition frequencies of about 40 Hz will be sufficient to meet many lidar mission requirements. CTI has recently conceptualized novel approaches to the development of efficient 2 micron lasers, and propose to extend current medium energy development work to the high pulse energy/high average power regime. Our numerical models indicate that a 0.5 J/pulse laser operating at 40 Hz repetition frequency (20W average power) with an electrical-to-optical efficiency of 5-10% in a simple oscillator configuration, is feasible to build with off-the-shelf components available today. This is a significant advance over realistic estimates of conventional oscillator/amplifier configurations. Key features of the novel designs are described in the proposal. During Phase I we propose to make detailed model calculations of laser performance, and provide a conceptual design of a demonstrator system. Efficient high power lasers will find uses as transmitters in lidar systems and as freestanding units. Lidar applications (long-range/high altitude wind mapping from the ground, in-situ high-altitude turbulence measurements, flood illumination imaging, etc.) exist for reduced eye hazard, high energy, high efficiency laser sources. The proposed lasers will also be well-suited for medical applications, as well as industrial applications. The laser will also prove useful as a 2 micron pump source for optical parametric oscillators operating in the 2 to 9 micron spectral range for DIAL applications.
title: Power Laser for Eyesafe Coherent Lidar
Autonomous Lidar Wind Field Sensor
On-Line Sensing Of Aircraft Vibration
An Innovative All Solid-State Laser Source for Direct and Coherent Detection LIDAR

abstract: This is a preliminary exploration of design problems and expected performance of compact combined cycle engines for transportation applications consisting of an intercooled gas turbine as topping unit and a Rankine cycle as bottoming unit.  The latter must take all or most of the required vaporizer heat from that rejected by the intercoolers and/or other flowpath coolers.  Water is rejected as the Rankine cycle fluid, and organic heat transfer fluids are the only  alternatives.  The first task is to choose from available fluids one or two having the best combination of properties. Dowtherm J and Fluorinol-85 are strong candidates.  Using one of these, the bottoming cycle combined with a topping unit based on CECs' Regenerative Feedback Turbine Engine (RFTE) is simulated to determine approximate performance and size of vaporizer/cooler, condenser, and turbine expander.  Next make engine performance estimates and preliminary layouts of selected engine configuration. The RFTE based topping unit will result in compact low-emissions combined cycle engines of high efficiency (.46 to .55) and specific power (680-820).  The commercial market for engines of such capabilities is enormous and the  military market is quite significant.  A proposed Optional task to provide preliminary design of the turbine expander is included.
title: Bottoming Cycle for Intercooled gas Turbine Engines: Combined Cycle Based on CEC RFTE Topping Unit with Organic Fluid Bottoming Cycle

abstract: A feasibility analysis of a modified Naval engine with both water extraction and water injection is proposed.  The modifications would implement the Regenerative Feedback Turbine Engine (RFrE), invented by Coleman Engine Corporation as a method of achieving high efficiency over a broad power range while reducing emissions significantly and, very important for a multi-deck ship, reducing the flow of air and exhaust by a factor of three.  In addition, the IR signature would be substantially diminished, and the engine compactness would be similar to a simple-cycle gas turbine. Preliminary calculations show a high potential for producing fresh water directly from the engine.  Trade studies are to be made on the effect on performance and emissions of injecting the self-produced water into the high pressure portion of the engine.  The net effect of this type of modified engine on ship architecture and mission capability will be assessed.
title: Naval Engine Improvement through Water Injection

abstract: Urethral strictures have long been a therapeutic dilemma for urologists.  The natural course of theprogressive scarring and narrowing of the urethral lumen.  Multiple attempts at developing and optimshort of an adequate cure rate.  Often the procedures have resulted in an increased progression of tstricture rather than resolving the disease.  Presently, internal urethrotomy is the primary surgicamost minor and moderate strictures.  It has been demonstrated that this procedure, which relies on hintention, is more a managerial rather than a curative therapy.  The use of an endoscopically placedbioresorbable tubular collagen implant to seal the incised areas and provide an enlarged conduct aftoffers a potential cure for urethral strictures.  The tubular collagen implant functions as a biomecbiological dressing to the wound bed.  The collagen matrix acts as a substrate for the migration ofscaffold for new tissue regeneration.  This tubular collagen implant can also be used as a deliveryand cultured epithelial cells to further enhance healing and prevent scar formation.

title: Resorbable Tubular Collagen Implant--Endoscopic Repair

abstract: Ceramics offer higher temperature capability, lower density, and higher fatigue lifetimes compared to bearing steels.  Low damage tolerance and fracture toughness of ceramics has eliminated their consideration for bearing raceways.  Colorado Engineering Research Laboratory (CERL) is proposing a completely new fabrication technology to make Si*3*N*4* ceramic-matrix composite (CMC) bearing rings with a core-reinforcement of SiC cloth or Nb screen while maintaining an unreinforced Si*3*N*4* surface-case.  The innovation involves centrifugal casting of a ceramic slurry (Si*3*N*4* powder with integral co-precipitated sintering aids) through a porous tube which has woven SiC or Nb architecture on its outside surface.  The very high centrifugal accelerations will induce complete infiltration through the reinforcement interstices, resulting in dense CMC rings after sintering.  CERL will initially perform centrifuge trials to establish the best: (1) Si*3*N*4* powder-to-binder ratio, (2) spinning rate, and (3) reinforcement interstice size, that will result in high density material. Larger-scale CMC rings will be fabricated using the best processing parameters and fracture toughness will be measured from ring specimens.  This technology will enable the fabrication of high-toughness Si*3*N*4* bearing raceways for turbine engine applications, which has not been successfully demonstrated to date.
title: A New Fabrication Technology for High-Toughnexx Ceramic Bearing Races for Advanced Turbine Engines

abstract: A state of the art computational fluid dynamic methodology is proposed for first-principles-based simulation of detonation in FAE clouds.  The approach is based on extensions of well proved and established technology currently in routine use for multiphase, chemically reacting and turbulent solid rocket motor exhaust plume analyses.  Latest advances in the modeling of multiphase phenomena from the field of transient, solid propellant interior ballistics are also brought to bear upon the FAE problem.  Recent developments in large eddy simulation (LES) of turbulence from the field of high speed jets and transient liquid propellant gun interior ballistics provide a physically realistic approach for representing large scale turbulent structures in FAE clouds.  The overall FAE modeling framework is constructed around a well proven, unsteady, three-dimensional, finite-volume, CFD code called CRAFT.  CRAFT utilizes a fully implicit, upwind scheme with higher order spatial and temporal accuracy to provide for robust shock capturing without spurious oscillations and good resolution of other embedded discontinuities (e.g. flame fronts, limiting particle streamlines, etc.). The overall modeling framework provides a unique capability for a variety of transient, particulate-laden, combusting flowfields.
firm: COMBUSTION RESEARCH AND FLOW TECHNOLOGY INC
title: Modeling Characteristics for Volumetric Explosives

abstract: Existing technology for the 3D CFD analysis of rocket plume/aerodynamic interactions will be specialized to the ejection seat problem.  Present technology includes a 3D Navier-Stokes code, CRAFT, with detailed plume thermochemistry and multiphase flow and with turbulence models specialized to the complex plume environment.  A struc- tured version with advanced Roe/TVD finite-volume numerics is operational at sev- eral government facilities (MICOM, NSWC, ARL) in support of plume/aerodynamic in- teractive problems.  New unstructured and hybrid versions for complex multi-body problems (stage separation, launcher interactions, etc.) are operational with further development underway.  Task 1 will demonstrate the applicability of pres- ent technology to rocket plume/ejection seat aerodynamics, including the performance of "scope-out" computational studies focussing on areas of most uncertainty (e.g. transient turbulence modeling/vortex shedding).
firm: COMBUSTION RESEARCH AND FLOW TECHNOLOGY INC
title: CFD Analysis of Rocket Plume Effects on Ejection Seat Aerodynamics
A Novel Approach to OCR Handwriting Recognition with Application to Man-machine Interaction

abstract: Commercial tools have been developed that support the graphical construction of behavioral models of reactive systems and implement various forms of analysis of such user-developed models.  These methods rely primarily on simulation, that is, the execution of a model on sample data.  We propose to take advantage of the extensive effort that has gone into making the graphical user interfaces of these commerical systems appealing to software engineers.  We will use formal reasoning techniques to augment simulation in the analysis of system models obtained via these interfaces. Formal reasoning can be used to answer questions that are difficult or impossible to answer via simulation.  Some of these questions can be formulated so that they can be answered with a minimum of user involvement, e.g. using ordered binary decision diagrams (BDDs) and derivative techniques, notably model checking.  More general theorem proving techniques can prove properties that cannot be proved using BDDs and, in addition, support the evolution of a series of increasingly advanced tools.
title: Using Formal Reasoning to Augment Commercial Reactive System Design Tools
Hp-Meshless Cloud Method for Dynamic Fracture in Fluid Structure Interaction

abstract: Two design approaches have been taken in the design of a compact infrared zoom lens to operate in the 3 to 5 micron spectral band, with an aperture of f/4.5: an overall length of less than 150 mm, and a diameter of 75 mm.  The zoom range is to be 4X, with focal lengths from 50 to 200 mm and angular field coverages from 5 to 20 degrees.  The first approach is the design of an advanced Mechanically Compensated IR Zoom Lens.  This design based on  prior COI 4X zoom lenses offers the most direct engineering design solution.  The second approach is the development of an Optically Compensated IR Zoom Lens.  This design concept has the potential of many advantages since it has only one moving part, and offers a simpler and lighter lens construction with greater reliability.  A detailed optical tolerance analysis will be carried out for both types, including the effects of all element thicknesses and separations; as well as thermal effects and manufacturability.
title: Design of Mechanically and Optically Compensated Compact Infrared Zoom Munitions Lenses

abstract: A key requirement of any future head support device is to develop concepts as integrated system. Such programs must consider not only safety, but also helmet-mounted sights/displays and other systems for mission enhancement. The design process must also be developed in concurrence with aviators' needs, desires, and requirements. This program employs a system approach to define and design a preliminary head/ neck support system. This includes an advanced helmet shell design coupled to an integral mandibular face shield with an integrated oxygen mask, and an inflatable head/neck support device. Phase 1 objectives include development of design concepts, modeling performance, and fabrication of a non-functional prototype helmet with integral head and neck support. The mandibular support system, oxygen mask, disconnects, helmet balance and stability, comfort, and vision will be evaluated by the flying population and documented. Considerations for windblast and high-G maneuvering will be analytically developed and documented for incorporation into the optimum helmet design concept.
title: Aircrew Head Support

abstract: The cost and limited lifespan of strain gages for stress and vibration surveys has driven researchers to find alternate means of investigating airfoil stress and vibration.  Systems based on optical sensors have been reported in the literature since the mid 1960's.  These systems have been limited to test cell use and relatively complex, thus preventing their widespread application. One recently developed system has been successfully used in LV100 testing.  Developed by the Principal Investigator while still at Textron Lycoming, this system produced stress and vibration data in good agreement with strain gage results.  Further work by the PI, since joining Concept ETI, included the programming of advanced data reduction algorithms, a graphical user interface, and the application of recently developed electronics for dramatic improvements in speed, accuracy, usability and cost.  The proposer will thoroughly research the diagnostic and prognostic needs of the sponsoring agency and the gas turbine community.  Recent advanced in optics and electronics will be investigated.  A software simulation of blade dynamics, optic probe response, electronic resolution, and data reduction algorithms will be created and implemented.  By combining the components of the system into a single simulator, the most capable and cost effective measurement system will be designed.
title: Research, Design, and Development of Cost Effective Optical Vibration Monitoring System
Improved Throttleability For High-Head Pumps

abstract: The auditory brainstem response (ABR) is one of several auditory evoked responses which have a variety of military and clinical applications (2,6).  Currently the ABR is analyzed using frequency-dependent filtering techniques over very long windows (up to several hundred seconds).  CMI proposes to use modern nonlinear signal processing techniques )order statistic filters, neural networks, fuzzy logic, etc) to improve the accuracy of the ABR analysis while reducing the analysis time.  One of the applications of ABR analysis currently in use at AL is the neurodiagnosis of auditory brainstem dysfunction in pilots for classification and retention.  Supporting goals for AL include; neurological assessment, threshold assessment, and the determination of a method to identify and standardize salient features of the ABR.  In the commercial sector there are obvious uses such as; newborn infant auditory screening, estimation of auditory sensitivity in very young children, intraoperative monitoring of the eight nerve and auditory brainstem status during posterior cranial surgery.
title: The Auditory Brainstem Response: Enhancement and Interpretation
Improved Hearing Assessment via Otoacoustic Emission Measurement Based on Advanced Fuzzy Logic Filtering Techniques

abstract: The overall objective of the Phase I program is to accomplish the preliminary design of a head-helmet support device which will significantly reduce the magnitude of maneuvering and ejection loads imposed on the aircrews cervical column. Other objectives to be met by the device include proper positioning and alignment of the head during ejection and high G maneuvering, while allowing unimpeded head and torso movement required during combat and routine operations. The program will identify and quantify functional requirements and parametric ranges of the support system. Through a structured scheme of alternative load paths, various candidate concepts will be synthesized for evaluation in a trade study. Optimality will be established on the basis of functional adequacy, manufacturing and operating costs, durability, environmental effects on aging, etc. Completion of the Phase I effort will accomplish the preliminary design of a helmet- head support system for reducing neck injuries sustained during maneuvering and ejection.
title: "Aircrew Head Support"
Manikin Test and Calibration System
Self-Monitoring Surveillance System for Prestressing Tendons

abstract: A novel and sensitive infrared detector based on micromechanical cantilevers that needs no cooling is proposed. A two dimensional array of these cantilevers with a scanning mechanism can be used as an image forming device. Micromechanical cantilevers coated with materials of different thermal expansion coefficients undergo bending due to the "bimetallic" effect. The bending of a cantilever can be detected with sub-nanometer sensitivity using the tunneling current detection technique. Calculations based on geometrical and material properties show that a temperature difference of 10-6 K can be easily measured using such microcantilevers. These detectors can be made sensitive to specific IR spectral bands by coating the cantilevers with selective IR absorbing materials. The objective of this proposal is to demonstrate feasibility of the micromechanical IR detector, leading to development of a two dimensional, image-forming micromechanical IR detector array.
title: Two Dimensional Micromechanical Infrared Detector Array

abstract: Effective modelling of transonic flow, viscous effects and the prediction of noise remain serious challenges for existing computational rotorcraft analyses.  The goal of this project is to couple new and innovative computational techniques into Continuum Dynamics, Inc.'s RotorCRAFT/AA analysis to address these issues while also allowing the user to easily adjust the physical fidelity of the computational methods to be employed for maximum efficiency.  In Phase I, two novel computational methods will be employed for maximum efficiency.  In Phase I, two novel computational methods will be incorporated into the present model. The first is a recently developed compressible panel treatment of the lifting surface that will improve the resolution of unsteady subsonic flow configurations.  The second, and more ambitious innovation, is a recently developed higher-order compact Euler CFD technique suitable for capturing concentrated vorticity as well as modelling detailed transonic flow phenomena.  Once incorporated, this Euler technique will form the basis for a full Navier-Stokes analysis of the flow over the blade.  The final product will be a fast, reliable and efficient software package suited for rotor design and analysis that is capable of simulating rotor/wake systems over the full range of relevant airspeeds and flight conditions as user-selected levels of sophistication and calculation speed.
title: General Rotor Aerodynamic/Aeroelastic Design Analysis
Fast Modeling Technology For General Rotor/Surface Interaction

abstract: The U.S. EPA and the California Air Resource Board are imposing regulations for the control of smoke opacity and particulates from diesel engines in mobile application, and the majority of AF trucks are not in compliance.  Additionally, the AF is pursuing NOx reduction credits wherever it is feasible.  To achieve both of these goals, CTI is proposing to develop a particulate converter/exhaust gas recirculation (EGR) system for emission reduction.  The particulate converter system is an innovative passive exhaust after treatment device for the separation and incineration of diesel particulate employing and advanced method for incinerating particulates.  The EGR hardware is designed to achieve highest NOx reduction, taking advantage of the converter to reduce the additional particulate emissions.  Phase I calls for the development and construction of a particulate converter/EGR prototype for a heavy-duty truck for the AF.  The prototype will be first tested for emission and operability at CTI's facility.  Then it will be tested at an independent emission test facility.  CTI is targeting 90% reduction in particulates/smoke, 30% reduction in NOx, 70% reduction in HC, and 80% reduction in CO.  Higher emission reductions are targeted for Phase II.
title: Converter/EGR System for Particulate & NOx Reduction from Heavy-Duty Diesel Trucks

abstract: The problem addressed here is how to structure a computer program (MOPIT) which can choose from a library of computer modules to solve a new problem defined by the user.  The modules must have common naming conventions, appropriate linking and have suitable input-output provisions.  A preprocessor will also be supplied as part of the proposed research.  The preprocessor using information supplied by the user will accept existing computer code modules and suitably modify them to be included in the library.  Using the concept of neural nets MOPIT will have internal checking features to determine if the proposed new code contains all the necessary modules for successful execution.  Thus computer program modules can be extracted from a variety of existing codes and reassembled for an entirely different purpose.  MOPIT will be a self learning program which will be capable of self modification for particular environments.  The program will be user friendly so that using only the modules supplied in the library a non specialist can use the program.
title: Modular Omnibus Program with Internal Checking (MOPIT)

title: Electro-Optically Tunable Integrated Diode Laser

abstract: CoreTek Inc proposes a rewritable ferroelectric thin film disk drive (Ferro-Disk), which is addressed optically and read out electronically. The Ferro-Disk stores data in the form of electric remnant polarization in a ferroelectric film. Because ferroelectric materials are radiation hardened, the Ferro-Disk is specially suitable for reliable data storage during space missions. The architecture a Ferro-Disk data storage system makes innovative use of ferroelectric thin film technology and optical data storage technology. The data storage density of a single layer Ferro-Disk is compatible or higher than that of a magneto-optical drive, limited only by the spot size of the writing laser beam. Because of the thin film nature of the ferroelectric recording media, multilayer data storage can easily be realized to further increase the data storage density. CoreTek's design of electric readout leads to a robust drive with much simpler optical configuration than a conventional optical drive. The simplicity of system design ensures the Ferro Drive to be reliable and compact with very low power consumption. Phase I will fabricate the proposed Ferro-Disk by using sputtering thin film deposition technique. We will evaluate the data storage characteristics of the Ferro-Disk by examine reading and writing process. Phase II will optimize the device performance to achieve specifications better than the present day disk-drives. Compared with conventional data storage systems (tape system, magnetic hard disk, optical disk), the Ferro-Disk has the following advantages: high read/write speed, high data storage density, simple and compact system design, low power consumption, resistant to radiation damage, and extremely robust. This new and revolutionary data instrumentation scheme will be of considerable importance for military as well as commercial applications.
title: Ferroelectric Data Storage Disk

abstract: The rapid development of the technology for producing high quality single crystal SiC wafers and thin films presents the opportunity to fabricate solid-state devices with power-temperature capability far greater than devices currently available. While conventional silicon power devices are already being used near their limits of operating temperature and power, the potential of SiC is just beginning to be demonstrated. Vertical power MOSFET structures fabricated in 4H-SiC with 150 V capability have already shown current densities of 100 A/cm2 with a voltage drop of 3.3 V (specific on-resistance of 33 m -cm2. These devices showed good characteristics at temperatures up to 300 C. 4H-SiC  thyristors have been demonstrated up to 500 C that block 200 V and have current densities of 500 A/cm2 at 3.8 V. While these are promising results, these devices have been far from reaching their theoretical voltages based on the doping levels used. One of the reasons for the relatively low voltages is the lack of good junction termination techniques for SiC. Therefore it is proposed that different junction termination designs and processes be explored and evaluated. The Phase I effort will focus on the application of these terminations to relative simple pn junction rectifiers. The methods to be evaluated will be improved passivation of mesa sidewalls and the use of non-mesa terminations such as floating field rings or field plates. A batch of identical pn junction structures will be grown on which these different methods will be used so that they can be systematically compared. The surface breakdown of SiC will also be characterized because of its importance in achieving higher power Sic microwave MESFETs, which are becoming vital for next generation phased array radar systems. The termination techniques for the rectifiers and the surface breakdown information can then be applied to more complex SiC devices currently being developed such as power MOSFETs, thyristors, and microwave MESFETS. High power silicon carbide devices which operate at high temperatures are required for a variety of power conditioning applications on radar systems, all-electric airplanes, turbine engine actuators, and space-based power systems. T
title: High Voltage 4H-SiC Power Devices

abstract: Gallium Nitride has been known for many years to have excellent physical and electronic properties which are well suited to the production of electronic devices that can emit radiation in the blue-to-green region of the spectrum, detect UV radiation, and operate at significantly higher temperatures than devices produced from GaAs or Si.  The larger bandgap of GaN offers several performance advantages in the realization of UV detectors.  Devices can operate at high temperature, dark currents are many orders of magnitude smaller, and response can be solar-blind.  UV detectors have already been fabricated at Cree research in the 6H polytype of SiC for the USAF.  These devices exhibit a 96% quantum efficiency with a peak responsivity at 270 nm.  The pn junction leakage currents were found to be 10(super4) - 10(super5) times smaller, with sensitivities up to 10(super4) times greater than for common Si based UV photodetectors.  However, these devices required the use of an external filter for solar blind operation.  We propose expanding on this work by fabricating UV photodetectors in GaN and AlGaN alloys.  The wider bandgap energies available with these materials will move the detector response to shorter wavelengths, permitting solar blind operation without the use of external filters.  In Phase I , the use of existing GaN and AlGaN epitaxial growth, fabrication and testing technology available at Cree, will permit rapid fabrication and evaluation of the performance advantages offered by these materials.
title: Totally Solar-Blind UV Detectors from GaN and A1N Alloys
Development of a High Temperature Silicon Carbide CMOS Technology

abstract: The use of ZnGeP2 in nonlinear optical applications has been limited in the past due to an extrinsic absorption in the near infrared.  Defect studies of ZnGeP2 indicate that the extrinsic absorption is due to nonstoichiometry (as a result of high volatility of some components at the temperatures required for melt growth) and/or order-disorder (resulting from growing crystals in the high temperature phase and cooling to the room temperature phase).  It may be possible to reduce both of these problems by growing crystals at lower temperatures (below the phase transition temperature).  As such, it is the objective of this proposed effort to demonstrate the feasibility of crystal growth of ZnGeP2 using the high-temperature solution (HTS) technique.
title: The use of ZnGeP2 in nonlinear optical applications

abstract: There is a need for optical materials with large nonlinear coefficients and high laser damage thresholds for tunable laser operation in the 2-5um region. This proposal describes a new member of the KTP family CsZrOAsO4 (CZA), which is expected to have superior properties in comparison to KTP. An empirical relationship between nonlinear properties and dielectric molecular polarizability indicates that CZA should meet these requirements. The synthesis, crystal growth and characterization of this new material is outlined and will utilize essential processes previously developed for KTP, KTA and CTA. The benefits of this program will be the preparation of a new material with very large nonlinear optical properties. Efforts can then be concentrated on growth of commercial size crystals and refinement of optical quality. This will result in a domestic source of large, inexpensive nonlinear crystals for device applications in both military and commercial laser systems.
title: CsZrOAsO4: New Nonlinear Material for Laser Applications

abstract: The proposed research will investigate the optimal placement of sensors and actuators for active control of sound.  The technique will be based on a tested approach for the robust placement of active and passive dampers in lightly-damped, complex structures.  Innovative performance metrics will be developed that are specifically tailored to the control of structure-borne sound.  These include exploiting simultaneous sensing and actuation for collocated control and the use of shaped sensors for the remote measurement of volume velocity.  Efficient algorithms will be developed for the optimal placement of multiple sensors and actuators.  Efficiency is the key issue due to the expansive search space that exists in a multiparameter optimization for reducing sound radiation from structures. The Phase I work plan consists of determining placement algorithms and metrics for broadband acoustic and vibration control, deciding on the level of spatial filtering needed for effective sound attenuation, and selecting a control approach which is computationally efficient robust to model errors.  A hardware demonstration will be performed in the Phase I option to evaluate the techniques.  The final product of the Phase I effort will be an experimentally validated placement algorithm for the active control of sound.
title: Technique for Placement of Structural Actuators/Sensors for Active Control of Sound
Passive Deployment Dampers

abstract: An evaporative spray cooled Switched Reluctance Motor with integral drive electronics is proposed.  The motivation is to increase power density, efficiency and reliability through improved thermal management.  A concept is presented in which all components are contained within a machine frame.  The gravity independence and heat transfer efficiency of spray cooling permits the elimination of large heat sinks attached to the power electronics.  The resultant volume reduction of the electronics assembly allows it to be easily located within the motor frame; a very thin spray assembly and integral liquid pump are also contained therein.  The machine frame serves as a condenser, rejecting heat to the ambient environment.  The primary focus of the Phase I program will be an experimental investigation into the key feasibility issue of rotor drag, particularly in the compressible flow regime that would be encountered in very high speed machines.  Spray cooling heat transfer efficiency in this environment will also be researched. Alternative Stator configurations to maximize performance will be examined both analytically and experimentally.
title: Integrated Motor

abstract: The miniaturization of the laser diode, power switches (MCT, IGBT, etc.), the drastic increase in the number density of transistors on a monolithic chip and the capability to drive these chips at very high power ratings and clock speeds has increased the demand for the devices.  However, such high performance can be extracted only over short time pulses because the devices produce a moderate amount of heat at extremely high heat fluxes.  The bottleneck towards running steadily at peak conditions is that the heat generation is too high to be dissipated by currently used heat sinks (conduction heat sinks with or without fans).  Hence, there is a need to develop a compact high heat flux cooler.  A key problem is that this cooler must be very compact so that it does not impact the over all size of the solid-state system.  Cudo proposes a highly innovative integral pump/motor/heat exchanger that elegantly solves this problem.  This revolutionary design has resulted in the submission of two patents.  Never before has a pump, motor and heat exchanger been integrated into a single stand-alone unit.  This pump-motor-heat exchanger integration will reduce the size of the cooler by more than 6 times, thus, reducing costs and increasing portability and marketability significantly.  The objective of this study is to design, fabricate, test and deliver a market-ready prototype of the high heat-flux cooler which integrates the functions of motor, pump, cooler and heat exchanger info a miniature, compact stand-alone package.
title: Compact High Heat-Flux Cannister Cooler

abstract:
This SBIR Phase I project will investigate an integration framework to enable the virtual prototyping of mechanical components, specifically for application to ISR's advanced spray cooling technology.  The framework will accommodate an Automated Design, Analysis, and Manufacturing system currently under development at ISR by allowing the integration of advanced parametric CAD utilities, a suite of analysis applications, CAM software, Virtual Prototyping, Assembly, and Manufacturing Systems.  The framework will be designed using object-oriented programming techniques, and will be open-architecture and expandable.

The Phase I program will provide an object oriented analysis to decompose the problem domain into object types that represent the real world problem.  Various applicable software standards will be evaluated for incorporation.  The object-oriented framework will be implemented using the current software utilities in use at ISR.  A demonstration will be conducted for a specific spray cooling system mechanical component.  Phase II will expand the effort to incorporate all other spray cooling system components so that the complete system design, and the creation of virtual and mechanical prototypes becomes automatic from customer specific input and requirements.  Phase III will see the implementation of the framework in the commercialization of spray cooling, and in the establishment of a service bureau to transfer turn-key systems utilizing the technology.
title: Integration Framework for Virtual Prototyping Software Tools
