abstract: Our proposed research for Phase I is in response to US Army solicitation for developing novel tungsten-based composites which offer the best properties for munition applications, particularly as kinetic energy penetrators.  To meet this goal, we propose to produce, high purity, unagglomerated, engineered, nanocrystalline tungsten and titanium particlates in situ in the ration of around 10:1 as a model material, by incorporating a low-cost method called Gas Phase Combustion Synthesis (GCS) and consolidate the fine particulates to full density by Hot Pressing to replace the environmentally sensitive Depleted Uranium.  Our W/Ti synthesis route involves a sodium-flame process together with a NaCl coating technique that prevents agglomeration.  The byproduct-coating of individual tungsten grains and reduce tungsten to tungsten contiguity.  Hot Pressing of the W/Ti particles will be conducted at lower temperatures and higher pressures to curtail the growth of tungsten grains.  The resulting material via nanoscale technology, will have a microstructure containing nanocrystalline tungsten grains uniformly dispersed in titanium matrix (binder phase).  The resulting microstructure will be unique and is expected to provide increased strength and fracture toughness and therefore, shear localization at reduced strain levels.  The GCS process is equally applicable for synthesis of a variety of  metals and composites. The process is attractive because scale-up is straightforward.  In addition to synthesis and consolidation of 90W-10Ti, we propose to demonstrate the occurrence of shear localization in nanocrystalline 90%W-10%Ti by compression testing at strain-rate ~5000 s(-1) in order to simulate ballistic test conditions and enhance the usefulness of this material in defense and commercial sectors.
title: High Performance and High Density Tungsten Based Composite Incorporating Nanocrystalline Tungsten within Titanium Matrix formed Insitu for DoD Munit

abstract: Our proposed research for Phase I is in response to US Navy solicitation for low-cost synthesis methods for producing nanocrystalline ceramics to offer the best properties for modem technological applications. We propose to process high purity unagglomerated and engineered nanocrystalline AIN as a model material, by a low-cost method called Gas Phase Combustion Synthesis (GCS) to combat two key issues obstructing full-scale AIN commercialization: i) the cost and, (ii) purity. Our AIN synthesis route involves a sodium-flame process together with a NaCl coating technique that prevents agglomeration. The byproduct-coating approach for controlling the particle size, agglomeration and oxidation, is novel and holds great promise for commercialization. The process is equally applicable for synthesis of a variety of ceramics, metals and composites and is attractive because scale-up is straightforward. Although, synthesis of AIN is the major thrust of this proposal, we plan to demonstrate the occurrence of superplasticity in nanocrystalline AIN by non-traditional elevated temperature compression testing to corroborate the general notion that superplasticity, although not exhibited by ultrafine AIN (-O. I ym) can indeed be possible in fully consolidated nanocrystalline AIN.
title: High Performance and High Purity Nanocrystalline Aluminum Nitride for Modern Technological Applications

abstract: In today's congested electromagnetic environment, broadband receivers for electronic support measures (ESM) are susceptible to interference by both friendly and hostile emitters. To avoid receiver performance degradation due to interference, narrow-band notch filters are often used to suppress interfering signals. Conventional notch filters that rely on the magnetic tuning (i.e. ferrite and YIG devices) are bulky, which makes them unsuitable for use in limited space, such as in periscope-mounted ESM receivers. Hittite Microwave Corporation has developed novel filtering techniques using active devices built in microwave monolithic integrated circuits (MMIC). Hittite has demonstrated tunable notch filters operating in X-band frequencies, built in a gallium-arsenide (GaAs) chip of 1.5 mm x 3 mm dimensions. Hittite's MMIC filters operate with a companion MMIC chip designed to control filter characteristics, and maintain optimum filter performance. This combination of two chips may be used for active and adaptive suppression of interfering signals. In addition, Hittite demonstrated MMIC chips for sampled-data filtering at VHF/UHF frequencies based on the switched-capacitance technique. The GaAs technology also allows extension of low-frequency interference suppression techniques to microwave frequencies. This proposal describes Hittite's approach to suppress interference and provide CW immunity to broadband ESM receivers by using MMIC filtering techniques. The MMIC filter chips can be accommodated in the limited space available in the front-end of submarine ESM receivers. The proposed program will lead to definition of optimum combination of filter techniques for seamless coverage of the receiver band and preliminary design and analyses of filter performance, in preparation for hardware implementation and demonstration in Phase 2.
title: Development of Adaptive Filtering System to Eliminate CW Interference in Submarine IFM-Based Electronic Support Measure (ESM) Systems

abstract: Microwave Monolithic Integrated Circuits (MMIC) provide means of integrating a large number of microwave circuits on a chip, and reducing the size of microwave front-end for broad-band EMS receivers.  For submarine ESM systems, MMIC techniques may be applied to integrate critical front-end functions with the antenna assembly to be accommodated within the limited space available on the periscope.  To take advantage of the full potential of size reduction offered by MMIC, it is imperative to develop MMIC techniques for high-scale integration.  To that end, Hittite Microwave Corporation has developed novel MMIC for filters, mixers, phase-locked oscillators, etc.  This proposal describes Hittite's approach to miniaturize ESM receivers using highly integrated MMIC chips.  Advanced MMIC techniques and high-scale integration experience, unique to Hittite, are presented as bases for the next level of integration of ESM receivers.  As an example, a design approach for a miniaturized scanning superheterodyne receiver is presented.  In Phase I of the proposed program, a specific receiver configuration will be selected for miniatruization, and MMIC requirements for such receiver design will be defined.  The program plan also includes; preliminary design of critical parts, package design, analysis of cost impact, and a plan for implementation of the concept in Phase 2.
title: Integrated Digital Electronic Warfare (ESM)- Communications Receiver Technology

abstract:
This Phase I SBIR project will investigate fundamental economic issues associated with sheep dairying.  The proposed feasibility study contemplates three areas of research:  (a) market research to determine consumer attitudes toward sheep's milk products and the prices thereof; (b) economic research to evaluate the derivative price justifiable for raw sheep's milk in a competitive marketplace; and (c) social research to test two hypotheses; one, that milk producer groups can be structured to functionally benefit both sellers and buyers; and two, that product-specific micro-creameries are conceptually the most valid format for incubating sheep's milk manufacturing businesses in the commerical sector.

Results will provide:  (1) an understanding of consumer preferences, buying patterns and price elasticity for sheep's milk products; (2) an economic model for pricing fluid sheep's milk; (3) a hypothetical format for a milk producer's group; and (4) data sufficient to evaluate, in Phase II, the hypothetical throughput and hence the revenues of micro-creameries, given research-supported price assumptions for raw milk, finished product, and anticipated consumer buying patterns.
title: Sheep Dairying: Commercialization Opportunity for Rural Regeneration

abstract: Current technologies for eye protection address fixed wavelength threats as well as agile laser threats.  Fixed wavelength solutions have advanced to the point where military eyewear with multiple protection (seven wavelength protection) is being implemented. Agile solutions are less developed, a major obstacle being the difficulty in obtaining the concurrent characteristics of safety blockage (required filter performance), very fast response times (less than nanoseconds) and implementability on current military eyewear.  A novel approach is proposed in which a hybrid technology capitalizes on the advances already achieved with fixed wavelength filters and the fast response of optical switching.  A fixed wavelength holographic filter is made tunable by doping it with materials which can vary the volumetric and/or index of refraction characteristics of the material.  A composite holographic filter reduces the material variation requirements to less than 1%, thus facilitating optical switching.  The result will be a tunable filter with a filter performance meeting military specifications and the fast response time required of an agile filter. Additionally, the filter architecture will be compatible with military eyewear.
title: Wavelength Independent Human Eye Laser Protection
Multiple Wavelength Large Holographic Mirror

abstract:
The huckleberry, a major religious, traditional, and cultural native food, is highly significant to the people of the Confederated Tribes of the Warm Springs Reservation of Oregon.  Those cultural, traditional and religious values are being threatened; as huckleberry plants are eliminated from their natural environment through loss of space, water, nutrients, and sunlight, part of the culture and traditions of the tribal community will die with it.

For many Oregonians and tribal people, this is also a family loss as an economic resource and for recreational family activities.  Governmental forest management eliminated the traditional burning methods of huckleberry  management and promoted commercial timber at the expense of native food resources.  This project will develop an opportunity for tribal people to be a part of the traditional ways within today's technology; and to regain community pride and employment through co-management for multiple-use of the forested areas.  The objectives are (1) to reduce competitive vegetation thereby increasing availability of sunlight, soil moisture and nutrients to the huckleberry plants while providing ground cover to protect the soil; (2) to restock plants, as needed; (3) to develop employment and training programs to form a pool of skilled workers or contractors.
title: Production Enhancement of Native Indian Food and Medicine Resources

abstract:
A combustion environment can be described by a characteristic fuel-to-air ratio normalized by the stoichiometric fuel-to-air ratio, otherwise defined as an equivalence ratio, _.  The equivalence ratio is used extensively in a wide range of combustion fields from fundamental flame studies, to full-scale fire testing, to power plant operations.  There have been basically two methods for calculating the equivalence ratio, each of which has significant disadvantages in practice.  Due to these disadvantages, there is no single instrument that allows direct measurement of _.  Recently, a technique has been developed in which the equivalence ratio of a gas sample can be determined via oxygen consumption.

The Phase I objective is to develop a practical, robust equivalence ratio meter which can be used for a wide range of applications.  This design effort will consist of material and hardware selection as well as component optimization testing.  Completion of this objective will result in detailed plans for an equivalence ratio meter that can be prototyped and tested in Phase II.
title: Development of a Commercially Viable Equivalence Ratio Meter

abstract: HYPRES, in collaboration with DuPont, proposes to develop A High TcSNS Josephson junction process for the fabrication of large scale superconducting circuits.  These devices are in demand for high speed signal processing electronics (such as A/D converters), improved IR sensors, and SQUID magnetometers.  The development of a high Tc superconducting circuit process will make the practical application of these superconducting electronic components possible, since liquid He cryogen can be replaced by an inexpensive, low power cryocooler.  We propose to use Silicon on Sapphire substrates to produce YBCO SNS Josephson junctions.  The use of SOS allows direct integration of the high Tc circuits with Si electronics.

abstract: The current distribution in plasma radiation sources is both a yardstick for measuring the coupling efficiency of the generator, and a means of studying the implosion dynamics of the load.  Since the current distribution cannot be directly measured, it must be deduced from the magnetic field profile.  Magnetic field distributions, based on the Faraday rotation of polarized laser light, are typically determined from intensity measurements of two polarization components.  They are therefore susceptible to background emission problems.  A differential interferometric technique is proposed to infer the magnetic field form the phase difference between the right and left circularly polarized components of a laser beam traversing a plasma.  The phase of the two circular polarizations will be simultaneously recorded using a two reference beam hologram.  The two reference beam holographic recording allows heterodyne techniques to be used during reconstruction for enhanced sensitivity.  This is two to three orders of magnitude more sensitive than a typical Faraday rotation measurement.  A third reference beam will be used to record a no plasma hologram needed to measure the electron density distribution.  This technique allows the magnetic field profile to be measured with better sensitivity and less susceptibility to background emission than Faraday rotation techniques.  A successful program will provide the PRS community with the first measurement of a magnetic field distribution In a PRS load.  This is critical to the design of such devices and the comparison with theory.
title: Development of a Differential Interferometric Technique for Measuring Magnetic Field Profiles in a Plasma Radiation Source

abstract: The accurate measurement of fluid densities flowing in pipes is important for custodial monitoring of valuable and/or controlled substances.  Most on-line fluid flow meters require independent determination of the fluid density while Coriolis type meters, which directly measure the fluid mass, are off-lie devices.  HY-Tech is proposing to develop a laser based diagnostic techique for measuring the fluid density on-line with an accuracy approaching 10 ppm.  The technique is applicable to measuring the absolute density of single component gases independent of pressure or temperature and the concentration of liquid solutions.  The technique will find widespread application in manufacturing processes where the monitor and control of fluid mixture concentrations is critical.
title: Development of an On-Line Density Measurement Technique for Fluid Flow with a 0.001% Accuracy

abstract: Although many fluorophores exist which are suitable for labeling biomolecules, most of them have absorbance and fluorescence wavelenghts which overlap with naturally occurring biological fluorescence.  This complicates their use with optical bio- sensors.  A very limited number of commercially available near-IR fluorophores exist (e.g., Cy-5, Cy-5.5, Cy-7) which contain suitable reactive groups for coupling.  How- ever, these fluorophores have relatively small Stokes' shifts and less than optimal photostability.  Innovation Associates proposes to develop a new class of near-IR fluorophores which utilize aromatic molecules absorbing in the near-IR to chelate metals in a manner which permits charge transfers from the ligand to the metal.  This will give rise to a series of fluorophores which are all excited at the same wavelength but which exhibit fluorescence at various near-IR wavelengths, depending upon the metal.  Because ligand-metal charge transfer chelates generally display larger Stokes' shifts and sharper fluorescence bands than purely organic fluorophores, discrimination of a fluorophore's emission from other fluorophore emissions and from the stimulating laser diode will be simplified.  Such a series will be ideal for simultaneous meas- urement of several analytes in, biological fluids by means of fluorescence measure- ments at several wavelengths. A family of near-
title: Near Infrared Fluorophores for Optical Biosensors

abstract: A power controller is described which has increased power capability (50-100 Hp range), improved efficiency, reduced cost, and increased control capability for control of onboard auxillary power sources. A full four-quadrant control inverter uses a variable frequency, quasi-resonant four-quadrant H-bridge configuration and a phase shifted PWM controller for control of a three phase AC induction motor. Use of second generation P-MCT's improves inverter efficiency.  Phase controlling the motor as a two-speed transmission. A custom hybrid microprocessor based system controller gives the desired control capability in a small, low cost, low weight, package suitable for volume production. ANTICIPATED BENEFITS: The single stage inverter concept offers a performance advantage (low loss, reduced parts count) and has wide application in motor control for electric vehicles, tanks, all electric aircraft and multifunctional switching in Navy and Marine power systems.

abstract: With power consumpition becoming prohibitive, SOI has become a key technological approach for production of integrated circutis with markedly reduced power requirments. SOI provides improvement (maintenance) of circuit performance and reduction of power consumption, largely independent of circuit architecture. Improved modelilng is a way of reducing the escalating cost impact of technology and product developments. Various parallel (some redundant) projects are focused on model development for particular types of SOI devices, but no comprehensive SOI circuit design models are readily available commercially. It is the purpose of this project to compare the modeling approaches for SOI devices, determine suitability for circuit level modeling which provides power estimation and parametric analysis for [low] power optimization, examine tradeoffs in efficiency and [power consumption predictive] accuracy, develop or modify models as required, and apply the model to test circuits to estimate power reduction. One or more commercial vendors will be involved for transfer of results to commercially available circuit design software. Key aspects of the desired modeling approach will be: comprehensiveness of device modes and types, applicability to perform parameter optimization, and inclusiveness of key SOI parameters for low power level estimation. Device data will be used for model verification. ANTICIPATED BENEFITS: The project will provide a needed design tool for SOI circuits, which can be expected to promote SOI technology use.  Sensitivity to technology parameters will be identified to optimize power reduction, analyze cost tradeoffs, and design Phase II experiments. The ultimate goal of the project is installation of useful SOI CMOS LPE design. Ibis's involvement in this effort will enhance technolgoy transfer.
title: Advanced Modeling of Silicon-on-Insulator Devices for Low Power Electronics
Investigation of Internal Thermal Oxidation (ITOX) in SIMOX

abstract: In spite of the rapid advances in the speed and density of electronic components, a compact hardware package  providing a complete real-time solution to vision problems remains beyond the capabilities of currently available technology.  This project proposes to develop a smart CCD camera using a temporal cellular neural network architecture that can perform a variety of iconic operations in real-time.  The programmable features combined with the planned execution of post processing algorithms on a conventional microprocessor will enable this smart camera module to be used as a general-purpose image processing engine capable of edge finding, motion and dept computations.  As a result, the proposed system will be practical in a wide array of settings, such as advanced manufacturing, hazardous material handing, and navigation, as well in a variety of commercial, and eventually, consumer video systems.  The Phase I effort will be directed towards proof of concept through system simulation of the smart camera.  In addition, the architectural issues involved in interfacing with a conventional microprocessor will be investigated.
title: Smart CCD Camera for Real-time Programmable Image Processing using cellular Neural Networks

abstract: This proposed project combines ideas from neuro-biological modeling of the cochlea, engineering designs of optimal filters, the theoretical formulation using the calculus of variations, and optimal filtering and control. Several competing formulations will be developed. A potential breakthrough entails a formulation that develops (i) a neural module that separates mixed signals or signal and noise from measurements in dynamic and cluttered environments, with very minimum assumptions, (ii) subsequent modules that initially preprocess the signals via a bank of filters in line with the cochlea's models, followed by an identification stage of the static "features." For part (ii), an alternative approach will pursue a direct formulation based on optimal filtering and control to develop identification networks for temporal signals. The Phase I effort will validate and evaluate the proposed explicit algorithms within a simulated mixing environment containing a combination of dynamically changing signals at varying levels of interference. The developed algorithms will be coded in a tailored C/C++ development code with graphics capabilities for demonstration. A real-time computing environment for separating mixed signals/signals and noise is expected. This algorithm is novel and departs from known methods in industry. The benefits include the ability to eliminate noise from speech signals or sounds of different vehicles/aircraft/missiles.
title: Real-Time Temporal Signals Separation and Identification in Noisy Environments

abstract: Superconducting Magnetic Energy Storage (SMES) offers many advantages for utility applications.  The only commercially available SMES products are for less than 3 MJ applications.  In the future, larger SMES products will be used to service many applications, such as a large industrial park or a utility substation.  The step in magnet technology from a few MJ coil to a 10 MJ coil is not a large one.  More important is the ability to continue to make steps to higher energies and delivered power as required.  In this SBIR program we propose to analyze, develop, and demonstrate the advantage of using a Multi-Wind Solenoid approach, over that of single solenoids or modular toroids.  The Multi-Wind approach offers the advantages of higher reliability, maintainability, and dramatically reduced external field.  The modular approach allows even 1000 MJ systems to be transportable by trailer with only limited site integration.  In very large systems, conductor savings and reduction of discharge losses are possible. In Phase I of this SBIR program we will perform a detailed comparison of the Multi-Winding and Single Solenoid approaches for energies for 10 MJ and higher.  A conceptual design of a 10 MJ/i MW demonstration system using two or more modules will be initiated. In Phase II, a sub-scale demonstration magnet system will be designed, fabricated, and tested.  A utility partner will be sought for an actual demonstration of a subsystem.
title: Micro-Superconducting Magnetic Energy Storage (SMES) System Scale-up for Substation Application

abstract: A Phase I investigation is proposed to develop concepts, architectures and software structures for the high-speed simulation of military communication networks using novel multiprocessing technology.  This technology can schedule, manage and synchronize large software applications and is portable among a variety of DSP's and multiprocessors.  The system we propose to build is thus capable of working with new processors as they are developed.  The project will benefit from a large amount of signal processing, GUI and simulation core technology already in place within ICUCOM that will be made available for use within this effort.  A novel combination of Finite-State-Machines and Block-Diagrams developed on prior efforts is expected to provide a new, efficient way of describing multiprocessor operation, as well as implementing efficient network simulations.  The results of this Phase I effort should provide the basis for explicit development of a comprehensive multiprocessor accelerator in a Phase II follow on.
title: Multiband Radio Technology (RL Evaluation)

abstract: We propose to make available within the public domain an innovative tool for network modeling.  Our approach is to provide a large number of example network models in the form of full interactive tutorial demonstrations covering a variety of emerging technology topics.  The goal will be to provide the full functionality of our comprehensive network simulation technology for this set of specific examples.  We expect this tool will be useful for training, experimentation and illustration of emerging technologies and standards.  The Phase I effort proposed here is expected to lay the groundwork for a full system of software, tutorials and interactive education focused on modern wireless networks to be developed in a Phase II follow-on.

abstract: With the increasing need for devices such as optoelectronics, which require different materials properties than silicon, new compatible materials and fabrication processes must be developed. A germanium silicon layer embedded in a silicon wafer provides new materials properties while keeping the silicon substrate. Molecular Beam Epitaxy has been used to make prototypes, but a manufacturing technique compatible with production lines is still to be found. Ion implantation to alloy thin germanium silicon layers in masked patterns would seem to be an ideal solution, but residual implantation defects have so far prevented  the manufacturing of such devices with satisfactory electrical properties . The goal is to obtain a 0.20eV bandgap decrease for optoelectronics applications, and this is obtained with an unstrained layer of 50 at% germanium. Such a high implant concentration can normally not be achieved because of sputtering limits and severe surface erosion. These problems can be solved by a recently developed novel "zero" sputtering technique combined with high temperature implantation. GeSi layers can be manufactured by conventional process equipment that are 0.5 micrometers thick and should exhibit acceptably low defect densities. The need for semiconductor materials with different properties then silicon but are still compatible with conventional processing lines will keep on increasing for optoelectronics, high speed devices or other applications. Patterned silicon germanium layers imbedded in silicon wafers provide such advantages. Developing a satisfactory manufacturing process based on ion implantation would allow the design and production of many such devices.
title: Fabrication of 50%-50% Germanium Silicon Layers by Ion Implantation

abstract: The growth rate of GaN films by Molecular Beam Epitaxy (MBE) needs to be increased to at least 1 micron per hour in order for the process to be commercially viable.  At present, this growth is being severely limited by the source of atomic nitrogen used.  The proposed program will design, fabricate and test a prototype source using an innovative new method of generating atomic nitrogen.  The method uses a chemical reaction to strip a nitrogen containing gas to produce atomic nitrogen in a neutral beam with an energy of 0.24eV.  In addition, the atomic nitrogen flux at the substrate is estimated to be greater than 10(15)/cm(2)ser with less than a 30% molecular N(2) content.  This high flux of atomic nitrogen will permit MBE growth at much lower chamber pressures than present technology.  In Phase II, the source design will be finalized and layers of GaN and AIN will be grown in collaboration with the Boston University MBE facility.
title: New Atomic Nitrogen Source for MBE

abstract: ISC proposes a 6-month program to demonstrate feasibility of employing ceramic-faced titanium appliques in near-term light and medium vehicles.  Specifically, functional gradient ceramic-titanium materials (FGMs) will be fabricated by vacuum cathodic arc - a high throughput, low temperature industrial process - capable of handling large, complex shapes and wide range of material systems.  FGMs produced by cathodic arc are fully dense and adhere well to the substrate.  The FGM layer is deposited beneath the surface of the ceramic substrate and then grown outward with its composition changing gradually from 100% ceramic to 100% titanium.  The FGM is brazed to a titanium alloy backplate by liquid interface diffusion - a commercial process that has been used for over 20 years to bond titanium.  In Phase I, two FGM systems will be selected for study based on a review of existing ceramic property database and the compatibility of the ceramic with titanium.  FGMs 100 mm square will be fabricated and the influence of material parameters and process variables on microstructure, compositional transition and gradient properties will be determined.  Selected systems will be modelled using MARRS and limited ballistic tests conducted.  An excellent support team has been assembled: Alme and Associates, UDRI, Ceradyne, and Rohr Industries.
title: Functionally Gradient Ceramic- Titanium Metal Materials

abstract: New submarine missions will require submarines operating in littoral waters to monitor non-radiating aircraft in their operational areas while remaining electromagnetically silent themselves. Conventional passive sensors such as ESM and IR will be ineffective against silent aircraft, and conventional radar sensors will compromise the submarine's own security. Consequently, new passive sensors are required that can detect and track such aircraft. ISL proposes that submarine sensors detect and track aircraft by observing the effects of the aircraft on the existing ambient electromagnetic signal environment. The electromagnetic environment is rich with signals emitted from commercial radio stations, television, radar, and satellites. These electromagnetic signals are scattered by the aircraft and can be received at the submarine using existing antennae. The scattered signals are delayed and frequency (doppler) shifted to an extent that depends on the aircraft position and velocity. Time and frequency shifts can be measured relative to the unscattered direct signal also received on the same antenna. By monitoring several signals, the position and velocity of the aircraft can be estimated without radiation from the submarine or aircraft.
title: Innovative Passive Electromagnetic Sensors for Submarines

abstract: Closely-spaced, co-channel (same time and frequency) signals, interference, and jamming can severely degrade the performance of communication, radar, and signals intercept systems.  The ability to maintain communications in operational scenarios encountering closely-spaced, co-channel signals using signal processing techniques will provide the Navy with increased operational capability without the need for increasing the amount of space required by existing antennas. Adaptive signal processing of receive antenna element outputs can suppress cochannel interference and separate communication signals of interest to allow copy and analysis of the communication signals.  These spatial nulling techniques are very effective when the interference and the communication signals are well separated in angle of arrival (i.e. in the sidelobe of the unadapted beam) and can be designed to work when the angular separation becomes small.  Alternative algorithm (and variations) for controlling adaptation are available with performance, cost (complexity), and applicability (scenario) tradeoffs. ISL proposes to explore signal processing techniques which extract the original transmitted signal from an environment of closely-spaced communication signals, interference, and jamming which way arrive from angles close to that of the communication signals.
title: Demodulation of Signals Localized by Super-Resolution Array Processing Techniques

abstract: The objective of this project is to develop new concepts and approaches in integrated radar system technology utilizing photonic elements to achieve significantly greater systems performance.  This effort will focus on the study of new hybrid digital/photonic radar architectures to achieve the desired performance improvements. Phase I will concentrate on evaluation of performance requirements such as bandwidth and computiational goals, define candidate hydrid radar architectures, identify enabling photonic technologies for inclusion into the selected system, define and model wide bandwidth antenna concepts, and develop risk reduction plans for follow-on phases of the project.  The output of this phase will be the development and selection of the most feasible design approach which can be further developed and demonstrated in Phases II and III. ANTICIPATED BENEFITS: This technology will benefit both government and civilian industry. While the result of this work will enable much higher performing radar systems for the department of defense, it will also benefit the medical field by allowing much higher resolution real-time imagery.
title: Photonic Radar Systems

abstract: This is an exploratory development effort which demonstrates a method for integrating the existing base of independently developed decision aids.  It uses a set of military trackers in a solution which can be transposed to business decision aids.  Dissimilar algorithms, whose products contribute to a cohesive intellectual paradigm, will be integrated.  The question this effort will answer is:  "Can independently developed decision models be integrated, ad-hoc, so that an operator can apply each interactively?"  The specific objectives of Phase I are:  1.  Demonstrate an analysis methodology for the integration; 2.  Simulate the Model Management integration; and 3.  Demonstrate the "integrated" decision aid system.  Our techncial approach is: 1.  Decompose existing, well studied, trackers intodefining graphs; 2.  Create hypercard stacks that establish the relations among input, output, constraint and operations objects; 3.  Simulate the intersection of the tracker parameters in a demonstration; and 4.  Report the reception of the mock-up by users.
title: Model Management System for Integration of Independently Developed Decision Aids.

abstract: During the last two decades, software to support the manufacturing lifecycle has become pervasive.  Sophisticated off the shelf packages are available for most standard manufacturing activities such as MRP, inventory control and dynamic scheduling.  Unfortunately, most of this software has been developed in isolation by independent vendors and does not interoperate well with other independently developed packages.  This can often be problematic since the manufacturing environment is too multifaceted for a single vendor to provide a total solution, making data exchange and integration a necessary if unpleasant fact of life in Computer Integrated Manufacturing (CIM) environments.  What is required to enable this installed base of "legacy" applications to interoperate with new standards based processing models is a meta translation layer which we have named the Intelligent Translation Layer (ITL).  The purpose of the ITL is to provide a migration path between the current "islands of automation" model of industrial computing and a fully integrated, object oriented CIM environment such as that envisioned in the Semetech CIM Application Framework.  The purpose of this Phase I effort is to define a detailed architecture for a data translation layer that embodies the necessary functional requirements as outlined in the proposal.  Phase II will expand upon the Phase I work to produce a working prototype of the ILT and a demonstration using one or more "live" applications.  Commercialization potential for such a tool is essentially unlimited.
title: An Intelligent Translation Layer for Legacy CIM Applications

abstract: The objective of this program is to develop Standard Module and Interface specifications, for the principal components, of a market-driven, cost-targeted, Thermal Imager.  The imager is based on the Honeywell Inc.(HI), Uncooled, Ir Si microbolometer, 2-Dimensional Focal Plane Array (FPA) and the existing Infrared Components Corporation (ICC) commercial Standard FPA Module. Beginning with the constraints to satisfy the home security market, Standard Modules and Interfaces will be defined for various system scenarios.  These will then undergo trade analysis to achieve designs that are projected to be very low cost in very high volume production.  A Standard FPA Module, adaptable through Standard Electronic and Optical Modules, and common to a variety of low cost Thermal Imagers, will be prototyped and tested.  HI 2-Dimensional Si Microbolometer FPAs will be integrated into these prototype Standard FPA Modules.  This is to evaluate the feasibility of the Standard Interface design(s) and specifications, and demonstrate a total product legacy to very low cost/high volume manufacture.

abstract: Drug resistance to chemotherapeutic agents remains the principal obstacle to improved response ratepatients. Frequently, relapse occurs after chemotherapy; this form of resistance is known as acquire(MDR). MDR is associated with the expression of an integral membrane protein called P-glycoprotein (encoded by the multidrug resistance gene, MDR1. P-gp functions as an energy dependent efflux pump whintracellular concentrations of various cytotoxic drugs by pumping the agents out of the cell. Thereresistant is unlikely to be eradicated even by high dose chemotherapy. The approaches to overcome rethe use of small molecule compounds (MDR reversing agents) which competitively bind to P-gp and arecell by this protein, and (2) P-gp- specific monoclonal antibodies binding to extracellular domainsthe function of P-gp. Both approaches have unwanted side effects and their clinical application mayproblematic. Innovative approaches and novel model systemss that can have an impact upon resistant tneeded. In the present study, we intend to develop new drugs against the MDR1 gene based on a new prtechnology known as genetic suppressor elements (GSEs). The GSE approach involves selective inhibitigene based on antisense oligonucleotides or peptides acting as dominant-negative mutants. The use ofenable us to identify new gene based drugs that will interfere with P-gp expression and/or function,tumor cells to MDR drugs.

abstract: Development of an expendable observation vehicle is proposed which is capable of launch from guns with calibers from 120 to 155 mm, sustaining set-back loads of 15,000 g. A 10-pound payload of sensors and guidance and communications gear is to be carried in a loiter pattern at 10,000 feet altitude for 3 hours.  A conceptual design for the vehicle was generated which meets the competing requirements for set-back load, launch weight and flight time while providing sufficient airspeed to sustain a prescribed search pattern through prevailing winds.  The need for high L/D and high span loading is met by a wing with inflated spars supporting a fabric skin.  The technology for this structure is proven and provides an efficient, affordable, gun-harden0d wing.  Four folding fins stabilize the vehicle in ballistic flight and generate the roll torque commanded by a simple but effective flight controller.  Propulsion is provided by a Wankel rotary engine fueled by propane and driving a pusher propeller, the rotary engine being well suited to gun hardening. The flight configuration has aspect-ratio 8 60-inch winds and 28.1 lb gross weight, for an airspeed at maximum endurance of 64 KTAS.  Phase I objectives will be met by generating detailed designs for all OV elements and identifying those subsystems requiring risk-reduction testing in Phase II.
title: Development of an Expendable, Gun-Launched Observation Vehicle

The highly capacity sorbents could be regenerated, recovering thechromate and other metals separately.  The regeneration is expected to beefficient and is simply based on changing the pH from one extreme to another.Bench scale characterizations of chromate specific sorbents and the ones forother metals will be carries out for their sorption capacity, adsorptionisotherms, desorption conditions, cycle life and efficiency.  The metals from thesorbents, except for chromate, will be recovered by electrowinning afterconcentration.  The chromate will be concentrated, recrystallized and recycled.Using the best set of sorbents, an environmental engineering company will conductbench scale testing for a continuous process to assess the merits of the proposedsorbents and will present a detailed report.
title: NOVEL SORBENTS FOR SORPTION AND RECOVERY OF HEAVY METALS FROM WASTEWATER

abstract: This Phase I feasibility effort will formulate a comprehensive algorithm incorporating (a) multispectral/stereo sensor fusion, and (b) sensor/terrain database correlation, to generate a three-dimensional range estimate to relevant terrain and man-made objects of interests, to enhance situational awareness during approach, landing, and taxiing at a representative airport.  It is also desirable that this navigational range estimate be suitable for usage in an automatic or manual vehicles guidance or control system.  Consequently, the candidate algorithm must also be amenable to implementation and evaluation on a real-time information processing system during the subsequent Phase II effort.  The proposed visible/IR sensor fusion algorithm will be based on selecting and correlating features that maximize luminance contrast of 11 x 11 (say) image pixel tiles.  The proposed sensor/terrain (airport) database range correlation algorithm will be based on representing the terrain as a compact wireframe model and correlating the multispectral stereo sensor based imagery with the corresponding wireframe model based synthetic imagery extracted from the prestored airport database.  The need for multispectral sensor fusion is driven by the wide dynamic range of the ambient illumination typical of outdoor imagery.  The requirement for stereo sensors and sensor/database correlation is driven by the need to generate consistent and sufficiently precise range estimates, suitable for real time vehicle guidance and control applications.  It is anticipated that this technology will be required by the planned national airspace plane, due to crew station visibility restrictions during approach and landing operations.
title: Passive Stereo (eD) Sensor Data Collection and Correlation for Aircraft Approach/Landing/Taxiing Tasks

abstract: Robust multiparameter adaptive control system design has become increasingly important in the context of optimization for a broad variety of platforms that incorporate dynamical systems.  Over the last two decades, new distributed control design algorithms and procedures have been developed.  This Phase I feasibility effort is based on the premise that these theoretical developments have now progressed to a stage where a "robust generic multi-parameter adaptive control system design" can be implemented (e.g., Phase II) as a generic multichip module (MCM) based controller by complementing existing design tools (i.e., INCA, Control Wave, Matlab), together with multiparameter visualization aids on a commercial off-the-shelf (COTS) multiprocessor.  Such an MCM based controller, with an appropriate user friendly (i.e., downloadable control software) interface, can be utilized by system designers to enhance their design turnaround capability, leading to the next generation of high performance dynamic systems. A proof of concept problem will be selected from several relevant-adaptive control (e.g., 2 input/multiple output) related design problems.  Subsequently, ground validation of the advanced MCM controller based system concept will be undertaken in Phase II, with breadboard hardware.
title: Advanced Adaptive Control Technology

abstract: This Phase I feasibility effort is directed toward developing a system level instrumentation assemblage to precisely monitor the movement and interaction (e.g., multiparticipant interface, equipment workbay clearances) among a multimember (e.g., 8) untethered mission team and equipment in a virtual (or real) operating environment (e.g., lab equipment related handling of hazardous chemicals).  The proposed instrumentation is comprised of multiple (e.g., 4) stereo cameras deployed at predetermined/precise locations in the workspace (e.g., 20ft x 20ft) based on the specific scenario being assessed.  Additionally, each member has a strapdown inertial sensor suite coupled to a wireless "downlink" transmitter, in a backpack.  All the stationary (e.g., camera) and moving (e.g., inertial) sensor data is input to a (central or distributed) multiprocessor that executes a sensor processing/feature tracking algorithm in real time and provides the task driven member state vector data stream at 30 Hz for each member, to a corresponding array of video scene view generators (15Hz) which are then "uplinked: via a wireless transmitter to the corresponding member.  The proposed baseline scalable system will be designed for a evaluation scenario of 1 hour.  The crew member state vector dimensionality (e.g., all limbs had orientation only, elbows only) and accuracy are anticipated to be a function of the specific operational scenario work space design objective.  The accuracy performance will be characterized as a function of range from the nearest stereo camera tracker to assess the feasibility of this concept.
title: Multiplayer Tracking for Virtual Design/Scenario Assessment
Sprayable Syntactic Foam Insulation For Cryogenic Applications

abstract: Portable, ultra-high sensitivity gas sensors for the detection of combustion products in plumes are urgently needed to accelerate efforts to reduce the environmental impact of combustion processes in both military and civilian applications.  Innovative Lasers Corporation (ILC) proposes to develop a portable, light-weight gas sensor based on intracavity laser spectroscopy (ILS) with the ultra-high sensitivity required for environmental monitoring.  ILS is an extremely sensitive technique that has already been demonstrated to be of commercial value for detecting microcontamination (molecular/atomic/radical/ionic) species of importance in the semiconductor manufacturing industry.  For example, ILS absorption can detect water vapor at less than 100 parts per trillion volume (pptv).  ILC will utilize its established ILS expertise in Phase I to develop a conceptual design and determine performance specifications for an ultra-light, portable and low-cost ILS device with the high sensitivity (less than 1 ppbillion) critical for environmental monitoring of combustion products.  The ILS sensor would be useable with survey air-craft and remotely piloted vehicles.  A comprehensive list of pollutant species that can be monitored by ILS together with detection sensitivity, time resolution and accuracy will be specified.
title: Portable Ultra-High Sensitivity Gas Sensors for Exhaust Plume Monitoring
Ag2Te/As2S3 a High-Contrast, Top-Surface-Imaging Resist for 193 nm Lithography

abstract: In the past two decades we have witnessed a tremendous growth in the application of solid-state microwave technology in the military, commercial and research arenas. However, solid-state sources are inherently low power and with increasing frequency the power output from a single device decreases rapidly. Therefore, the many advantages of operating at higher, millimeter-wave frequencies (e.g. increased bandwidth, improved spatial resolution, more compact, lightweight systems) have been difficult to realize. In addition, in many of the above applications both transmitter and receiver systems often require an electronic scanning capability. IR&T proposes to provide low-cost, reliable solutions to both of the above problems through the application of innovative quasi-optical millimeter-wave circuit technology. A quasi-optical diode multiplier array will be integrated with a monolithic beam-steering diode array at 94, 140 and 220 GHz to provide improved reliability as well as tremendous cost savings over conventional MMIC systems. A successful completion of the Phase I/II Programs would find application in a wide range of commercial and military applications. Cost-saving, compact, reliable, millimeter-wave sources combined with electronic beam steering are critically required in developing areas, such as satellite communications, mobile navigation, collision avoidance radar systems, non-destructive testing, radiometric imaging, etc.
title: Compact, Electronic Beam Steering System
A Reliable Density Profile Diagnostic for Next-Step Fusion Devices

abstract: Silver thiogallate, AgGaS2[sub], is an attractive nonlinear crystal for the generation of tunable laser radiation from 2 to 12 microns. Its application is limited by surface and bulk absorption.  It is proposed to address this absorption problem by characterizing single crystals grown from off-stoichiometric Ag2[sub]S-rich solutions, as well as from conventionally grown crystals from near stoichiometric melts.  both as-grown and as-annealed crystals will be characterized, particularly with respect to absorption by laser calorimetry, photoluminescence, photoconductivity, and Brewster angle spectroscopy.  We expect to reveal the role of crystal imperfections, including point defects, elucidate possible mechanisms for absorption, and establish the feasibility of growing AgGaS2[sub] crystals with very low absorption.
title: Absortption Reduction in Silver Thiogallate

Resampling methods are computationallytechniques which approximate the distribution of a statistic using only the observed data. The two-fresampling methods are that (1) they are conceptually simple and (2) they often apply in complex prothrough other techniques. Phase I research will focus on designing software in the S-PLUS environmenfacilitates use of resampling methods. We plan to achieve this through judicious use of presentationflexible software design. This design will support the different needs of (1) data analysts and (2)who want to modify and extend resampling capabilities. In Phase I we will prototype the design, focumodel. Resampling methods offer the opportunity to revolutionize statistical practice: making it easunderstand, yet applicable to complex problems.

abstract: Rapid, on-line characterization of water vapor content and/or condensed-phase (liquid or ice) mass loading is required to measure the total moisture content of flows in ducts from 0.30m to 4.6m in diameter over a range of flow conditions. A successful proposal must address one or more of the flow conditions outlined in the solicitation. Measurement response times on the order of one second are necessary and the system must operate unattended for extended periods of time.  The rapid response requirements motivate the use of optical, laser based instrumentation. Insitec Measurement Systems has teamed with Sandia national Laboratories/California to develop an instrument that meets the technical criteria outline in the solicitation. By combining Insitec's knowledge of particle characterization using Single Particle Counting Technology with Sandia expertise in Tunable Diode Laser spectroscopy, an instrument can be designed that is capable of measuring vapor-phase and condensed phase moisture simultaneously, in real-time, over all of the conditions posed in the solicitation and within stipulated uncertainty limits. The successful integration of these two techniques using a single illumination beam to simultaneously measure moisture concentrations in each phase is a novel concept forming the basis of this proposal.
title: Measurement of Water-Vapor/Ice Content of Large Industrial Air Flows

abstract: A large body of work has been done based on the fundamental concepts of social cognitive development, including the need for authentic learning environments and collaboration.  It is now possible to transfer the work done to date from the classroom setting to Computer Supported Collaborative Learning (CSCL) and achieve significant gains in both instructional effectiveness and cost effectiveness.  In particular, there is a need for intelligent performance support tools (IPSTs) to aid in the design and development of interactive, computer-aided, networked, multimedia instructional environments.  The following objectives have therefore been defined for Phase I: .  Define the functional requirements, in terms of narrative specifications grounded in sound pedagogical theory and research, required for CSCL design, development, and delivery. .  Design, based on commercially available software and existing software tools, prototypes of IPSTs which can make a significant difference. .  Develop prototypes of CSCL applications in several areas which will demonstrate the concept and provide proof of the feasibility and effectiveness of IPSTs for CSCL. .  Provide a technology assessment of the concept and prototypes which will aid in decisions about further work directions and scope.
title: Intelligent Performance Support Tools for Development of Computer Supported Collaborative Learning in Networked, Hypermedia Instructional Environment

abstract: The objectives of this Phase I program is to demonstrate the feasibility of a new class of monolithic solid state quantum well lasers for the mid-infrared.  The concept is based on the use of a novel electron Fabry-Perot interference effect which achieves population inversion by free electron injection at a convenient voltage level for highpower applications.  The laser consists of a single stack of III-V semiconductor layers produced by advanced MBE techniques.  Preliminary experiments have shown that the energy states have approximately the expected energy levels and cross sections.  In Phase I the current density will be increased to lasing threshold and a prototype laser with one watt output will be fabricated.  Actual lasing action will provide a demonstration of feasibility.  In the option task a Ge waveguide approach will be studied for suitability for high power lasers.  The use of Ge removes the need for AlAs cladding layers with AlGaAs MBE growth reduced by a factor of 10.  Furthermore, removal of the AlAs cladding improves stability, reduces electron conductivity problems in the AlAs, and provides greater thermal conductivity for high power lasing.
title: Compact Mid-Infrared Laser Source
Identification of Human Intruders

abstract: The objective of this proposal is to develop robust nonlinear control design methods based on available measurements and associated computational tools with emphasis on feedback linearizable systems.  A mod-follower scheme is proposed as a design method that utilizes available measurements.  Feasibility of developing the necessary tools for proposed approaches will be investigated.  These tools will form the basis of the next generation of Computer-Aided Control System Design environments aimed at nonlinear control system design and rapid prototyping, rather than just analysis and simulation.
title: Nonlinear Control System Design
Real-Time Code Generation For A Passive Range Estimation

abstract: Development of an inexpensive, portable medical nebulizer is proposed for targeted delivery of monoaerosols to the lung. This nebulizer will not use CFCs, will be breath actuated, and will deliver thand high droplet density. These attributes are not present in any single nebulizer currently on thetechnical aspect of the proposed nebulizer is a small (l cm x l cm) silicon chip containing a very lsmall micronozzles from which droplets are dispensed. By using integrated circuit manufacturing tech10,000 of these micronozzles will be created on a single chip. These chips will produce very large nmicrodroplets, each equal in diameter to the micronozzle orifice size, which will vary from 0.5 micrmicromoles. The nebulizer will not require high pressures, an external pressure source, ultrasonic eextravagant means for droplet creation. Diminution of the bulk liquid into droplets occurs naturallyinstability of the jet formed at each micronozzle. This nebulizer will be effective in delivering measthma, cystic fibrosis, MDS-related pneumocystis carinii pneumonia, bronchitis, emphysema, and otheailments.

title: Portable Nebulizer for Monodisperse Aerosol Generation

abstract: The proposed Phase I work effort will achieve the following objectives: (1) Determine the feasibility of simulating.  CASS digital functions in software, (2) Develop a fundamental approach for the creation of an integrated diagnostic tool that allows for digital fault verification in an integrated test software environment. (3) Investigate development of improved digital diagnostic algorithms that may shorten the development time or improve the performance of fault diagnostic programs. Integrated Test Solutions (ITS) has been expending work effort in both the Federal Government area and the private sector to meet objectives similar to the above listed objectives in order to provide solutions to customer's test problems which are identical to those of the Navy. The Phase I effort will be a continuation of previous ITS work, but will direct the outcome to the achievement of the Phase I objectives.  ITS will expand on previous work in state sensitive trace, LASAR device model development and the development of relevant algorithms to ascertain the feasibility of creating a Fault Simulation Environment which would be a major element of the integrated test software environment. This continuing ITS work effort has essentially established the framework for accomplishing the work in Phase I, and it has enabled ITS personnel to obtain a knowledge of the state of the art available for achieving the Phase I objectives.
title: Integrated Tester Software Diagnostics
Wireless Telecommunications Infrastructure for Rural Communities
A Low-Cost Distributed Fault Tolerant System

abstract: Images are two dimensional and the world is three dimensional. This fundamental difference greatly limits the utility of image processing in many potential applications. Intelligent Automation has designed and is currently building an entirely new type of electronic camera. Our camera will generate 3 dimensional images in real-time. By "3 Dimensional Image" we mean that the value of each pixel in the image will represent the distance from the camera's focal point to the corresponding point in the scene. We call this type of image a "range image." Our camera will be able to produce RSI70 compatible range images at 60 frames per second, or many times faster for special applications.  Under other funding we are building a prototype range camera for long range applications, and for applications where ambient light cannot be controlled. Under the work herein proposed, we will develop and validate approaches to increase the accuracy of the range camera to where it will have sufficient accuracy for application in real-time dimensional inspection, and even more importantly, real-time process control. For those inspection applications requiring the camera to be moved, we propose to exploit a hexapod structure as a motion stage for the camera, yielding a new class of Coordinate Measuring Machine. Anticipated Benefit: Closed-loop in-process control of many manufacturing process requires real-time dimensional inspection, and IAI's range camera makes this feasible for applications where it was not previously feasible. When configured as a coordinate measuring machine (CMM), the camera will make 3,900,000 measurement per second, as compared to several seconds per measurement for a conventional CMM.
title: Optical High Speed Dimensional Inspection
Scalable High Performance Computing Using Autonomous Agents
Real-time Calibration and Dynamic Error Compensation for an Octahedral Hexapod-based Machine Tool or Coordin

abstract: Intelligent Fiber Optic Systems (IFOS) proposes a new approach for development of a compact, in-line, fiber-optic filter with low-voltage, ultra-high-speed tunability for active demodulation of wavelength division multiplexed (WDM) communications and dense computing systems as well as optical spectral sampling. The integrated structure is based on novel combination of three simply implemented potentially low-cost technologies: (i) Fiber Bragg Gratings (FBGs) produced by rapid laser writing, (ii) side-polished fibers or Fiber Half-Couplers (FHCs), and (iii) Active Optical Polymer (AOP) overlays. The FHC/AOP combination forms an asymmetric coupler whose transmission can be made particularly wavelength selective via judicious parameter choice. This feature is enhanced by FBGs. Both wavelength and coupling strength are tunable via AOP nonlinearity. Phase I objectives are: (i) to make use of IFOS's extensive light guide modeling and analysis capabilities to design an electro-optically tunable fiber-optic filter to satisfy the requirements and predict its performance, (ii) to implement a feasibility prototype demonstrating the effect of parameter choice on wavelength response and tunability, and (iii) to characterize its behavior (tuning range/speed, resolution, insertion loss). The proposed innovative high-speed tunable optical filter has the potential for low cost  manufacturability, low power requirements and  compactness. As well as in DOD's communications and computing programs, it can be used in commercial advanced WDM communications and sensor  systems, intelligent fiber systems and  spectroscopy.
title: Half-Coupler Active Optical Polymer Fiber-Optic Tunable Filter
Grating-Based Fiber-Optic Sensor Arrays For Smart Aerospace Materials
Multi-Function Bi-Modal Fiber-Optic Space-Mission Environment Seneors

abstract: We will develop a computerized device capable of simultaneously acquiring and processing otoacousti(OAEs) and auditory evoked potentials (AEPs). A simultaneous OAE-AEP recording device will provide amany clinical and research applications: l) differential diagnosis, 2) infant hearing screening andmonitoring. This system will acquire both OAEs and AEPs using the same set of stimuli and will implemulti-modality (acoustic and electrical) artifact rejection techniques. In addition, the device willmonitoring of the stimulus during AEP acquisition, providing additional safeguards against erroneousoccluded ear canals. The effects of new stimulus signals required for a dual OAE-AEP device will becompared to the standard derived nonlinear method (Kemp et al., 1986; I99Oa,b) currently used for tralternating and non-alternating polarity stimuli used for AEPs. A method of eliminating stimulus artnon- alternating stimulus signals in both OAEs and AEPs is also proposed. Phase I will focus on TEOAit will be expanded to include distortion product OAEs and frequency following AEPs.

abstract: IntelliSense Corporation proposes to demonstrate the feasibility of integrating optical, electronic, and mechanical functions in a single low cost, compact and reliable inertial system. The baseline system consists of an integrated optics gyroscope and a micro-opto-mechanical accelerometer. The accelerometer uses optical techniques to measure the response of the silicon micromachined flexures to acceleration. In Phase I, we will demonstrate feasibility of a silicon integrated optics gyro by performing a rigorous design and performing several manufacturing steps. In Phase II, we would optimize the gyroscope concept demonstrated in Phase I, produce and evaluate the performance of the gyro and integrate it with a micromachined accelerometer in a monolithic inertial measuring unit (IMU) system. The micromachined optoelectronics gyro proposed has two unique technological features: (1) a sensitive measurement technique using ring resonators and (2) unique material processing for the waveguide formation. The resonator technique has the advantages of high performance with low sensitivity to thermal variations, non-homogeneity and material residual stress. The processing technology uses micromachining to produce miniature, low cost and batch fabricated devices compatible with standard integrated circuit (IC) processing. An all integrated optics gyroscope has applications in DoD missile and projectile guidance systems as well as in commercial avionics. Low cost versions can be used in automotive and robotics applications.
title: Micro-Opto-Electro-Mechanical Guidance System
Microfabricated Gyro Using Opto-electronics

abstract: The development of a computer database software in Microsoft (MS) Windows is proposed.  The proposed software product which is to emulate the reference section of Huber and Herzberg's book, Spectroscopy of Diatomic Molecules, will contain complete and updated spectroscopic data on diatomic molecules.  One design goal will be to create a graphical user interface (GUI) which is user-friendly, flexible and functional.  All molecular states are displayed in its symbolic form, exactly as it appears in printed literature.  The search and data display screens will be designed to be flexible and efficient.  Included in phase I development is a module that plots the potential energy diagram (both Morse and RKR potentials) of the electronic state for those molecules with sufficient data.  The end-product of Phase I development will be a working version (version 1.0) of the database software.
title: Diatomic Molecules for Windows

abstract: Due to increasing environmental awareness, the demand for products which are environmentally responsible, biodegradable, and made from renewable resources is growing.  Therefore, there is an increase in demand for lubricants made from vegetable oils and synthetic esters such as rapeseed and canola.  These base oils, though biodegradable themselves, need special additives which are compatible, non-toxic and biodegradable.  International Lubricants, Inc. (ILI) has developed extreme pressure and anti-wear additives as well as viscosity index improvers from seed oils.  ILI proposes to develop new oid thickening additives, ashless detergent/dispersants, including non-metallic detergent/dispersants and other products.  The principle application would be in industrial and automotive lubricants which would have improved biodegradability.
title: Oil Soluble Copolymers of Rapeseed Oil with Dienes and Dienoids

abstract: Silicon p-n junction photodiodes (AXUV diodes) with stable, theoretically predictable quantum efficiencies in the vacuum ultraviolet, extreme ultraviolet and the soft x-ray (XUV) spectral region were developed by us recently leading to their use for establishment of an independent responsivity scale for the soft X-ray region.  In this work, we intend to optimize developed AXUV diode processes to fabricate near ultraviolet (UV, 200-400 nm) photodiodes.  During Phase I, fabrication of a discrete, 1 cm^2 area photodiode with stable, 100% internal quantum efficiency in 350-600 nm is proposed.  We believe that the fabricated diode will be superior in all respect compared with the secondary standards used by NIST presently.  Demonstration of successful fabrication of a stable device will lay a foundation for fabrication of one and two dimensional arrays during Phase II.  Fabrication of stable 1024-element self-scanned photodiode arrays and CCDs will be undertaken during the Phase II research.
title: Stable Silicon Photodiode Arrays for the Ultraviolet
Gps-Enabled Spread Spectrum Altimeter

abstract: The development of a EEPROM tester capable of unattended batch testing for reliability analysis is proposed.  The proposed test bed is capable of operating under the test conditions required for accelerated aging such as high temperature and high cycling rates. The tester is also capable of characterizing data retention and endurance for EEPROMs commonly found in avionics.  The proposed tester makes use of a PC compatible computer and of a bank of microprocessors to independently and simultaneously exercise a large number of devices through multiple read and write cycles. The software polling of the independent microprocesors allows to generate the statistics for the various devices under tests as well as complete identification of the type of failure observed. Full control of the ambient temperature for the tests is achieved through the use of an oven and temperature controllers with set points defined by software for unattended operation.  The system is flexible enough to enable other types of reliability and endurance studies such as degradation caused by total dose accumulation and single event upsets.  As part of this work, a large number of EEPROM devices found in the F/A 18 avionics will be tested and the results reported.
title: Automated EEPROM Tester Capable of Batch Testing for Reliability Analysis using Accelerated Aging Conditions

abstract: Tactical power generator sets for producing MIL-STD frequencies are limited in terms of mobility, deployability, and performance flexibility due to their size/weight and rigid architectures.  the conventional approach to generating 60 Hz, 120 VAC is particularly limited due to the constraints on engine rpm and the number of poles in the alternators that can be used.  While the Army has long recognized the excellent potential to reduce dry weight and improve fuel conversion efficiency by scaling up to high engine speeds and alternator frequencies, the stumbling block has been in the development and skillful implementation of Power Frequency Conversion (PFC) systems that do not significantly offset the potential advantages.  A program to develop a new generation of tactical power generator systems using the HFA-PFC approach is proposed.  The proposed effort is highly leveraged against ongoing research being carried out by the proposing firm under the auspices of the Advanced Research Projects Agency (ARPA).  Under this effort, the Principal Investigator has demonstrated a 500 Watt, 1 lb permanent magnet HFA that scales readily to tens of kilowatts.  For the proposed effort, InterScience, Inc. shall develop system integration strategies to combine advanced engines, high frequency alternators, and power conversion topologies, devices, and control algorithms.  A sub-scale prototype HFA-PFC to be delivered as part of the Phase I Option Task shall lay the groundwork for full-scale development in Phase II and follow-on commercialization that will reduce the cost for military procurement.
title: A New Breed of Lightweight Tactical Power AC Generators Utilizing Advanced High Frequency Alternator Power Frequency Conversion (HFA-PFC) Technologie

abstract: Recently, studies of organosilicon hybride network materials containing reactive R-Si-H moieties have found that such high silicon composition exhibit superior photosensitivity and function as single layer photo-definable glass etch masks.  We propose a unique, low cost approach to dry plasma polymerize materials with similar properties and the demonstration of their use for an entirely dry photolithographic processing for sub-micron level geometries on large, irregular, or complex substrates.  This new class of plasma deposited organosilicon resists will be highly photosensitive organosilican hydride network materials which may be photo-oxidatively patterned and processed without removal from a vacuum processing environment.  Image development is accomplished by chlorine based RIE, leaving a robust, negative tone Si02-like etch mask that allows pattern transfer to underlying materials ina single RIE sequence.
title: Plasma Deposited Environmentally Friendly, Dry Photo Resist Process for Closed System Integrated Circuit Manufacture

abstract: A novel nitrogen beam source will provide 5 eV atomic and molecular nitrogen to a 0.5 cm diameter circle with a flux of 10(21)/cm(2)/sec. Larger areas can be irradiated with a lower flux (eg. 10(18)/cm(2)/sec over a 2" diameter wafer). The technique will put minimal gas load into the chamber so it will be compatible with ion pumped MBE systems. The source will be used in an attempt to synthesize crystalline cBN and InGaN thin films. Nitrides in thin film form are potentially commercializable. The sale of the atom source as an add-on to thin film deposition systems is directly commercializable even after Phase I. The source may be particularly appropriate for wide bandgap nitride synthesis.
title: MBE Thin Film Formation Using Nitrogen Source

abstract: A unique approach to formation of nitride materials using matrix isolation methods will be attempted. Large quantities of reactants can be prepared and forced to react under much more controlled conditions than in CVD or MBE. Important issues that will be addressed are epitaxial growth and growth rates, both of which can potentially be better than MBD. A very promising cluster beam approach will also be investigated which may be useful in its own right. However, if both are successful approaches, they will be combined in Phase II. This work promises a new approach to nitride growth. Both the resulting materials and the equipment to make them would be saleable.
title: Cryo-Radical Chemistry and Cluster Beam Deposition

abstract: Irvine Sensors proposes Self-Aligning Polylithic Opto-Electronic Integrated Circuit (SAPOEIC), a low cost technique that can be used to mount and interconnect both optical and electronic devices of any material on a common substrate of any material without specific designs and elaborate assembly equipment. ISC's self-aligning flip chip bonding process has been used successfully on several electro-optical programs. It involves the insertion of an array of solder bumps into a matching array of polyimide sockets. The bumps carry the electrical signals along with excess heat and the sockets provide self alignment and solder damming. A logical extension of this concept would be to use the polyimide for socketing and as a waveguide material. As the laser diode or photodiode is brought into very high precision alignment by the mating of the bump and socket, then the respective emitting and detecting regions of these devices are also automatically aligned to the pre-existing waveguides. Anticipated Benefits/Potential Commercial Applications of the Research or Development. The development of SAPOEIC will provide a base which will allow fabrication of commercial and military opto-electronic integrated circuits for digital as well as analog applications. With additional reliability, lower cost, and improved performance, the production of OEICs will become more common. As these become more available, communication function design will
title: Polylithic Opto-Electronic Integrated Circuit

This project relies on assistthe place of the job coach, at least for some prompting functions. A small, hand held computer willprovide auditory prompts and participants trained to use the device for self-prompting. The feasibila series of pre-experimental investigations and Experimental Study I, a matched comparison study ofneed for supervisory assistance of supported employees under normal job coaching conditions in compaExperimental Group using the CASP. A multiple baseline, reversal design will also be used to measureproductivity, work quality, and need for prompts for the 10 adults in the Experimental Group. All reconducted in community work sites for four industries: fast food, mailroom, data archives, and legalRecommendations from Phase I research will be used for refinement and expanded testing in Phase II.
