abstract: Mohawk Innovative Technology, Inc. (MiTi) has designed a unique shock tolerant magnetic bearing system design that is compact, durable and uses a control strategy that optimizes the total bearing system performance.  The shock tolerant bearing being proposed for this effort builds upon the Navy investment in integrated rotordynamic-magnetic bearing design analyses, and magnetic bearings that have resulted in demonstration of systems designed by the Principal Investigator, for steam turbine generators, vent fans and submerged pump rotors.  Other DOD investments in damping and dry-lubricated high-speed bearing technology provide the basis for the proposed zero clearance auxiliary bearing.  The proposed time transient simulation tool will include multiple and intermittent bearing operation during preshock, shock and post shock conditions and will permit evaluation of integrated control stategies and auxiliary bearing designs that are intended to minimize the detrimental effects of shock events on system operation.  The overall potential of this effort is demonstrated by GE Marine and Industrial Systems' expressed interest in teaming with MiTi to support our Phase I development and for the Phase II and III demonstrations. A four-task six-month effort is proposed that will; (1) add auxiliary bearing analysis into the already integrated rotordynamic-magnetic bearing analysis; (2) establish preliminary magnetic and auxiliary bearing sizes for Phase II simulator evaluation using the developed design analysis, (3) develop a transient rotor bearing simulation analysis capability that accounts for the magnetic bearing, its control system and the auxiliary bearing. (4) Using the developed design and simulation tools a three bearing single rotor, scalable shock tolerant magnetic bearing system and control strategy will be designed for use in the Phase II scaled rotor simulator of a GE Marine and Industrial Systems gas turbine generator representative of identified Navy needs.
title: Shock Tolerant Magnetic Bearing System
Interfaces For Data Sharing Between Structures, Dynamics And Controls Design

abstract: The overall goal of this proposal is to validate a new principle and method of immunization against the malaria parasite, gen immunization using as a vaccine an immunoglobulin gene re-engineered to encode a discrete epitope of the malaria parasite. We refer to this approach as "antigenization of antibody".  As a model system we will use the tetrapeptide sequence Asn-Ala-Asn Pro (NANP) of the malaria parasite Plasmodium falciparum CS protein.  Recently, we obtained evidence that immunization with a plazmid DNA encoding the wild type immunoglobulin heavy chain polypeptide combined with targeting of the lymphoid tissue elicits an antiimmunoglobulin response direct at both the constant and variuable portion of the molecule.  Moreover, following DNA immunization the gene product appears in the circulation for a period of approximately 10 days in quantifialbe amounts. Previosly, we demonstrated that an antiboldy antigenized to express three contiguous repeats of the NANP epitope could be used to induce antibodies reacting wit P.  falciparum sporozoites, a NANP synthetic peptide, and the immunizing antigenized antibodies, and that these atnibodies could inhibit sporozoite invasion of human hepatoma cells in vitro.  In the studies proposed her we intend to use plasmid DNA for the heavy chain of an antigenized antibody encoding for (NANP)3 to immunize mice and induce an anti-P. falciparum antibody response specific for the NANP peptide.  The studies are designed at verifying feasibility and empirically establishing a series of parameters such as specificity and titer of the antibody response, isotype of NANP-reactive antibodies, duration of the antibody response and priming effect on a subsequent immune response elecited by a protein antigen.  We are excited hy this new approach and hopeful that the ensemble of results that will be generated in the proposed work will constitute the permise for future and wider spectrum investigations on the potential use of antigenized antibody DNA immunization against malaria parasite in humans.
title: Antibody DNA Vaccine Against Malaria

abstract:
Soaking and co-crystallization experiments for studying the binding of potential drugs with proteins of known structure are a significant research function of crystallographic labs in pharmaceutical companies.  Such experiments have two overriding characteristics:  (a) the experiments are repetitive, and therefore become routine, and (b) numerous experiments are performed to acquire the desired information and understanding.

Our goal is to develop a software system that reduces human intervention 10-fold in all stages of structure determination for experiments involving isomorphous crystals.  An important part of this proposal is the determination of appropriate criteria to measure quality during the process and to reject cases not meeting specifications controlled by the scientist.  In Phase I, we propose to build a prototype, referred to hereafter as X-LIGAND, to process a series of soaking experiments.  The functionality in this prototype is a superset of what is required to study mutant proteins, and so would establish the feasibility of automating that process as well.
title: Automated Structure Determination of Protein-Ligand Complexes

It is non-toxic and nonimmunogenic but being similar to glucose, may utiltransport system. However, glucaric acid possessing 2 carboxylic acid residues, should not be able tcell membranes. The mechanism of localization and targeting intracellularly will be investigated. Atequivocal diagnosis for acute myocardial infarction is about one-third of 1.5 million new infarcts aestablishment of such a reagent for hyperacute diagnosis of myocardial infarction should facilitateand thereby conserve scarce health care resources. title: Diagnosis of Myocardial Infarction with Tc-99m Glucarate

abstract: Real time thin film holographic elements are crucial components in a number of optical signal processing technologies. There is a need for development of materials to record both permanent and reconfigurable holograms. Recently, polymeric photorefractive (PR) materials have evoked a lot of interest as inexpensive holographic media.  This Phase I project proposes to develop anew class of polymeric PR materials. The materials proposed are soluble polydiacetylenes (PDAs), known to exhibit large charge carrier mobilities and high photoconductivity. These polymers will be asymmetrically functionalized with second order nonlinear optical (NLO) chromophores and urethane containing flexible side groups. Polymer chains of these novel asymmetric PDAs self-assemble in an acentric stable polar organization leading to second order optical nonlinearities. High photoconductivity and large mobility, in conjunction with the NLO properties, would result in the fast PR response in these materials. These polymers will be synthesized and processed into thin films and bulk samples. Materials will be characterized for their optical properties, photoconductivity, and charge carrier mobility. PR measurements will be carried out to evaluate the PR responses of the materials. The polymeric PR materials would yield inexpensive and efficient holographic recording media. Such materials have applications in the areas of optical signal processing, optical data storage, and holographic optical interconnects. Also, such materials are suited for devices in industrial control and automation, based on real-time optical interferometry.
title: Photorefractive Materials for Optical Signal Processing

abstract: Polymeric materials are superior to inorganic and organic crystals for second-order nonlinear optical (NLO) applications because of their low dielectric constant, large nonlinearity, light weight and ease of process-ability.  These features have led to tremendous interest in the development of polymeric NLO materials for practical uses.  The specific goal of this research is to develop second-order NLO polymers for electro-optic devices.  This proposal focuses on design, synthesis and fabrication of NLO polymers with large second order optical nonlinearity, low optical loss, and long term stability of the NLO properties at elevated temperatures.  A new series of crosslinkable polimides containing tolane-based NLO chromophores is proposed.  The Tg and molecular weight of the soluble polimides can be controlled by adding proper amounts of end capping agent.  The chain end hydroxyl groups provide the opportunity for the polimide to form cross-lined networks by using an NLO active alkoxysilane dye as a crosslinking agent.  This system combines high Tg and crosslinked network characteristics to enchance the temporal stability.  Preliminary results in our laboratory indicate the expected stability in a poled\crosslinked polyimide sample.  The detailed characterization of structure, property and the linear and NLO properties will be carried out.
title: Crosslinkable Main-Chain Second-Order Nonlinear Optical Polyimide for Electro-Optic Applications

abstract: Technology is proposed for in-service detection of airfoil and rotor defects, and of operating conditions that can accelerate them.  The technology consists of deterministic signal processing algorithms that fundamentally advance spectrum analyzer technology for extracting torsional vibration signals from operating turbines. Newly patented analytical methods for constant velocity power turbines will be generalized to accommodate the effects of acceleration in high performance aircraft turbines.  The resulting technology will continuously extract airfoil and rotor resonances and track their frequency shifts as a means to detect integrity-reducing structural changes in those engine components. The current project will also code the generalized method and test it with data collected during on-going, full-scale compressor tests, with the results being compared with strain gauge data.  The resulting technology will provide continuous resonance information for in-flight or ground-based use.  In-flight uses include detecting defects and such conditions as airfoil flutter or contamination.  Ground-based uses include design, development and testing, including maintenance inspections.
title: In-Service Signal Processing Code to Monitor for Cumulative Defects in Engine Airfoils

abstract: Automatic selection of control and display modes using data available on the aircraft has the potential to reduce the physical and cognitive workloads of aircrews.  However, current experiences with automated mode selection have shown that there are significant difficulties with automation that can result in reduced situation awareness, increased workload, and cause "automation surprise". These problems have resulted in numerous mishaps and are believed responsible for several fatal crashes. It is expected that the problems currently observed in fixed wing aircraft will be exacerbated in helicopters using HMDs because, in contrast to fixed wing aircraft, the flight path and the direction of the aircrew's attention are often not aligned with the  helicopter's longitudinal axis.  This Phase I proposal addresses the issues of designing and developing improved mode switching for helicopter HMD symbology. This Phase I proposal goes beyond the feasibility analysis and promises to demonstrate automated display mode switching in a part-task flight simulation environment.
title: Intelligent Information Presentation for a Helmet Mounted Display in a Synthetic Environment
Microelectronics Inspection Using Fuzzy Logic Sensor Fusion
Non-Contact Magneto-Optical Analyzer for IR Focal Plane Array Materials

abstract: The objective of this project is to begin the design of a very large monolithic dual band 3-5 um and 8-12 um infrared focal plane array (IRFPA) and undertake critical experiments to support the design.  The fabrication of IR sensors directly on the Si readout and their interconnection with conformal thin films as a monolithic IRFPA eliminates hybridization and provides the opportunity of making more reliable, larger, and lighter single and multicolor IRFPAs. Conformal thin films can also significantly reduce blind regions at the edge of the array. This effort will plan the architecture for the dual band monolithic IRFPA, determine the most promising materials for the two bands, provide a preliminary layout of the dual band unit cell, describe a preliminary process for fabricating the monolithic two color IRFPA, and plan and undertake critical material, detector and interconnect experiments. Defense applications include IR search and track systems, upgrading missile systems and IR reconnaissance systems. Commercial applications include robotics, processing control and surveillance by police, border patrols and security agencies.
title: Monolithic Dual Band Sensor

abstract: Depleted uranium alloys currently used for kinetic energy penetrators have become a major environmental and health concern for the DOD.  New materials are required which can replace these alloys.  Safe tungsten alloys are being investigated as an alternative to uranium alloys.  The problem is that the ballistic performance of the tungsten alloys has not equaled that of the uranium alloys. However, it was recently reported that single-crystal tungsten has a superior penetration performance to tungsten alloys and an equivalent penetration performance to uranium alloys.  Current techniques for producing oriented polycrystalline tungsten alloys and single-crystal tungsten are not capable of economically supplying the dimensions and quantity needed by the DOD.  We propose to use a plasma Czochralski crystal growth technique to economically manufacture oriented polycrystalline tungsten alloy rods and singled-crystal tungsten rods up to 50 mm in diameter for use as kinetic energy penetrators.  This technique could also be used to make single-crystals of other materials which cannot be grown by currently available techniques.
title: Crystal Growth of Tungsten Alloy and Tungsten Rods for Kinetic Energy Penetrators Using a Plasma Czochralski Technique
A Small, Simultaneous, Soft X-Ray Spectrometer

abstract: The proposed Phase I program addresses key challenges to the development of ceramic-based mechanical fasteners for Naval aircraft applications. Specific applications of interest for the ceramic fasteners include high temperature joining regions of aircraft such as in the vicinity of engine exhaust, and also for use in the joining of aluminum airframe components to the galvanically dissimilar graphite fiber reinforced epoxy matrix composite panels. Existing titanium fasteners begin to lose stiffness and strength properties at temperatures as low as 2000F. Couples set up by the transmission of galvanic current from graphite/epoxy composites to metal components lead to degradation of the composites and corrosion of the metals. The use of coatings on the composite and sealants applied to the outside and mating surfaces of the metallic components has been demonstrated to be effective in reducing the galvanic action of the couples. This practice works successfully until a joint is reached, where a galvanic conduction path from the edge of the aluminum component to the edge of the composite is provided by the metal fasteners. Ceramic fasteners will be investigated as a potential solution to both of the technical problems posed by the use of the metal fasteners. This project will be performed with the engineering and technical assistance of Bell Helicopter and DuPont Lanxide, which will act as subcontractors to MSNW.
title: CERAMIC FASTENERS FOR AIRCRAFT JOINING APPLICATIONS
Liquid-Derived Refractory Compound Interface Coatings for SiC Monofilaments

abstract:
In the semiconductor industry, standard reference wafers are needed for calibrating wafer surface scanners.  Scanners are currently available for detecting particles down to a lower size limit of approximately 100 nm (0.1 um).  Advanced wafer scanners capable of detecting particles to 60 nm will be needed for future generation of devices such as the 1 Gbit DRAMs (dynamic random access memory) expected by the year 2002.

This proposal is concerned with developing advanced concepts for generating and depositing PSL spheres to 30 nm.  In the Phase I proposal, the lower size limit of the current PSL generation methods will first be established experimentally.  Various atomizer concepts will then be explored to identify those capable of producing fine droplets with a maximum droplet diameters in the 0.1-0.5 um range in order to reduce the residue particles to the < 10 nm diameter range.  The residue particles are formed when empty water droplets containing dissolved impurities are evaporated.  Since they are generated and deposited simultaneously with the PSL spheres, they must be of a considerably smaller size than the PSL in order to avoid interfering with the PSL in producing light scattering signals for wafer scanner calibration.
title: Generation and Deposition of Nanoscale Particles for Reference Wafers

abstract: MTL Systems, Inc. proposes to develop and qualify the preliminary design of an Innovative Infrared (IR) Scene Generator using Defense Mapping Agency (DMA) Databases.  The development will take advantage of an existing real-time infrared scene generator developed by MTL, tentatively called IR-Scene, to develop and demonstrate critical aspects of design in Phase I.  By using an existing product as a cornerstone, we can greatly reduce the risk inherent in a real-time simulation, and at the same time reduce development costs.  The first objective is to determine the difference between MTL's existing IR Scene and the USAF's requirements, delineating the work that needs to be done.  The third and fourth objectives are to conceive, design, and qualify software that must b written and the computing system needed to run the software.  For the fifth objective, we will conceive, design, and qualify the integration into a test facility, specifically the Benefield Anechoic Facility at Edwards Air Force Base, Ca. Our sixth and final objective, as is always the case with a SBIR, will be to determine additional areas of commercialization.
title: Innovative Infrared (IR) Scene Generation using DMA Database

abstract: This research will define, and establish the feasibility and commercialization potential of, a parallelized analog hardware description language (HDL) and simulator. The language will consist of extensions to the VHSIC Hardware Description Language (VHDL), and will by synergistic to current analog HDL development and standardization efforts. The technology shall be developed from existing analog HDL technology and parallel computing VHDL speedup techniques, being designed under other ARPA/government-sponsored HPCC projects as well as under commercial initiatives. The purpose of the language and simulator is to provide effective, high-speed simulation capability to support designers of large and complex mixed-signal computing and communications systems. The program objectives are to (1) define the language and simulator - as extensions to the existing technologies, (2) evaluate and demonstrate the feasibility - by implementing a language subset and executing a definitive simulation test case upon low, medium, and high-performance parallel computers, and (3) assess the commercialization potential - through liaison with commercial vendors of VHDL-based electronic design automation (EDA) tools. The Phase I products will be the substative language and simulator definition, the experimentally-determined feasibility assessment, and a preliminary commercialization plan based upon marketability assessments from current marketplace participants, to form the Phase II foundation. ANTICIPATED BENEFITS: An immediate benefit will be enabling HDL-assisted electro-optical designs critical to HPCC initiatives. Broadly, the technology allows mixed signal-designers to apply high-speed simulation.  Commercial opportunities include all mixed-signal designers as well as any analog system designers (thermal, mechanical, fluid, etc.)
title: Computationally Efficient Parallel Codes, Algorithms or Tools for Computational Prototyping (Parallelization of Analog..

abstract:
Plants represent a largely untapped reservoir of therapeutic and other agents.  Of the 250,000 to 300,000 plant species, only 5000 have been examined for medically useful compounds.  Agents discovered include cardioactive steroids, vasoactive compounds, antineoplastic agents, e.g., taxol, insecticides (pyrethrins), ribosome inactivating proteins (e.g., ricin), abortifacient proteins (Karasuring) and antifungal proteins (chitinases, glucanases and permatins).  However, many species producing useful pharmaceuticals are not crop plants and are not capable of being grown in large scale.  This necessitates the use of heterologous systems in order to obtain large quantities of the desired compound or protein.

We propose in this Phase I application to test the idea that the simple eukaryotic fungus, Neurospora crassa, can be used for the expression and production of plant proteins of high value using conventional submerged fermentation.  In this proposal, we will test the feasibility that chimeric DNA constructs containing the gene for an inducible, secreted N. crassa protein fused with Zsa mays gene coding for an antifungal protein, zeamatin, can be used to transform N. crassa and that transformants will express and secrete zeamatin when induced.
title: Expression of Plant Genes in Neurospora crassa

abstract: We propose to develop a novel and ambitious tool for large-scale development: a fourth-generation computer language (4GL) based upon an object-oriented generalization of the hierarchical block diagram paradigm, with powerful integrated simulation capabilities. Developers would assemble a prototype in a connect-the-blocks visual programming environment, test and evaluate it via simulation, then iteratively refine it until it is ready to be ported to the target environment. The simulation would then become a tool for training, trouble-shooting, and "maintenance", i.e. further iterative refinement. The connect-the-blocks approach facilitates system evolution and incremental integration. Previous tools have taken this same general approach, but have been successful in only a few narrow application domains, e.g. digital controls, circuit design, and signal processing, because they are too restrictive. Our tool would be enormously more flexible, extensible, and programmer-friendly, making it useful for any application domain. It would also serve well as the foundation for a variety of domain-specific tools, making it easy to use them in combination. The tool's simulation capabilities would also be useful outside the context of development per se, e.g. for constructing interactive virtual environments, and model-based decision making for autonomous systems. Such a tool is applicable through-out the public and private sectors in the design and analysis and implementation of large hardware and software systems. The tool will standardize and reduce the risks of such efforts.
title: Object-Oriented Hierarchical Tool for Large-Scale Development

abstract: NAVSYS has developed a low cost sensor, the TIDGET (TM), which is currently being used for tracking weather balloons, but also has application for small rockets.  The TIDGET sensor operates by buffering brief snapshots of GPS data for transmission to a ground processing system through an on-board telemetry link.  This simplified the functionality in the rocket payload.  Conventional GPS receivers has difficulty in acquiring and tracking the GPS satellite signals under the rocket boost phase dynamics and also are restricted form high altitude operations (>60,000 ft.). The TIDGET can provide reliable operation under dynamics an dover the full rocket trajectory through the use of the enhanced signal processing algorithms in the ground station.  This includes an innovative "virtual IMU" process which provides dynamic aiding to the TIDGET tracking process but requires only a single-axis, low cost (~$5) accelerometer to be included in the rocket payload.  The existing TIDGET sensor includes logic to interleave the accelerometer and met sensor data with the location data in telemetry downlink.  The innovative TIDGET-Small Rocket (TIDGET-SR) tracking system provides highly precise location data throughout all phases of the rocket trajectory without requiring expensive GPS or inertial components.
title: A GPS Small Rocket Tracking System for Meteorological and Atmospheric Research
Destructive Adsorbents for Chemical Agents and Hazardous Chemicals

abstract: The projective is to develop methods by which a new class of X-ray sources, with a small focal spot and high X-ray flux, the NanoRay tube, can be used in NDE methods for evaluation advanced composites and composites processing.  Within the scope of Phase I, work methods will be developed for evaluating prepreg materials after layup and prior to curing and finished polymer-based composites.  The principle effort will be to investigate the X-ray beam energy requirements to achieve satisfactory imaging of (i) prepreg materials after vacuum compression prior to molding, and (ii) composite structures after curing.  A preliminary examination will be made of images generated by a 10 micron X-ray source.  NDE based on X-ray transmission offers the opportunity to obtain precision real-time data on the condition of composite materials prior to use and immediately after molding or curing.  The technology emerging from this project will have value in the manufacture of all classes of fiber reinforced composite materials.
title: X-Ray NDE Method for Advanced Composite Materials

abstract: There is an increasing need for innovative technologies that can destroy hazardous chemical wastes cost-effectively.  The ideal technology needs to be non-polluting, of low capital and operating costs and capable of producing useful products from the wastes. Destructive Absorption Technology (DAT) has been demonstrated to meet two of these needs: DAT is non-polluting and can produce useful products (fuels) from wastes.  However, DAT is expensive because the nanoscale powders of MgO and CaO that DAT uses as raw materials are expensive to produce.  For commercialization of DAT it is mandatory that a technology be developed that can produce nanoscale powders at low costs, ideally in the cents/lb range. Nanomaterials Research Corporation (NRC) seeks, in collaboration with the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, to develop a process that can produce bulk quantities of DAT-powders economically.  NRC's technical approach is to synthesize nanopowders of MGo and CaO by continuously evaporating high vapor pressure precursors of the DAT-component and then forming nanoscale powders (expected size less than 5nm) in a forced convection stream.  The nanoscale powders will next be quenched and used in situ.  Phase I work will establish the proof-of-concept that high surface area DAT-nanopowders can be synthesized economically.  Phase II will build a prototype reactor, optimize its performance and field test the reactor.
title: Economical Synthesis of Highly Reactive Nanoparticles for Destructive Absoprtion Technology

abstract: There is an increasing need for an innovative technology for low cost remediation of chemical warfare agents and chemical wastes. Existing technologies such as bioremediation are not suitable for remediating chemical warfare agents because they are toxic to biological processes.  Furthermore, for chemical wastes of military and some commercial wastes such as surfactants, bioremediation is too slow and too expensive (requires a constant supply of nutrients, etc.).  An innovative alternative is photooxidation on semiconductor particles.  Photooxidation of chemicals on semiconductor catalyst is fast and works with solar energy. However, for solar irradiation-based photoremediation to become commercially viable, the process efficiency (quantum yield) of existing semiconductor particles needs to be significantly higher. To this purpose, Nanomaterials Research Corporation (NRC), in collaboration with the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, will develop nanocatalysts with significantly improved photocatalytic activity.  NRC's technical approach, during Phase I, is to investigate quantized nanoparticles of TiO(2) (Q-TiO(2)), with and without absorption-band broadening dyes, as photocatalysts.  During Phase II, NRC will design, assemble and test a photoreactor. Furthermore, NRC will initiate commercialization of the photoremediation technology based on quantized nanocatalysts during Phase II.
title: Efficient Photoremediation of Chemical Agents by Quantized Semiconductor Nanocatalysts

abstract: Indoor air in work places, automobiles, recreation settings and homes is one ofthe major sources of direct human exposure to particulates, chemicals and diseasecausing bacteria.  Recent estimates suggest that more than 98% of theseparticulate pollutants are very small (less than 1  ) and, therefore, cannot beeffectively filtered by exiting filters.  These particulates are also know to becarriers of chemicals such as volatile organic compounds (VOC) and bacteria.Therefore, it is very important that a low cost, low pressure drop, highefficiency filter that can effectively remove these particulate pollutants bedeveloped.  Nanomaterials Research Corporation will during this program develop26nanoporous filters from proprietary precursors that have the ability to filtersub-micron particulates efficiently and also completely mineralize any VOC in thefeed air stream.  Phase I will establish the proof-of-concept that nanoporousfilters can be produced and the filters can simultaneously remove VOC andparticulates from air.  Phase II will systematically develop and optimizenanoporous filters, and Phase II will commercialize the technology.
title: NANOPOROUS FILTERS FOR SIMULTANEOUS REMOVAL OF VOC AND PARTICULATES FROM AIR

abstract: Nanoscale powders with narrow particle-size distributions significantly reduce sintering time and temperature during the processing of high performance coatings and structural ceramics; their superplastic behavior can be exploited to net-shape form structures. Nanoscale powders can be made by a variety of methods but production scale, cost effective, environmentally sound methods are required. A supercritical C02 process is proposed for the synthesis of nanoscale zirconia (ZrO2) and yttria stabilized ZrO2 powders. During Phase II the process will be extended to non-oxides such as c-BN and TiN. Supercritical C02 is a novel solvent that enable precise control of primary crystallite size, aggregate size and distribution, and interface chemistry. The process will operate in a closed-loop configuration; C02 is abundant, environmentally benign, inexpensive ($ 0.05/lb.), and has reasonable critical parameters that enable this process to be economically scaled to produce large quantities of powder. Reactants will be introduced into the C02 feed stream. Nucleation and particle growth will be controlled by adjusting the reaction conditions Of C02. This process will benefit from increased polymerization kinetics at elevated temperatures and pressures. Powder interfaces will be controlled to prevent aggregate formation and powders will be collected by controlled expansion . Nanophase Technologies Corporation is a commercial producer of nanoscale powders by the GPC process and has made significant progress in superplastic net-shaping of nanophase ceramics.
title: Synthesis of Nanoscale Powders In Supercritical Fluids

abstract: Nanoscale, highly reactive metal oxide powders with very high surface areas are required as destructive adsorbents to treat hazardous substances.  Destructive Absorption Technology (DAT) is a non-polluting treatment process that has demonstrated the capability of treating hazardous substances and allows for reclamation of valuable byproducts.  But currently, DAT performance is dependent upon the synthesis and use of ultrafine (nanoscale), highly reactive metal oxides such as CaO and MgO.  A supercritical CO(2) process is proposed for the synthesis of nanoscale CaO and MgO powders that have very high surface areas. Supercritical CO(2) is a novel solvent that enable precise control of primary crystallite size, aggregate size and distribution, and particle surface area.  The process will operate in a closed-loop configuration; CO(2) is abundant, environmentally benign, inexpensive ($ 0.05/lb.), and has reasonable critical parameters that enable this process to be economically scaled to produce large quantities of powder.  Commercial CaO or MgO will be solubolized in CO(2).  Nucleation, particle growth, and surface area will be determined by controlled expansion of the CO(2) solution.  Powder surface area will be correlated with destructive capacity using various stimulants and chlorinated solvents as substrates.  Nanophase Technologies Corporation is a commercial producer of nanoscale powders by the GPC process and is developing a range of catalytic applications for our powders.  During Phase II a prototype DAT reactor will be built and tested for a range of hazardous substances.
title: The Synthesis of Nanophase, High Surface Area CaO and MgO for DAT Application
Gold and Combined Fluorescent/Gold Labels for Solid-Phase DNA Synthesis

abstract: This proposal is to demonstrate the feasibility of fabricating novel infrared coherent fiber optic bundles. The application is for a passive missile warning receiver (MWR) system in a space based ballistic missile defense platform. The MWR system will use focal plane arrays to sense the plume radiation of approaching missiles. New types of polymer permit the extension of this technology to the mid infrared (MIR) range 2.0 to 4.8 microns. The new MIR fiber optic bundle will be flexible, highly stable and match the resolution requirements of a typical 256x256 element focal plane array detector. Success in this project will permit greater integration of multiple detectors for large angle coverage of MWR system, with the consequence of greater reliability and cost savings. The fiber bundle will permit thermography inside machinery and other difficult to access locations. The proposed technology will permit MIR medical diagnostic endoscopy for the first time. With use of narrow band filters, gas spectroscopy and industrial process control is another application of the proposed technology.
title: Coherent Fiber Optic Bundles in Infrared

abstract: The purpose of this Phase I project is to develop a PC based interface between a CAD system and a PC computer for the eventual use on a PC based PAWS-OLPS. This objective will be met, and demonstrated, with file transfer of the translated CAD information from a PC to the existing PAWS-OLP System now, with the eventual goal of using the interface to talk to a PC based PAWS System developed in the Phase II effort. This system will be based on an "open" architecture, utilizing a number of standards related to this problem which already exist, or are under development. Project personnel will actively participate in the standards setting activities. The project objectives are: 1) Identify geometric information that can be extracted from standard CAD formats (IGES, PDES, etc.); 2) Determine the amount of other "non-geometric" process related data required; 3) Design and develop a Windows NT based system for maintaining geometric and non-geometric data and a translator that produces a data file from a CAD system using IGES 5.1 standard; 4) Test the system with the PAWS Controller; 5) Develop documentation according to Navy standards; 6) Participate actively on related standard committees. This effort includes, at no additional cost to the Government, cooperative work to ensure compatibility of the PC based PAWS-OLPS with the WeldExcell Robotics Workcell and an existing commercial flexible welding controller, in addition to the PAWS Robotics Workcell.
title: PAWS Off-Line Planning System- PC Based System

abstract: The proposed research will determne the feasibility of extending the steady and unsteady aerodynamic modeling capabilities of ASTROs using modern nonlinear Computational Fluid Dynamics.  The object of Phase I is to explore the technical means by which CFD codes can be efficiently integrated into the ASTROS methodology.  Four tasks are proposed. (1) analysis of the functionality of the Aerodynamic Influence Coefficients formulation, including the evaluation of two novel sensitivity alternatives; (2) assessment of performance requirements and operation bounds; (3) assembly of a compendium of ASTROS-compatible CFD technologies; and (4) layout of a detailed system design.  The result of the Phase I research will be the construction of a development roadmap for a prototype of an enhanced ASTROS system.  Candidate CFD codes suitable for integration into ASTROS in the Phase II effort will also be determined.
title: Novel Concepts for a CFD-Enhanced ASTROS Capability

abstract: In future military and commercial communication infrastructures, there is a growing need to handle high density packaging problems, dispersion, losses and multireflections, associated with signal lines carrying short pulses. High temperature superconducting (HTS) thin film technology has reached a stage where it is now feasible to combine  HTS thin film passive components with various active and passive VLSI components to achieve greater integration and optimize performance, thereby overcoming some of the above mentioned problems. The Superconducting Non-reciprocal Multi Chip Module (SNMCM) proposed in this Phase I program is a compact multilayer sandwich incorporating HTS films for digital signal transport, ferrimagnetic films for non-reciprocal functionality and permanent magnetic films for fixed magnetic bias. It is expected that successful development of SNMCM would greatly benefit a broad range of electronic systems, spanning from military-secure communications to commercial wireless multimedia networks. Phase I of this SBIR has the goal to study the feasibility of an SNMCM by combining HTS and magnetic multilayer thin film technology with various active and passive components. We will undertake system-wide studies of future communications networks to assess the needs in term of inter-connectivity, packaging and system function. We will assess limitations and establish key manufacturing technologies for the different SNMCM layers which will form the basis for a subsequent Phase II effort. ANTICIPATED BENEFITS: Successful development of an SNMCM would lead to advances in (1) Digital signal processors for heavy traffic multi-channel communications system - such as the current cellular and paging networks and future mobile sataellite pay loads, (2) Digital beam forming networks for phased array radars and multi-beam communications antennas, (3) Digital signal processors for wide band, multi-media transmissions involving digitally compressed video, data and voice channels for both commercial (such as the National Information Infrastructure) and battle field communications.
title: Application of High Temperature Superconducting Materials to Compsoite Structures in Thin Film Interconnected Electronic
Tunable High Temperature Superconducting Filters

abstract: Inverse Beamforming (IBF) active acoustic processing and analysis concepts are presented to identify the environmental acoustic parameters that degrade active acoustic sonar performance in shallow water due to time dependent multipath arrivals. A fully coupled normal mode model is proposed to be used with measured data to identify environmental parameters that adversely impact active sonar performance due to time dependent multipath arrivals. An example of shallow water multipath dispersion is described using active acoustic sonobuoy data in shallow water. IBF active acoustic energy detection and signal replica correlation algorithms and methods of using IBF to enhance active sonar system performance are described. An IBF synthetic aperature technique is presented that is based on IBF matched field processing (IBF/MFP). Higher spatial resolution will be achieved when IBF is used over synthetic apertures.
title: Overcoming Environmental Limitations on Active Sonar Detection Performance

abstract: The main challenge to generate virtual reality from the satellite and aerial imagery is the difficulty of reconstruction of 3D models in complex urban areas. one promising solution to the problem is the insertion of the 3D models of cultural features in the image data textured onto terrain elevation values. However, the necessity of extracting features manually in this method results in its failure to meet the automation requirement for the feature extrusion application. NETECH proposes a novel pattern recognition technique to automatically extract the features, therefore, the insertion of 3D models to the elevation data becomes feasible. Combining with a fast wavelet correlation method for stereo correspondence, the proposed approach can furnish the automatic feature extrusion with realistic appearances. The multiscale techniques and the parallel data structures of the underlying algorithms provide the advantages of utilizing multiple processors, which enables the system to significantly increase the throughput. During the Phase I effort, NETECH will prove the feasibility of the approach by prototype demonstration, which includes image registration, feature modeling, pattern recognition, stereo correspondence, and 3D scene rendering.
title: Model-Based Automated Feature Extrusion and Terrain visualization

abstract: Until recently, digital transmission of high-quality images was limited to special high- bandwidth communication links, but even these kinds of channels cannot provide for real- time transmission of high-rate image sequences. Thus, a digital image sequence must be coded prior to transmission and storage. To remove the redundant information, which always exists in image sequences, most high rate image sequence compression techniques as required for some multi-media applications use 2D coding to achieve spatial compression and motion compensated difference coding in the time dimension. The advantages of the wavelet transform for static image analysis are well known and NETROLOGIC has developed very powerful wavelet as well as Fractal Stationary Image compression routines. We plan to investigate the nonlinear multiresolution analysis in the time dimension to be applied either before or after the cociiiig stage of 2D wavelet coefficients processing. This technique will be used to extract and code separately the 'edges" and "texture' components in time domain, in order to detect and compactly code the information on interframe changes accumulated in "time edges". The approach achieving the best performance will be selected for an advanced prototyping study in Phase II.
title: Real Time Video Compression Using Wavelet Edge Enhancement Technique
Application Of A Three-Dimensional Wavelet Transform To Recognition Of Occluded Objects From Multiframe Sensor Imagery
A Network Solution For A Vitual Reality Application

abstract: In order to realize the full commercial possibilities of wavelet technology, it is critical for potential users to be able to explore candidate applications conveniently.  Neural Technology, Inc., (NTI) proposes to create a powerful wavelet "toolbox" for Silicon Graphics workstations.  This toolbox will enable its users to assess the impact of wavelet-based processing for real-time applications by (1) providing access to wavelet processing alternatives through a graphical user interface, (2) permitting users to interface the toolbox conveniently with their own simulation, modeling or preprocessing tools, and (3) augmenting the Silicon Graphics workstation with a hardware accelerator.  During the Phase I effort, NTI will demonstrate the practicality and feasibility of the toolbox by developing a prototype wavelet "toolbox" on a Silicon Graphics workstation.  The capabilities of the toolbox will be demonstrated on 1-D acoustic signals and 2-D thermal images.
title: Real Time Wavelet Transforms for pattern Recognition Applications

abstract: Recent catastrophic failures of Self Contained Underwater Breathing Apparatus (SCUBA) aluminum gas cylinders and similar air tanks have generated the need for a highly reliable, low cost inspection method to insure the integrity of these tanks.  The failures of these tanks have been the result of crack formation in the neck and shoulder area.  The cracks originate from the interior wall and can result in tank rupture.  At least one such failure has resulted in serious injury.  The proposed program will develop an ultrasonic based inspection system that will locate the cracks before they can cause the tanks to fail.  The inspection system that will be developed will be able to discriminate between benign and critical cracks, indicating when the tanks need to be removed from service.  The technique will be rapid, highly reliable, simple to implement, and will require little operator training.  The expected goal is to make the inspection system sufficiently inexpensive to be deployed at every refill station and rapid enough to perform a complete inspection during a refill procedure.  Such an inspection system will insure that no aluminum air tank in use will contain dangerous cracks located in the neck and shoulder area.
title: Ultrasonic Inspection for Neck/Shoulder Cracks in Aluminum Gas Cylinders

abstract: In response to AF95-135, we propose to determine the feasibility of enhancing the resolution of current excimer lithography systems by employing spatial filter and phase mask of novel designs.  The spatial filter (which is a diffractive optical element) will be specially designed for edge enhancement to improve on the high frequency contents of the images illuminating the photoresist and the resolution performance of the excimer lithography system.  The phase mask (which is another diffractive optical element) will be special designed for controlling the illumination direction of the mask (or reticle) in the excimer lithography system to achieve superresolution performance (or the performance of a larger effective aperture than the actual lens aperture).  These two approaches will result in low cost add-on accessories (with mechanism similar to reticle or color filter changers) readily insertable to the production lithography system, one for each system model.  They will overcome the disadvantage in the existing method of using phase shifting masks, which require custom design and fabrication specific to each integrated circuit; they will not require redesigning the lamp housing for illumination control.  To demonstrate the feasibility of resolution enhancement, NIPT will work closely with ANVIK to ensure that the designs and the fabricated spatial filter and phase mask will function properly in their excimer lithography systems.
title: Novel Phase Mask and Spatial Filter for Excimer Lithography System

abstract: We propose to develop a high compact, low cost, and high performance 3D volume holographic storage and retrieval system by employing novel opto-electronic devices. In this approach, the holographic medium - photorefractive crystal is spatially partitioned into a 3D grid of multiple holographic sub-volumes. In each sub-volume, multiple page-oriented holograms are superimposed by wavelength multiplexing. The advantages of the approach are compact design, i.e. suitable for system packaging and immune from air turbulence and system vibration; low cost, i.e. cheaper than semiconductor DRAM; and high performance, i.e. capacity larger than 10(11) bits/cm3, random access time faster than l us, throughput larger than lTbits/sec., and diffraction efficiency larger than 1%. The Market of optical storage are sizable (about $30 billion/year) and applications are numerous, including both military and commercial. The successful completion of this project in Phase I will provide a solid foundation for building a fully functioning prototype of compact information storage and retrieval system in Phase II and its commercialization in Phase III.
title: 3D Volume Holographic Storage/Retrieval System

abstract: A packaged optoelectronic interconnection module consisting of at least 64 parallel interconnections between two stages of optoelectronic devices will be demonstrated in Phase I (including option).  The packaging technology to be employed for the demonstration will be highly compatible with the existing electronic packaging technology of multi-chip modules on printed circuit board (PCB).  Therefore, the resulting packaged interconnection module will be rugged, compact and low maintenance allowing field replacement to the overall assembly.  it will involve replace many high speed signal distribution layers in the PCB by one highly multimode waveguide (which can be called free space) in photopolymer, with recorded volume holograms to couple light from one smart pixel to another.  By adopting free-space optical interconnection technology, more interconnectivity (>256) among optoelectronic devices can be achieved, the layout of interconnections (e.g. for cross-over and fanout) will be simpler, and the design difficulties experienced by electrical interconnects at high frequency operations (e.g. transmission line impedance matching or termination) will be overcome.  The optoelectronic devices to be interconnected will either by GaAs FET-SEEDs (from AT&T) or VCSELs (from Honeywell) and photodetector arrays with HBT preamplifiers (from Rochwell).  In carrying out this demonstration project, NIPT, Inc. will work closely with Dr. Steve Hinterlong, Manager of the Photonic Switching Group at AT&T at Naperville, IL to ensure technical as well as future commercial viability.  A supportive letter of collaboration from Dr. Hinterlong is attached.
title: Design and Prototyping of free space optical interconnects packaged compatible with electronic assembly

abstract: This Small Business Innovation Research Phase I project will study the use of antiferromagnetic oxide materials with high Neel temperatures as pinning materials for spin-valve structures based on the giant magnetoresistance (GMR) effect.  Reactive sputtering with a mixture of Argon and Oxygen will be used to fabricate these materials.  The materials to be investigated have high Neel temperatures, thus they are expected to operate at temperatures above 200 degrees Celsius.  These materials are highly insulating with resistivities much larger than 200 u_cm, thus they shunt no current from the spin valve structures.  Because these materials are oxides, they are also expected to have high corrosion resistance to common chemicals.  These improved oxide pinning materials will enhance the operating temperature range of spin valve materials, improve their performance characteristics and service life for magnetic recording read heads, magnetic memories, and automotive and industrial sensors.
title: Pinning-Layer Materials for Spin Valve Structures

abstract:
Methane will be generated from the anaerobic fermentation of waste grass straw mixed with dairy manure.  The fuel will be used for power generation using internal combustion engines.  The mixing of the two wastes provides a synergistic effect whereby the combination of feedstocks generates more methane than the individual streams.

Preliminary laboratory tests have shown that grass straw and dairy manure can produce about 5 cubic feet of methane per pound of volatile solids.  At this rate, such wastes in Oregon can fuel over 100 megawatts (MW) of power generation.  Nationally, the total is over 20,000 MW.  This can all be accomplished while producing electricity at a savings of 15% to 85% over current rates.

A dual uniqueness exists in this project:  first, a new process for using two agricultural wastes simultaneously on a commercial scale and, second, optimal power generation tailored for such a system.  The project includes process R&D into several critical variables including nutritional additives, pre-treatment, and feed ratios.
title: Methane Fuel from Grass Straw and Dairy Manure
Pulsed Flow Adsorption Columns for Multi-Component Gas Separation

abstract:
We propose a unified front end (UFE) for placing NOAA's databases on the Internet.  The UFE uses a combination of existing World-Wide Web technology along with custom-written elements to present the user with an efficient, content-oriented data search.  The goal of the UFE is to allow data seekers to concentrate on the measurements they seek rather than on which NOAA database contains them.  A second goal of this work is to reduce loading on NOAA's databases and network connections as well as to minimize the modifications required to put those databases on-line.  A third goal is to improve data access for users with low-bandwidth Internet connections.

The proposed solution includes a "state engine" to remember prior user requests.  The user is therefore not required to repeatedly enter the same search parameters during an iterative data request.  By implementing the state engine at the UFE level, the interface with individual databases is simplified.  This overcomes a major impediment of applying WWW technology to database access.  

The proposed solution also includes a real-time bandwidth-sensing feature to optimize the transfer mode for the output data set.
title: Design of a Unified Front End for NOAA Database Access

abstract: The exponential growth in information technology has led to a commensurate explosion in data transfer requirements.  Satellite transmission presents a unique set of challenges since the links need to satisfy this burgeoning demand 10 years after launch.  The new satellite generation must maintain compatibility with the preceding constellation in order to maintain coverage and crosslink interconnectivity.  Transponder power consumption limitations preclude the high order QAM modulations that have become prevalent for terrestrial modems. Satellite transponder power amplifiers achieve their highest efficiency when they are driven into compression, requiring a modulation that is essentially constant envelop, yet fits within a narrow channel.  The Crosslink Hyper Speed Multimode Modem (CHM3) sets the course to obtaining data rates of 10Gbps while satisfying the unique bandwidth and power constraints of satellite links.  Crosslinks with existing on orbit satellites are maintained by selecting an architecture that shifts modulation formats on-the-fly, enabling a graceful transition to the next generation communications package. Channel latency is dramatically diminished by incorporating block phase estimation to accelerate acquisition when switching between modes.  The Phase I effort includes a thorough evaluation of the proposed techniques and culminates in an ASIC specification for a fully compliant 50Mbps modem.
title: Crosslink Hyper Speed Multimode Modem (CHM3)
Visual Programming Development Environment (VISDE)

abstract: In the past paper technical manuals were the only means of communicating fault isolation, diagnostics, and repair action to soldiers.  The need for this information is at the weapon system itself as well as at the maintenance depot.  Several research and development projects has employed interactive stored video as a means of providing maintenance information to the soldier.  The problem with this approach is the massive data storage requirement that is required.  Because of our involvement with the Bradley program we have been able to assess what is available in physical storage device technology as well as the state of video and sound compressing techniques.  We found that the Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory is the recognized leader in this software technology.  They have developed methodologies in connection with their weapons work that have direct application to the Army data compression problem.  Because of this and because  the Government is encouraging the transfer of defense related technology to industry, Nova has arranged for the support of LLNL on this project. LLNL will make available the use of some of their data compression algorithms for which commercial licenses are being developed.  LLNL will work with Nova under a funded Cooperative Research and Development Agreement.  We will perform a data collection test, assess the technology, assess hardware implications, provide a demonstration and prepare a Phase II plan.
title: Video Compression Routines

abstract: In general, the wavelength acceptance of most non-linear optical crystal suitable for second harmonic-generation (SHG) is much larger than the linewidth of a single frequency laser. However, for low coherence sources, like many diode lasers which have relative large spectral bandwidths, the wavelength acceptance becomes an important issue. LiB305 (LBO) is proposed as the most suitable material for the frequency upconversion of diode lasers because it can accept a much wider spectral bandwidth (few nanometers) for SHG required phase matching than either LiNbO3 or KTiOP04. Additionally, Type I SHG phase matching in the XY plane, and noncritical phase matching of LBO are preferred for SHG in a waveguide structure. However, no thin film growth of LBO has yet reported. Therefore, in Phase I, we propose to develop a metalorganic chemical vapor deposition (MOCVD) to grow the world's first thin films of LBO and process them for fabrication of waveguide structures. The success in Phase I will lead to the further development of integrated short wavelength (
title: Metalorganic Chemical Vapor Deposition of LiB3O5 Thin Films

abstract: This proposal addresses the fabrication of a novel uncooled pyroelectric IR detector array having significant spectrum coverage (from UV to far IR), size, weight, and cost advantages over the current ones. The innovation is based on the utilization of pyroelectric thin films of high figures of merits and monolithic integration technology. The proposed thin film membrane device structure allows the optimum IR detector array design. A substantial reduction in fabrication cost is anticipated from the elimination of both wafer thinning and solder bump bonding associated with the current state-of-art. This technology development is particularly suited to meet the applications that require broader spectrum coverage, smaller weight and size, higher resolution and sensitivity, lower power consumption, and higher reliability. This Phase I project will demonstrate the feasibility of the proposed approach by an initial growth of new pyroelectric films of PbScl/2Tal/2O3 on Si via an innovative low temperature plasma-enhanced chemical vapor deposition (PE-CVD) process. The PE-CVD may become the best choice to produce large IR detector arrays in sufficient qualities and at low enough cost to facilitate widespread use of infrared sensing systems. In Phase II prototype devices will be produced. Success in the Phase I effort will identify a viable manufacturing route for advanced uncooled IR imaging array fabrication. These devices have a wide range of "dual use" applications, from various DoD's space-based applications to commercial applications of fire fighting, law enforcement, industrial control, and drivers aid.
title: Monolithically Integrated Pyroelectric IR Sensors of High Performance and low cost

abstract: The use of silicon as the supporting template for nitride growth offers obvious advantages in terms of low cost and the prospects for integration of photonic devices with the mature silicon technology.  However, GaN has a large lattice mismatch with respect to Si while SiC is closely lattice matched to GaN.  Thus we propose an approach for growing very high quality single crystal films of SiC on Si which will solve the nitride substrate problem by providing an excellent silicon-based substrate for GaN deposition.  Our approach will keep the lattice points for the SiC layer coherent with the silicon substrate (no kinks); thus all of the dislocations will remain in the plane of the junction, passing out of the material at the edges of the wafer.  We rely on a non-thermodynamic equilibrium growth technique, supersonic jet epitaxy, that can supply kinetic energy for growth at low temperatures where lattice relaxation cannot readily occur, and a compliant substrate which will relieve the stress by generating dislocation in a thin layer of Si on Sio  2  before the SiC film can relax. Phase I will concentrate on substrate preparation and parameters for depositing highly perfect SiC films at low temperatures.  An optional task will explore the effect of alternate substrate orientations.  Phase II will concentrate on optimizing the compliant substrates and developing high performance nitride devices on them.
title: Compliant Silicon-on-Insulator Substrate for GaN Epitaxy

abstract: The proposed program seeks to develop optical interconnects for advanced signal and data processors by relying solely on silicon technology for all optical and electronic functions. Epitaxial silicon quantum wires (QWRs) confined by suitable lattice-matched cladding layers will be grown by chemical vapor deposition on silicon substrates: these nanostructures should exhibit quantum size effect~ similar to "porous silicon," but advantageously will feature a organized growth habit with controlled dimensions. Although "porous silicon" produced by electrochemical etching shows bright visible photoluminescence, electroluminescence intensities remain poor due t enormous defect densities. Our QWR structures will have high crystalline perfection, allowing bright electroluminescence to be manifested. V-grooves formed in the silicon substrate should encourage the formation of triangular silicon wires due to anisotropic growth as previously demonstrated for GaAs/AlGaAs quantum wires. Cladding layers will be grown on specially cleaned silicon substrates, using (unique procedure developed at the University of Florida; the silicon films will be deposited at low temperatures thereon. Phase I will specify growth conditions to form silicon quantum wires, and to demonstrate strong, blue-shifted photoluminescence. In Phase II we shall prepare junction diodes which emit near-visible light under electrical bias. Because the QWRs will be configured as waveguides, we anticipate subsequent demonstration of arrays of silicon diode. Potential Commercial Applications of the Research or Development: Arrays of silicon quantum wires should yield valuable commercial devices including light-emitting diodes, laser diodes, photovoltaic detectors, and optical modulators. They afford the promise of true wafer scale integration of all optical and electronic device function in a single silicon wafer.
title: Epitaxial Growth of Electroluminescent Quantum Wires

abstract: The recently discovered giant magnetoresistive (GMR) effect in intrinsically layered complex-oxides has opened an unique opportunity to practically realize the next generation magnetic detector head technology. The new GMR complex-oxides hold the potential for overcoming the drawbacks of artificial GMR multilayer materials. Currently, the key to using GMR oxide films in magnetic sensors is the improvement in their field sensitivity. We have conducted the thin film growth of new GMR oxides and demonstrated the highest field sensitivity at room temperature reported to date. Our study indicates that the sensitivity could be significantly improved by reducing carrier scattering at the phase transition. Phase I will further improve the field sensitivity of GMR oxide films meeting the practical read head requirement via the epitaxial growth of high structural perfection single-crystalline films by an innovative plasma-enhanced chemical vapor deposition (PE-CVD) process. The PE-CVD is suitable for practical manufacturing. Phase II would anticipate prototype demonstrations. It is anticipated that the high performance GMR magnetic sensor technology will have wide applications in both DoD and commercial systems. The new low cost GMR oxide sensors will be strong contenders for applications now served by inductive recording read heads, Hall sensors, and AMR bridge sensors.
title: Giant Magnetoresistive Materials for Data Storage Read Head

abstract: Existing mid-frequency (MP) hull-mounted active sonars can be used for high resolution imaging of submarines and small objects in shallow water (SW) by combining synthetic aperture sonar (SAS) technology with matched field processing (MFP).  SAS increases the overall sonar system aperture (from the existing sonar size) to the ship's length (or longer), thereby improving the azimuthal resolution.  MFP provides a means to coherently focus both target and clutter returns.  Transmit waveforms, transmission parameters and the processing algorithms will be defined, and a follow-on plan for a MF-based sea test will be developed.  This approach offers an economical way to significantly improve existing sonar systems because it requires strap-on signal processing hardware without modification to the sonar array.  We estimate for a nominal 3 kHz MP bow-mounted sonar, SAS-MFP based resolutions of 0.15 m (6 inches) cross-range, 0.30 m (12 inches) slant-range, and 0.95 z (37 inches) depth can be achieved out to 3 km range and up to a 10 knot platform speed.  This results in a two-sided mapping rate of up to 108 square kilometers per hour.
title: Develop and Produce High Resolution Image Processing with a MidFrequency Active Sonar
