abstract: Phase matching for frequency conversion can in principle be achieved with cubic crystals with high nonlinear optical coefficients, high damage thresholds and wide regions of optical transparency by using a periodic arrangement of thin plates of the material oriented such that the sign of the nonlinearity reverses from plate to plate. In practice, it has proved difficult to produce a large number of lamellae of correct thickness, orientation and optical quality for operational devices. We propose a novel bonding technique of individual lamellae for the fabrication of InP quasi-phase matched stacks. Potential features of the process include interfaces of low loss without altering the nonlinear optical properties of the bulk. The stacks will be characterized by transmission measurements and frequency conversion efficiency. The process will also be applicable to other nonlinear optical semiconductor crystals, e.g. GaAs, GaP, GaSb, ZnS, ZnSe, ZnTe and CdTe. Frequency conversion by QPM stacks of semiconductor crystals in the IR may be applied to spectroscopy, remote sensing and LIDAR, monitoring the Earth's atmosphere from satellites to acquire meteorological and environmental data.
title: Quasi-Phase Matched Stacks of InP for Frequency Conversion
A State Estimation Based System for Fault Detection, Fault Isolation and Service Restoration in Power Distr

abstract: A combination of newly available GPS2 microchip technology and microminiature optically sensed gyroscopes will allow us to configure a small (2"x4"x4", 0.018 cu ft), low cost, self-contained, battery-powered (2.5 Watts), projectile guidance system.  The Phase I prototype will continuously output all 6 components of projectile orientation (latitude, longitude, geometric altitude, roll, pitch, and yaw) at a digital 120 Hz rate.  From time sequences of these parameters we also compute ground-speed and heading.  Because of our existing aircraft test platform, previous experience in military aircraft instrumentation, and use of low-cost off-the-shelf components, we are able to configure and preliminary flight test such a prototype system with 1000 G shock resistance in the Phase I effort.  Phase II will consist of refinements, cost-effectiveness studies, MIL-SPEC testing, sensor integration with flight control systems, software development to optimally integrate GPS and inertial reference (gyroscopic) data, enhanced G-load tolerance, quicker GPS acquisition, and repackaging for military projectile and/or cruise missile test evaluations.
title: Low-Cost Six Axis (GPS/INS) Guidance System for Gun Launched Projectiles

abstract: Missile defense systems for battle management require dense computing for several extremely complex simultaneous information processing requirements. The computation architecture must be highly flexible and rapidly reconfigurable. OPTELECOM, Inc. offers to develop a proprietary optical switch concept for use in BMDO applications. The basic switch element is an in-fiber grating whose reflection spectrum is shifted momentarily by the action of a focused acoustic wave. A switched optical carrier frequency selective optical tap is produced by using the switch as an element within an all fiber Mach-Zehnder interferometer. The OPTELECOM switch is superior to present day optical switches by virtue of lower insertion loss, optical frequency selectivity, rugged construction and potential for reduced cost. The switch enables use of a given optical fiber grid by many independent signals without interference or relative timing constraints. Asynchronous Transfer Mode (ATM) and other packet data switching protocols are readily supported by systems using the OPTELECOM switch.  Proposed Phase I work is design of critical experiments to characterize the OPTELECOM switch and definition of functional elements which will provide the maximum stimulus within BMDO optical computing and optical signal processing programs. Phase I effort also includes development of a Phase II program plan for functional element demonstrations. Successful completion of the proposed optical data interconnect investigation will identify and characterize an important component for future dense computing systems. The proposed component, and computing architectures enabled by unique component features, will significantly advance United States information infrastructure capabilities for both military and commercial applications.
title: Rapidly Reconfiguring Optical Interconnects

abstract: We propose extending the operating range of VCSELs to He-Ne wavelengths and beyond, by taking advantage of recent breakthroughs in selective oxidation and wafer fusion, combined with better heat sinking. Selective oxidation is not only a low-loss way to confine current and optical energy, but can be used to convert low reflectivity semiconductor mirrors to high reflectivity AlInP/AlxOy mirrors. These latter mirrors have excellent reflectivity down to 560 nm. Wafer fusion allows us to replace an absorbing GaAs substrate with a transparent GaP substrate. This in turn allows flip-chip bonding, which improves thermal management and device efficiency.
title: High-Efficiency AlInGaP Visible Vertical Cavity Lasers

abstract: Vertical cavity surface emitting lasers are a breakthrough for parallel free space communications, since they can easily be fabricated into one and two dimensional arrays. Recent advances have yielded devices with efficiencies approaching in-plane lasers, but at operating currents in the order of one milliamp. This means that it is now possible to produce massively parallel two dimensional emitter arrays with acceptable heat generation. Adding to the device improvements, has been the development of GaAs microlenses integrated directly into the substrate of bottom emitting vertical cavity surface emitting laser arrays. The integrated microlenses are used focus the emission of the lasers for effective free space communications.
title: Low Power Vertical-Cavity Laser Arrays with Integrated Microlenses

abstract: Many telecommunications and data communications applications require fiber ribbon-coupled detector arrays.  Not only is such a product not commercially available, it is currently impossible to buy even an unpackaged bare detector array.  We propose fabricating a fiber ribbon-coupled array.  This will include multi-mode fiber ribbon, an InGaAs/InP substrate-illuminated detector array designed for 1.0-1.55 um operation, and transimpedance amplifiers following the detectors.  Our receiver array will be capable of 2 Gbit/channel in first generation devices.  We propose a simple passive alignment scheme for fiber to detector coupling, which has a displacement tolerance of 2 microns.  This alignment scheme can be combined with integrated semiconductor microlenses to passively align to smaller, higher speed detector arrays in future generation receivers.
title: Passively Aligned InGaAs/InP Receiver Array

abstract: Optoelectronic interconnect modules are proposed which use vertical-cavity lasers and InGaAs detectors which allow very simplified drive conditions and receiver designs. The modules are assembled using an adaptation of standard hermetic packaging technology. Backside illuminated photodetectors and bottom emission vertical-cavity lasers are mounted on a window and are wirebonded to the electrical components. Taking advantage of the low divergence beam qualities of the lasers, the modules are designed for both free space and fiber ribbon applications with a minimal retooling. A complete board-to-board interconnect solution is proposed including the transmitter and receiver modules, Multiplex and demultiplex circuits and data bus interface. The proposed approach uses several chips rather than a fully integrated solution to provide the widest applicability and minimize the market risk in this rapidly evolving field. The proposed modules provide low cost solutions to the growing bandwidth requirements of computer data buses. The modules will have significant impact on the commercial and military sectors requiring low cost, high power computing systems.
title: High Speed Intra-Computer Optoelectronic Interconnect Module

abstract: The objective of this proposed effort is to design a compact infrared zoom lens suitable for use in guided munitions.  The continuously variable zoom of the lens offers significant operational performance benefits to weapon systems using switchable FOV optics.  Oetc will design a zoom lens that meets the Army requirements by employing aspheric and diffractive surfaces. Significant weight savings and performance enhancement over conventional lenses are anticipated to be realized.  The resultant zoom lens design is planned to be the basis for the Phase II effort with concept validation as the principal objective.
title: Compact Infrared Zoom Lens Design
High-G Microelectromechanical Accelerometer
Novel Materials for Optical Fibers with High Numerical Apertures and Optimum Transparency Windows

abstract:
NASA Ames Research Center entered into a SPACE ACT/Technology Transfer Agreement with Optical Sales Corporation (3/94) to commercialize advanced optical filter technology based on research from NASA scientist Dr. Leonard Haslim.

The filters (passive chlorophyll detectors) discriminate the reflective spectra of chlorophyll bearing vegetation by exaggerating the visual effects of incipient chlorosis.  Because of human retina sensitivity, early signs of damage to vegetation caused by insufficient (or excessive) water, minerals, frost, fertilizers, chemicals, insect infestations, pollution and diseases often go undetected.  Using spectral shift principles the filters allow people to see what they otherwise can not see.  The results are low cost filters/glasses for the early and real time identification of plant stress.
title: Early Plant Stress Detection Filters/Glasses

abstract: Crystals of ZnSe are needed as substrate wafers for the growth of 11-VI epitaxial structures for blue and green LEDs and lasers. The matching of lattice constants, thermal expansion coefficients and energy bands, as well as chemical compatibility, provide a strong incentive to use native substrates. Classical growth methods all suffer from problems; in some cases, quality is high but cost, resistivity and fragility are also high. Melt growth is used for all other high volume semiconductors, presumably because the high rate of growth leads to reasonable cost. However, ZnSe has a phase transition close to the melting point. Thus, we propose a slightly lower temperature growth process that combines the speed and composition versatility of melt growth with the features of other low temperature processes. Early results have shown that significant volumes of twin-free ZnSe can be grown. Conductivity without annealing has also been seen. We expect that this process will be capable of meeting the Phase II goal of high n-type doping densities.
title: ZINC SELENIDE SUBSTRATES FOR BLUE LASERS

abstract: This proposal addresses a design and fabrication investigation of a volume photorefractive optical memory system.  The technology supports integration into two dimensional (2D) arrays of reconfigurable optical interconnect pixels for high performance digital processing applications such as high speed telecommunications and computing.  The proposed volume memory array will be integrated into the high perfromance optical computing (HPOC) module program currently under development by Rome Labortory, ARPA, ONR, and BMDO.  These modules use planar diffractive optical interconnect elements (DOIEs) where fixed programs are stored.  The insertion of volume photorefractive optical interconnect element (V-POIE) technology will provide wavelenght selective interconnect reconfigurability at system clock speeds (or faster).  Target switching speeds of 1 ns may be achieved by electrical tuning of multisection distributed Bragg reflection (DBF) edge or a vartical cavity surface emitting laser (VCSEL) diode.  We refer to this photonic random optical memory access system as "PROMAC".  The primary goal of this Phase I SBIR progam is to investigate, define and design a photorefractive volume crystal array and the methodology for read/write and fix.  Task 1 addresses the issues of algorithms, architecture and chromatic dispersion requirements. Hardware issures include V-POIE orientation, transmission, reflection geometries, refraction efficiencies, spectral resolution, SNR, contrast ratios, etc.  Task 2 addresses material technology, fixing techniques and procedures, recording strategies, and performance projections.
title: Volume Photorefractive Optical Interconnect Elements (V-POIE) for C3I Applications
Global (N4) Free Space Optical Interconnection Packaging Technology

abstract: With the advent of advanced infrared staring focal plane arrays, and especially uncooled FPAs, there is an increasing need for high speed (low f/number) imaging optics which also provide the required high resolution while being compact, light in weight, and low in cost.  Conventional IR seeker optics are often heavy, bulky, costly and have other performance, packaging, and related problems.  This SBIR will develop a new class of high performance low f/number IR imaging seeker optics for the MWIR and/or LWIR for these new FPAs.  The optics will be compact, high performance, and low in cost.  The design concepts will assure a 100% cold stop efficiency for maximum sensitivity and freedom from image anomalies.  Several unique and innovative approaches will be optimized and thoroughly evaluated including refractive and reflective optics using aspheric as well as diffractive surfaces.  A key concept to be used is that of the reflective warm stop which will aid significantly in meeting these demanding system requirements. Fabrication and producibility issues as well as athermalization will be given a high priority.  While not addressed in the solicitation, athermalization can often be the single most significant problem in IR seeker optics development.  If considered early in the system engineering and development, it can be kept under control, and athermalization will be given a suitably high priority in this design effort.
title: Advanced Optics for Imaging Infrared Seekers
Develop and Produce a Large Screen Color LCD Projection Screen
Optical Coupler Between Infrared (IR) Scene Emitter and Installed Sensors

abstract: We are proposing to develop a novel compact blue fiber laser which overcomes the limitations of currently available lasers.  These lasers offer significant advantages over the solid-state and gas lasers that are presently available.  Fiber lasers are compact, efficient, widely tunable, and deliver their power in a small core (
title: Compact Upconversion Blue Fiber Laser
Tunable 1 Micron Fiber Laser
Single Longitudinal Mode Distributed Feedback Fiber Optics Laser

abstract: An innovative application of the pattern recognition technology for the development of a rotorcraft limit avoidance system is proposed. The system is based on a feature extraction algorithm and an artificial neural network.  Feature extraction and pattern classification systems are designed using flight vehicle database and rotorcraft performance models.  Display requirements and feasibility demonstration aspects of the project are also discussed.
title: A Neural Network-Based Pilot-Aid for Rotorcraft Limit Avoidance
Computer-Aided Design Software For Integrated Flight/Propulsion Control System Design
Robust Nonlinear Control Technology for High-Agility Missile Interceptors

abstract: Measurement of stratospheric temperatures yields information critical to the monitoring of long-term atmospheric changes, weather forecasting, and scientific understanding of the middle atmosphere.  We propose to develop a simple stratospheric temperature sounder, based on a Fabry-Perot interferometer used as a Multi-Order Etalon Sounder (MOES), measuring the emission spectrum of CO2. MOES uses the regularly spaced FPI instrument function to map a similar portion of each line onto a single detector.  The addition of a kaleidoscope and cone allows the entire lineshape spectrum from several spectral lines to be recorded at one point in time by a linear array detector. Preliminary calculations show portions of the 4.3 um band of CO2 to be acceptable for an instrument resolution near 0.01 cm-1. Fluorescent emission of very narrow halfwidth at line center will have an effect on temperature retrieval using this band at the higher altitudes, but these effects can be accounted for by the combination of a deconvolution technique and a quantitative model. During Phase I, the proof-of-principle experiment and the MOES instrument will be designed.  The instrument itself can be built and perhaps even flown in Phase II.
title: Innovative High Resolution IR Sensors

abstract: Detailed models of limited aspects of vehicle performance are currently used in engineering development, e.g., DADDS, BRL-CAD/SQUASH, PRISM, etc.  There is a need for an integrated model which analyzes the interactions among subsystems and evaluates performance of multiple system functions.  Design decisions which make sense in isolation can turn out to be detrimental in the integrated system operational context.  This proposal is to develop a "macro-model" for design tradeoffs, feasibility analysis, and design optimization.  It models subsystems and their interactions using simplified models of subsystem performance linked back to detailed analytic simulations and test data via calibration databases.  It uses a single, common description of the design concept for all system functions and design constraints.  The "ripple effects" of a design change will immediately be seen in all affected functions.  The model will be embedded in an interative optimization wrapper which will identify conflicts among the performance objectives and design constraints.  The proposed Phase I effort will deliver specifications for the full-scope Ground Vehicle System Integration and Design Optimization Model, and will implement and demonstrate a fully-functional but limited-scope prototype.
title: Ground Vehicle System Integration and Design Optimization Model
Further Development of A Computational Vision Model for the Generation and Analysis of Photo-Realistic Scenes for Military and Civilian Virtual Reali
C4I Distributed Performance Simulation Environment
Integrated Optic Accelerometer with Six Degrees of Freedom

Laboratory evaluation of various design iterations will be conducted with in vitro assayprovide high potential for improved oral health, for both the general population and those with peri

This approach to enhancing toothbrush efficacy may provide highoral health for both the general population and those with periodontal disease.National Institute of Diabetes and Digestive and Kidney Diseases (NIDDK)
agency: Department of Health and Human Services
title: Pressure Sensing Sonic Toothbrush

abstract: The increasing array sizes and bits per pixel of focal-plane imaging devices require a reliable, easily assembled and repaired, electrically isolated, high bandwidth (= to or > than 200 Mbps) interconnection between focal plane detectors (operating at cryogenic temperatures) and output electronics (operating at ambient temperatures).  This proposal addresses the problem of providing such a connection with free-space optics and smart-pixel optoelectronic devices.  Free-space optics is uniquely suited to implementing this connection because it:  (1) requires no physical connection between the focal plane and the outside electronics, leading to simple assembly and low heat loss; (2) has the lowest optical losses of any connection technique; (3) minimizes the number of components at cryogenic temperatures; and (4) can be scaled to higher bandwidth applications.  Smart-pixel devices combine arrays of optoelectronic modulators with signal processing electronics using monolithic or hybrid integration on a common substrate.  The goal is to develop a free-space link to move data from a cooled focal plane to an ambient temperature electronic output will less heat loss than existing electronic or fiber interconnects.  In Phase I, we will determine suitable optical components, evaluate transmitter and receiver designs, and determine the best combination of devices to maximize data transfer rate, parallelism and robustness while minimizing cryogenic heat load, alignment and packaging problems.  We will develop a thorough preliminary design for a complete link, evaluate its performance, power dissipation and cost, identify technical challenges to implementing the free-space focal plane interconnect to be constructed in prototype form in Phase II.
title: Optical Free Space Focal Plane Interconnect

abstract: Fiber-optic switching is required in a variety of commercial and government applications, including datacom and telecom networks, photonically-controlled phased array antennas and fiber-optic sensor systems.  Conventional electromechanical fiber optic switches are commercially available and exhibit low insertion loss, but are not sufficiently rugged, compact, integratable, or low-cost for many applications.  Fiber-optic switches based on microelectromechanical systems (MEMS) technology have the potential to achieve very low cost in compact, rugged packages, and are well-suited to integration to implement arrays of switches and more complex switches.  In this document, Optivision (acting as prime contractor) and Texas Instruments (TI, acting as a subcontractor) propose the development of MEMS fiber-optic switches using TI's digital micromirror device (DMD) technology and Optivision's fiber-optic packaging expertise.  We will: (1) Investigate DMD designs with adequate pixel size and deflection angle for single mode and multimode MEMS fiber-optic switches, (2) investigate packaged switch architectures for 1x2, W, and 1xN switches, (3) investigate MEMS package components and implementations, (4) demonstrate operation of a MEMS fiber-optic switch in the laboratory, (5) identify a Navy program customer for the Phase II MEMS switch, and (6) perform a high-level design for a switch to be built during the Phase II effort.  TI has world-class optical MEMS fabrication capabilities and design expertise, while optivision has extensive experience in fiber-optic packaging and in commercializing technology developed under government programs.
title: Low-Cost Rugged Fiber-Optic Switches Based on Digital Micromirror Devices (DMDs)
A Network/Bus Transceiver With Multi-Channel Fiber Optic Interconnects
Multicast Transport of Compressed Audio and Video in Computer Networks

agency: Department of Health and Human Services
title: Advanced Optical Methods for Noninvasive Assays In Vivo

abstract: A semiconductor laser proposed for optical control of millimeter waves.  The laser emits 2 frequencies  which are locked in phase, whose polarizations are orthogonal.  The beat between these frequencies can be used to generate mm waves.  The difference between these 2 frequencies is determined by cavity geometry.  No stabilization or feedback is required.  The laser is integrable with other components based on compound semi-conductors.  Feasibility of this laser, together with an alternative proposal from Bellcore, will be studied in this contract.
title: Dual-Frequency Lasers with Orthogonally-Polarized Outputs for Millimeter Wave Generation and Transmission
Differential Optical Channels

abstract: Imaging spectrometers (hyperspectral imaging sensors) and various airborne and spaceborne multispectral scanners have been used for the remote detection of mineral in the soil and for the study of vegetation.  New applications are developing for hyperspectral sensors in the area of environmental monitoring.  The combination of imaging with spectroscopy allows their data to be tied to maps and geographical information systems and, by use of global positioning system (GPS), report in real-time on the exact location and extent of events of interest.  This capability is of particular importance in emergency response, toxic cloud tracking, oil spill detection, and more.  OKSI is currently developing the first staring hyperspectral imaging sensor (TIRIS) that operates in passive mode in the long wave infrared portion of the spectrum for use in such applications.  The development of chemometric techniques that are geared for operations with such a sensor will open the road for major advances in remote sensing and chemical detection.  Under Phase I OKSI will develop novel algorithmic paradigms that are based on deterministic transform-domain analysis of spectral signatures, and utilize spatial information to obtain signal statistics.  These techniques were originally developed for target and countermeasure discrimination and their application to chemical detection will be explored.
title: Hyperspectral Analysis Techniques for Remote Sensing
Sensor Data Fusion for an Intelligent Fire Detection and Control System
A Novel Spray Reactor for Industrial Photochemical Processing

abstract: This proposal describes a plan to develop techniques for parallel sampling of the internal parameters of semiconductor devices using optical imaging methods.  These techniques were created initially to study high-power photoconductive switches and have demonstrated the ability to measure the internal electric fields, carrier densities and temperatures in these devices.  Application of these techniques is not limited to photoconductive switches, however, and can provide a powerful tool for the research and development phase of semiconductor device development, as well as on-line inspection. Currently, the design, manufacture, and troubleshooting of modern, high-performance semiconductor devices and integrated circuits relies almost entirely upon electrical measurements made to the device's external electrical contacts.  Internal characteristics must be inferred from these limited measurements.  The use of optical imaging techniques allows direct measurement of these critical parameters over the entire circuit.  Optometrix has assembled the team of scientists and engineers responsible for the initial efforts in this area in order to bring these methods to the general semiconductor industry.  We believe that this technology opportunity represents a significant breakthrough in semiconductor testing and diagnostic techniques.
title: Optical Imaging of Semiconductor Device Properties
Optical Magnetometer For Non-Destructive Inspection Of Aging Aircraft

abstract: Unexpected threats to flight safety cause commercial and military aircraft crews to make new plans to safely complete their missions. OR Concepts Applied (ORCA) proposes to deliver algorithms that enhance traditional techniques and enable on board inflight computation of maneuvers and flight paths that take advantage of multiple degrees of freedom.  During Phase I of this effort, we will present the results of a requirements analysis, a system concept that will address those requirements, and a demonstration of the feasibility of our approach.  The principals of ORCA have been studying problems of inflight replanning since the mid 1980's.  Our past and current research includes replanning for unexpected threats and mobile time critical targets.  This SBIR effort will represent an extension and refocusing of that work.  We have fielded a commercial product that can serve as a demonstration tool.  Our experience in designing and building mission planning systems will help insure a robust and flexible design with a good pilot-vehicle interface.  ORCA has participated in three Air Force programs particularly relevant to this topic - Pilot's Associate, War Breaker, and the Air Force Mission Support System.  We bring with us a knowledge of state of the art routing algorithms as well as lessons learns from past Air Force initiatives.
title: Associate Technology Revisited: Multiple Degrees of Freedom Real Time Flight Rerouting

abstract: Our goal is to develop a live vector vaccine against Helicobacter pylori by expression of urease inShigella flexneri 2A strains and testing the ability of these strains to induce a protective mucosalmice. OraVax and others have demonstrated that oral immunization with H. pylori ureasprotective response against H. felis infection in mice when administered along with Cholera Toxin asAttenuated S. flexneri 2A (CVD1203) expressing urease will be constructed and used to immunize mice.immunity to Helicobacter infection will be assessed by subsequent challenge with H. felis. These expthe use of a live vector approach to immunization against H. pylori as an alternative to toxic mucosof these preliminary experiments will provide the basis for Phase II experiments using non-human priShigella and H. pylori to confirm the efficacy of live attenuated S. flexneri 2A strains as vaccine
agency: Department of Health and Human Services
title: Attenuated Shigella as Vector for Helicobacter Vaccine
Large Throw, Imbedded Microactuator Drag Reducers
Fault Tolerant Adaptive Control For Space Systems

abstract: ORBITEC proposes to develop haptic interface software for virtual reality simulations and assisted telerobotic manipulation.  A haptic interface is a device which allows a human 'observer' to explore and interact with a virtual environment or control a remote manipulator using the sense of touch.  Presently a number of commercial enterprises have developed haptic interface hardware products, but there is no vendor of haptic rendering software to support these devices.  The Mirage project will use a state of the art haptic rendering technique, the constraint-based god-object method, to develop a software environment to support currently available haptic interfaces.  The god-object method is the first which allows users of haptic interfaces to touch arbitrary three dimensional objects.  This generality will be necessary to support the scope of applications researchers have already identified for haptic interfaces.  Mirage's real-time software architecture will allow application specialists to apply haptic interface technology without being experts in the field.  In addition, its object-oriented nature will allow future haptic researchers to easily develop individual components of the haptic renderer.
title: Mirage- A Virtual Reality Haptic Rendering Software Environment

We will design and synthesize a technradiolabeled Single Photon Emission Computed Tomography ligand with high binding affinity and selectto be used in the measurement of DAT depletion and diagnosis of Pd. The proposal is based upon the dtropane analogs bind potently and selectively to the DAT and three tropane skeletons have been selecdifluoropine, 0-401, and WIN 35, 428. The novel ligands to be prepared will be composed of a tropane99mTc chelating unit. Three ligands have been selected for synthesis and biological evaluation in reduring Phase l. In Phase l a lead SPECT ligand will have been identified. If successful, a Phase IIsubmitted to optimize this lead. SPECT studies and detailed in vitro and in vivo pharmacology will b
agency: Department of Health and Human Services
title: Spect Imaging Agent for Parkinsons Disease

abstract: The impending failure of a machine can be predicted by condition-monitoring to detect precursors to failure. When a failure precursor is detected, actions to prevent or delay that failure can be taken. Acoustic Emission Sensors (AES) have been successfully used in condition-monitoring applications. They are attractive because they can detect events that are significantly above the spectral range of accelerometers and provide a unique capability for monitoring transient events such as crack propagation. During Phase I, we plan to define requirements for an AES-based gearbox vibration monitoring system and demonstrate automatic detection and classification of turbojet engine faults using a set of turbojet engine data gathered by AESS. This fault detection and classification system will be developed on ORINCON's RIPPENT application, which provides a means of rapidly processing data through a variety of alternative processing chains. Using RIPPEN tm we will develop and demonstrate a rapid prototype of the processing architecture for a real-time gearbox monitoring system. A system design that includes both AES and accelerometer sensors, signal processors, a processing architecture, and displays for real-time monitoring of gearbox components will be produced for use in the Phase II acoustic/accelerometer sensor performance comparison.
title: Acoustic Sensors Used for Gearbox Vibration Monitoring and Diagnostics

abstract: The impending failure of a machine can be predicted by condition monitoring to detect precursors to failure.  When a failure precursor is detected, actions to prevent or delay that failure can be taken.  Acoustic Emission Sensors (AESs) have been successfully used in condition-monitoring applications.  They are attractive because they can detect events that are significantly above the spectral range of accelerometers, and provide a unique capability for monitoring transient events such as crack propagation.  During Phase I we plan to demonstrate automatic detection and classification of turbojet engine faults using a set of helicopter turbojet engine data gathered in 1993.  This data is particularly attractive because it is from co-located AESs and accelerometers and spans a large number of engines in a variety of operating conditions.  This fault detection and classification system will be developed on ORINCON's RIPPEN application, which provides a means of rapidly processing data through a variety of alternative processing chains.  Using RIPPEN, we will develop and demonstrate a rapid prototype of the processing architecture for the onboard monitoring system.  A system design that includes sensors, signal processors, a processing architecture, and displays for onboard monitoring of critical mechanical components will be produced.
title: Application of Acoustic Sensors for Helicopter Health Monitoring

abstract: ORINCON proposes to investigate real-time pattern recognition techniques that exploit the multiresolution properties of the discrete wavelet transform (DWT).  We will process one-dimensional acoustic signals and two-dimensional visual and thermal images of vehicles provided by the Army to generate several different wavelet-based signal representations (including the DWT, multiscale-edge representations, and best-basis expansions).  We will design classifiers to recognize patterns of interest in the data.  Classification schemes to be investigated include hierarchical decision trees and multifeature-fusion classifiers. Basic architectures will be based on neural network paradigms; ORINCON has several fully implemented architectures available for use, including multilayer perceptrons, radial (or ellipsoidal) basis function networks, and fuzzy min-max networks.  Classifiers will be trained and tested using a jackknife approach.  As an optional task, we will undertake a preliminary design study for a real-time hardware system on which to implement the pattern recognition algorithms developed.  All implementation and testing will be performed on Silicon Graphics workstations using ORINCON's RIPPEN graphical programming software package, which combines a graphical user interface and a software utility library to facilitate rapid prototyping of signal and image processing algorithms.  All software developed for this contract will be included as deliverables.
title: Wavelet Transform Methods for Acoustic and Image Pattern Recognition

abstract: During present clay mine search operations, targets are detected acoustically using active sonar and identified by analysis of video-based images. Recognition and classification of mine-like targets in highly cluttered environments are difficult tasks even when using today's most technologically advanced systems. Hybrid systems that make use of acoustic and nonacoustic sensors, artificial intelligence (Al), and advanced multisensor fusion technologies are required to provide improved detection and classification performance. To achieve this goal, a design study will be conducted during Phase I of this SBIR contract. Three objectives will be satisfied during the design study phase: first, acoustic and nonacoustic sensor technologies will be Identified and characterized (i.e., report timeliness coverage, etc.) to determine mission applicability; next, hybrid neural network and AI applications will be defined to provide automated detection, classification, and localization estimates to an operationally proven multihypothesis fusion algorithm; finally, the multihypothesis fusion algorithm will be modified to provide final classification and localization estimates using sensor-level detection data from dissimilar types of sensors. During the transition option phase of this program, AI-based intersensor cueing techniques will be implemented and evaluated.
title: Artificial Intelligence, Data Fusion, and Mine Recognition System

abstract: ORINCON proposes to develop a multiple-sensor fusion system to locate bulk subsurface contaminants.  Typical contaminats are comprised of fuels and chlorinated solvents that lie on top (LNAPL) or bottom (DNAPL) of an aquifer, and slowly diffuse into groundwater.  The use of a particular geophysical technique/sensor primarily depends on the contaminat of interest, geology of the survey area, and possible interference from surrounding objects. The most promising approach is to use a variety of sensors to measure different physical parameters and to independently integrate each sensor's information to provide data interpretations that are not attainable by a single technique or sensor.  ORINCON is proposing the development of a system that integrates image processing, morphology techniques, and multiple-sensor data fusion techniques to robustly define the extent of conteminated deposits. The fusion system will characterize and image LNAPL and DNAPL deposit boundaries by physical parameters as measured by multiply senors. A two-dimensional image of the sensor information is constructed where the intensities of the image represent the measured physical parameter values.  Boundary information form multiple sensors will be fused to refine the final automatic target boundary location for the given depth z o.  Contamination boudaries can similarly be defined for various depths z j by taking sensor measurements along a bore hole placed by a cone penetrometer.
title: Non-Aqueous Phase Liquid Detection by Seismic or Electromagnetic Imaging

abstract: Phase I will develop a novel photosensitive polymer dielectric which would allow MCM-Ls to be produced reliably, and with high yields through a sequential multilayer additive process. This material would be developed from novel polymer precursors which have demonstrated the positive attributes of polyimides as well as the potential for zero shrinkage upon cure, low processing temperatures compatible with polymer laminates, and low moisture absorption leading to stable dielectric constants. It is proposed that these exiting new precursor materials be developed specifically to meet the needs of implementing this technology. It is anticipated that this work will provide a novel photo-imageable dielectric material which will be ideally suited to sequential multilayer additive fabrication of MCM-Ls. This technology has the potential to reduce the costs of high density MCMs by orders of magnitude.
title: Enabling Photosensitive Polymer Technology for Additive MCM-L

abstract: There exists a growing need for electronic packaging that is capable of good thermal management. Better thermal dissipation can be achieved with the use of insulated metal boards at a fraction of the cost. Despite this, the high thermal conductivity of the metal substrate has not been taken full advantage of in copper-clad metal substrates because of thermal resistance of the adhesion layer which is used to bond the circuitry. Additionally multi-layer circuitry was not possible until now on metal substrates. The development of an insulated metal substrate with directly deposited conductive traces using electrically conductive inks based on transient liquid phase sintering technology is proposed. High temperature operation, low cost, light weight and the ability to print directly onto metallic substrates are properties that give these conductive inks unique advantages. Thermally conductive metal substrates could take advantage of this technology to achieve high thermal dissipation. Thermally resistive adhesive interfaces would be eliminated, resulting in higher thermal dissipation and higher product reliability. It is anticipated that high temperature circuits fabricated will exhibit superior resistance to thermal and environmental degradation. Anticipates the development of a low cost, high thermal dissipation insulated metal substrate technology. This technology will utilize simple, additive processing of stable conductive ink materials to build reliable multi-layer circuitry.
title: Thermal Management in Electronics Packaging Using Metal Substrates
An Expert System for Aquaculture Environment Control

abstract: The recognition and tracking of objects, especially moving objects, in real time from a visual input has been studied extensively but remains a difficult problem.  A lot of data must be moved around quickly and many computations are required upon it.  We propose a two-part solution, made possible by our novel work on two related product lines.  First, to perform feature extraction over the entirety of an image in real time, we  propose to develop a high resolution, pin-compatible, 2-D, CCD image sensor with integrated electro-optic, feature-extraction neural network.  This small, rugged device will couple a novel, miniature, "distributed optical device" of our design and manufacture to a commercially available image sensor.  This modified sensor will plug into the image sensor socket in a video camera and, using the massive parallelism of optics, extract features over the entirety of scenes that are imaged upon it.  Second, to increase flexibility and perform neural network and signal processing operations in time and space n real time over the extracted features that are output from the sensor, we propose to develop algorithms that run on our A236 Parallel Signal Processor Module.  This small, low cost module provides a unique combination of very high performance, large memory capacity and bandwidth, low power dissipation and very high I/O rates for real time applications.
title: Powerful, Electo-Optical, Image Processing and Pattern Recognition Device
Human Systems/Subsystems Research

abstract: PSR will develop the preliminary design for an eye safe laser radar system to assist with carrier landings.  This laser radar system will measure local wind conditions, detect wind sheers along the glide slope, and measure deck positions, aspect and motion.  This information will be processed and integrated into the existing automatic Carrier Landing System (ACLS) to provide instantaneous flight control correction during carrier landing.  Through the existing ACLS interface, the laser radar data could be sued for improved "hands off" landing operation or to modify existing pilot landing cues (meedles).  PSR's approach is to use an existing aircraft optical aperture for the laser radar's transceiver and off-the-shelp processign and laser technology, with the potential of using fiber optics so that the laser radar transmitter, receiver and/or processor can be remotely located within the aircraft.  This also offers the crucial advantage of accessing existing laser assets (transmitters, processors, etc.) for landing support functions.  This technological approach is compatible with installation of a wide variety of aircraft and should significantly enhance safety of carrier deck operations.
title: LASER RADAR FOR INSTANTANEOUS FLIGHT CONTROL CORRECTION DURING CARRIER LANDINGS

abstract: The significance in providing a solution for rapid map production lies in the cost savings for the entire mapping community, the benefits to resolving environmental problems on a local and global scale, and to assist in resolving problems of a military nature for the purpose of securing peace worldwide.  The key to successfully developing a rapid map production system utilizing high resolution, high accuracy data, is to properly identify the engineering technologies required and to integrate these technologies into a robust and expandable system.  The developed rapid map production capability should be portable and transferable to the mapping community at large.  This proposal describes an approach for establishing the basis for developing a rapid map production system.  A majority of the Phase I work will be to develop, validate, and integrate automated computer algorithms for feature classification and extraction.  Both classical PR and neural network (NN) approaches will be investigated.  Innovative approaches to the data classification problem are outlined in this proposal, and a testing/verification methodology is also presented.  The two source data considered for feature classification and extraction are fine resolution SAR data, and high resolution digital elevation  models (DEMs).
title: Computer Automated Image/DEM Feature Classification and Extraction

abstract: Pacific-Sierra Research Corporation (PSR) proposes to provide the research necessary to fully characterize the automated system design process.  Relevant existing (and future) tools will be identified.  Development of needed new capabilities, especially those required for integration/configuration of simulation models, will be identified and prioritized.  Cost and schedules for the highest priority needs will be provided.  Research will focus on the integration and synthesis strategies necessary to establish a virtual prototyping system design capability.  Specifically, the work will address integration approaches based on the following required capabilities:  -  Databases (DTED, JCALS, DES, TPSs) -  Highly configurable aircraft cockpit prototypes for human operators -  Mission planning and C4I capability -  Recording and analysis tools to isolate problems of the prototype -  Model systhesis and library capability
title: SIMULATION ENVIRONMENT FOR THE RAPID PROTOTYPING OF ADVANCED AVIONICS

abstract: PSR proposes exploratory development research aimed at devising methods which employ binary optics to improve the performance and cost effectiveness of airborne electro-optical sensors, including missile seekers, reconnaissance cameras (visible, mid and far infrared) and guided bomb laser sensors.  Significant reduction in sensor weight, size and cost are anticipated.  Specific examples of reduced parts count, improved thermal and chromatic optical performance are presented as evidence of the potential of binary optics in similar applications.  Examples of practical, producible binary optical elements demonstrate the producibility of these novel designs.  PSR proposes teaming with Teledyne Brown Engineering, Huntsville, AL, for theoretical design assistance for Phse I option and the production of prototypes in Phase II.
title: Binary Optics for Electro-Optical Sensors

abstract: While there has been a great investment by the Government in all types of infrared focal plane arrays (FPAs) over the past several years, there has been little direct investment in innovative imaging systems to mate with these FPAs.  For the most part, classical imaging solutions have been applied to this optical imaging problem with a certain level of success.  However, the latest generation of focal planes utilize a unit cell size which is driving a demand for very fast (low f/number) imaging objectives. Clearly, more innovative imaging solutions must be found.  This proposal demonstrates how advances in optical design, coating, and fabrication technology can be brought together to design hybrid refractive/diffractive systems which can keep pace with both uncooled and cooled focal plane technology.  Here two novel objective forms are introduced:  (i) the AMOS (Athermal Multiple Order Imaging System) imaging concept and (ii) the ACIS (Athermal Catadioptic Imaging System) imaging concepts.  Both concepts utilize hybrid refractive/diffractive components and can be used for either uncooled or cooled focal plane array. Both AMOS and ACIS type systems allow for ultra wideband imaging at very low f/numbers.  In addition, the configurations offer a reduced element count making them more manufacturable at a lower cost.
title: Novel Applications of Diffractive Optical Elements for Infrared Seekers

abstract: Future spacecraft will require reliable, passive thermal control systems.  Capillary pumped loops (CPLs) are currently limited by the performance of conventional capillary evaporators because their heat transport capacity and their heat flux capability are low.  We propose to develop a reliable CPL with higher flow and pumping head capacity than conventional CPLs, thus increasing the heat transport capacity of the system and the intensity of the heat flux that can be absorbed.  Benefits are a passive, lightweight, low cost, and reliable thermal control system.  In Phase I we will prove the feasibility of the reliable capillary pump by (1) proof-of-concept experiments that demonstrate operation of the key CPL component, (2) fabrication experiments that demonstrate the feasibility of economically producing the capillary pump, (3) conceptual design of a CPL, and (4) analysis of CPL performance to quantify the expected benefits.
title: Reliable Capillary Pump

abstract: This proposal addresses the development of a novel permanent magnet motor for a miniature centrifugal compressor.  The compressor is a critical component in a low capacity, vibration free, long life cryocooler.  Key features of the development include the incorporation of a permanent magnet in a miniature high speed shaft, and a unique and simple control system to synchronize the motor at its optimum efficiency point.  This motor concept promises a major increase in efficiency over existing miniature induction motors.  The increase in efficiency will, for the first time, enable the use of turbomachine-based cryocoolers in spaceborne applications where input power to the system is limited to about 100 W and where cooling requirements are in the range of 0.5 W - 2 W at temperatures between 35 K and 100 K.  Phase I consists of proof-of-concept demonstration of the permanent magnet motor.  In Phase II, prototype compressor will be designed, fabricated, and tested in reverse-Brayton cryocooler.
title: A Miniature Permanent Magnet Motor for Low Capacity Reverse-Brayton Cyle Cryocoolers for Space

abstract: Recent developments in orifice pulse tube refrigerator (OPTR) technology have made these devices competitive with Stirling cycle cryocoolers for long-life spacecraft service, but further improvements in efficiency, capacity, miniaturization, and reliability are required. We propose an innovative and simplified thermodynamic cycle, based upon the enthalpy flux heat-lifting principle of the OPTR, with potential benefits in reliability weight, and manufacturing cost. The Phase I project objective is to prove the principle of operation in breadboard hardware and to empirically define sensitivity of performance to design parameters. The Phase I effort includes breadboard apparatus construction, testing, data analysis, and documentation. Anticipated benefits include substantial reductions in cost for highly reliable mechanical refrigerators and heat pumps for extended mission spacecraft applications. The innovation has broad potential commercial application for compact and light-weight, low-cost cryogenic cooling of HTS components in telecommunications systems, high-density electronic systems, and medical instrumentation.
title: Refrigeration Cycle for Thermal Management Applications

abstract: The use of robot technology in many military and private sector applications has been limited due to the application-specific nature of available robot hardware and control software.  the use of robots with multiple sensors, kinematic redundancy, and mobile bases has been restricted because of the lack of a a flexible means to develop robust control algorithms for positioning, interaction forces, and high level tasks.  We propose to develop an object- oriented, robot control and development environment (OORCDE) which provides a method for rapid prototype testing of novel robot hardware configurations and task requirements.  The OORCDE provides tools that use descriptions of the robot hardware (sensors, actuators, and physical parameters) and the desired tasks to generate control algorithms which may subsequently be directly loaded into target processors to implement closed-loop control. The feasibility of the proposed concept will be established during Phase I by a demonstration of the methodology and by completing the preliminary design of the object-oriented modules and software, and simulating an illustrative example.  In Phase II, a full scale system will be designed, assembled, and tested using existing sensor-based, mobile robot test beds.
title: Object-Oriented Robot Control and Development Environment

abstract: A rugged CD-ROM optical disk drive utilizing a commercially available drive will be developed for use in harsh environments. Techniques for using optical disk drives in space-based flight experiments will be adapted for use in airborne, shipboard, and fielded applications.  These include: suitable mechanical and electrical interfaces, shock/vibration isolation, and extended operating ranges. Efficient use of commercial-off-the-shelf elements will serve to reduce overall cost.

abstract: Retention of learned skills is a key issue in the efficiency and effectiveness of training.  This research takes a systematic approach to identifying, measuring, and validating a wider range of retention-relevant variables than has been studied before.  The scientific focus is on a retention model that will identify effects of various practical variables on training retention. The practical focus is on a computerized procedure that will allow training practitioners to input key aspects of the training situation and learn the optimal means of training as well as the practical effects of various training decisions.  This implementation of the retention model represents an important step in bridging the gap between science and practice. The model will be identified by a literature review on skill retention and models of skilled performance.  We will then develop and refine a means of measuring these variables in a Inventory of Task and Instructional Characteristics (ITIC), with different versions for administration to task experts, training personnel, and trainees.  Phase I will also include development of a prototype computer module to demonstrate the decision-making procedure.  We will also refine a plan for Phase II validation of the ITIC and completion of the computerized procedure.
title: Human Systems/Subsystems Research: Toward a Model of Skill Retention: Identification, Measurement, and Validation of Critical Retention-relevant Va
Enhancing the Accuracy and Utility of Performance Measurement in the AF

abstract: We propose to study, formulate and assess the concept of a Virtual Test Range (VTR).  A virtual test range, and its close relative the Virtual Training Range, allow live and simulated vehicles and troops to interoperate in the same exercise.  Live vehicles and soldiers are instrumented to allow them to see into, and themselves to be seen in, a virtual battlefield which correlates to the actual terrain.  VTR allows conventional vehicles to emulate experimental ones.  VTR also allows a few live vehicles to be augmented with simulated forces to form complete BLUFOR and OPFOR units.  Because of the expense of fidelity and concerns regarding validation, emulated live vehicles lower cost and allow better testing over that of simulator-only methods.  Because of environmental damage restrictions, OPTEMPO reductions, and safety considerations, fewer live vehicles lower cost and allow increased training over that of field-only methods.  Previous demonstrations have shown that VTR is possible, in principle.  We propose here to establish the necessary system requirements, architecture, and technical basis for assessing the feasibility of the complete VTR concept based on actual user community needs.  Newer technologies will be investigated to lower instrumentation cost and to allow simulated targets to be merged with real out-the-window views.  Our ultimate goal for Phase I is to demonstrate the VTR concept in a functional mobile breadboard.
title: Virtual Test Range: Concept and Feasibility
Thermal Management for Controls and Accessories on Advanced Gas Turbine Engines

abstract: The Perrigo Technology, Inc. team proposes an innovative, multi- discipline research program to develop a rapid repair system by integrating emerging corrosion control technology with many recent developments in the use of steel components to strengthen concrete structures.  The proposed repair system consists of prefabricated "steel component modules" suitable for various common repair scenarios, supplemented by a combination of protective coatings, cathodic protection, proper corrosion design configurations and procedures to minimize material degradation during transportation, storage and installation.  The proposed repair methods combine corrosion control advances with recent innovative structural and construction engineering developments in the following areas: 1) the use of steel plates to strengthen concrete members, 2) the steel/concrete composite construction, and 3) various pile replacement retrofit methods with steel pipe piles.  The repair system will be designed for easy transportation, storage, and installation.  It also will be suited for rapid repairs in emergency conditions where it is necessary to ensure continuous port operation.  Based on extensive previous studies and field-proven methods, the proposed research has a great potential for significant early return on the investment by reducing repair costs.
title: Innovative Steel Component Module Repair Approach for Waterfront Infrastructure
A Common Semantic Framework for Procedural and Non-Procedural Object-Oriented Database Developm

abstract: We will develop a computerized self- management program for hypertension. The computer-assisted nutexercise program for hypertension (CANE-H) will incorporate a hand-held computer (HHC) for structuriand a set of written support materials. The product will be unique because it incorporates the criticlinic-based programs for lifestyle intervention, e.g., sound nutrition, exercise, and behavior modithem in a hand-held computer. The computerized delivery format will offer many unique features, e.g.instantaneous feedback, and simplified self-monitoring that may result in greater ease of use and eftraditional manual-based self- management programs. In particular, a computer-assisted program may pnecessary to enhance long-term maintenance where many other approaches have been unsuccessful. Durinprototype of the CANE-H system will be developed and tested for feasibility in a short-term self-helwho have high normal blood pressure or mild hypertension. abstract: This proposal is for the synthesis and testing of rigid analogs of the antipsychotic drug clozapineclozapine does not cause extrapyramidal and endocrine side effects that are typical of antipsychoticagranulocytosis in 1-2% of schizophrenics who take the drug. Because of this, there is a need for aantipsychotic drug that does not cause this potentially fatal side effect. Based on molecular modeliidentified the structural features that distinguish clozapine from other antipsychotic drugs. This wcompounds that share those structural features in a rigid structure. These compounds were energy minMM2-87 program and the resultant structures were superimposed onto a crystal structure of clozapinesquares sense to determine which compounds were the best fit to clozapine and to prioritize the rigisynthesis. The synthesized compounds will be screened for affinity at dopamine D2, D3, and D4 receptatypical profile of clozapine appears to be due to its D4 selectivity relative to D2 receptors. Thethis proposal is to develop a clozapine-like antipsychotic drug that does not cause agranulocytosis.

abstract: The Surface Discharge (SD) is an electrically driven impulsive acoustic source with a broadband low frequency spectrum. In comparison to an explosive acoustic source the SD is safe, reusable, can provide pulse trains and has controllable acoustic output. The originator of the Surface Discharge acoustic source proposes to evaluate the use of SD technology for "A1" size sonobuoy applications. Existing SD acoustic source technology, developed for surveillance arrays, has novel features attractive for use in sonobuoys. The SD has high efficiency in converting electrical into acoustic energy and a compact transducer design that translate into a powerful impulsive acoustic source with the potential to supplement or replace explosive acoustic sources currently in use. Controllability includes both the ability to determine the peak in the acoustic spectrum as well as precise electronic timing of pressure waveforms. Unlike explosives, an SD system can ping many times, and will eliminate the safety and environmental concerns of explosives. Phoenix Science & Technology (PS&T) proposes to apply its unique knowledge of low frequency impulsive SD sources in a design study to determine the SD's Energy Source Level (ESL) and acoustic spectral capabilities in an "A" size sonobuoy, in comparison to a four pound SUS charge. We will trade-off the maximum ESL as a function of number of pings and ping repetition rate, and use existing experimental data to determine the timing accuracy capability for producing programmable wavetrains. In addition, we will design single and 3 element SD systems for fabrication and testing in Phase II.
title: Evaluation of a Controllable Impulsive Surface Discharge Acoustic Source for "A" Size Sonobuoy Application

abstract: This project will develop a design and proof-of-concept demonstration kernel for an Integrated Data-Model Assimilation Package (IDAP), appropriate for high-fidelity synthetic scene generation and other modeling and simulation applications. IDAP will integrate an existing data access and analysis package, the Visual Interface for Space and Terrestrial Analysis (VISTA), and an existing high-fidelity scene generation capability, the Synthetic Scene Generation @del (SSCM), and leverage from the experience and software from preliminary work in this area being undertaken by NRL. The five objectives of the work are to: assess the capabilities of an SSGM Data Driven Module; establish priorities for IDAP functionalities; identify data-model assimilation tools and techniques to meet the above priorities; develop a detailed IDAP design; and implement and test a high priority IDAP functionality as a proof-of-concept.
title: Integrated Data-Model Assimilation Package (IDAP)
IR Scene Generation Using Defense Mapping Agency (DM)

abstract: Future naval systems will reduce the number of separate shipboard and airborne antennas by sharing sensor, receiver, and signal processing resources.  A robust signal processor, capable of handling a multi- tude of signal processing functions over a wide instantaneous signal bandwidth is needed.  We propose here the development of a novel two dimensional acousto-optic processor for real-time multifunction signal processing including correlation, convolution, spectral analysis, and ambiguity and Wigner function calculation.  Applications for the pro- cessor include pulse-Doppler radar processing, target recognition using synthetic aperture radar processing, and communication and electronic warfare signal processing.  The optical design of the processor is based on a newly invented optically efficient, in-line, high stability, two dimensional interferometer using four acousto-optic devices.  Via the simple technique of Bragg cell carrier offset adjustments, the processor can generate the desired high dynamic range interferometric output on a chosen spatial carrier that is required for bias removal and electronic post-processing.  The proper choice of Bragg cells is key to realizing a wideband, robust, multifunction processor.
title: Optoelectronic Multifunction Signal Processor
Integrated Digitizing And Display Surface Utilizing Touch Entry, Geographical Information System, And Flat Panel Displays

abstract: This Small Business Innovation Research Phase I project aims to develop compact and low cost instruments to measure tissue oxygenation based on near-infrared (NIR) spectroscopy.  NIR light in the .7-1.1 Um range penetrates human tissue to a depth of several centimeters, and is attenuated during transmission by oxyhemoglobin, deoxyhemoglobin, melanin, water and cytochrome aa3, each with its own characteristic absorption spectrum.  NIR absorption spectroscopy offers a number of advantages in comparison with other oxygen measurement modalities: it is non-invasive,  uses non-ionizing radiation, offers high spatial and temporal resolution, and supplies new types of metabolic and functional information for low cost, rapid, bedside diagnostic procedures.  The Phase I project will determine the most practical means to implement a hand-held NIR spectroscopic oxygenation monitor,k specify the components needed, define the measurement method and assess the practicality of the instrument for Phase II development.
title: Non Invasive Deep Tissue Oxygenation Sensor

abstract: This Small Business Innovative Research Phase I project is directed to increasing the visible light response of photocatalytic oxidative destruction of organic materials by replacing titanium dioxide, the common photoconductor used in this process, with gallium indium nitride.  Success in achieving greater sensitivity to visible light will substantially improve the economics of using sunlight to destroy chemical warfare agents and other material interest to the Army.
title: Nitrides as Solar Photocatalysts for the Oxidation of Pollutants
The Development of an Off-Line Programming System For Automated Welding
